column1: brahmarātryāṃ vyatītāyāṃ prabuddhe padmasaṃbhave / viṣṇuḥ sisṛkṣur bhūtāni jñātvā bhūmiṃ jalānugām //
column2: THE night of Brahman being over, and the God sprung from the lotus (Brahman) having woke from his slumber, Vishnu purposing to create living beings, and perceiving the earth covered with water,

column1: jalakrīḍāruci śubhaṃ kalpādhiṣu yathā purā / vārāham āsthito rūpam ujjahāra vasuṃdharām //
column2: Assumed the shape of a boar, delighting to sport in water, as at the beginning of each former Kalpa, and raised up the earth (from the water).
His feet were the Vedas; his tusks the sacrificial stakes;
his tongue was the fire;
His eyes were day and night;
his voice was similar in sound to the chanting of the Sâma-veda;
and he was of huge size. He was full of piety and veracity;
his strides and his strength were immense (like those of Vishnu);
his scrotum was the sacrificial seeds and grains;
the hindparts (of Vishnu) in his transformation were the Mantras; his blood was the Soma juice.
his smell was that of the (sacrificial cake and other) oblations;
and instructed with the initiatory ceremonies for manifold sacrifices (lasting one, or two, three, or twelve years, and others).
he was possessed of the (sacrificial and other) great Mantras employed in order to effect the union of the mind with the Supreme;
his lovely, lips were the beginnings of the twohymns recited at the beginning of the animal sacrifice;
All sorts of sacred texts (the Gâyatrî and others) were his path in marching;
he was accompanied by his consort Khâyâ (Lakshmî);
he was in size like the Manisringa mountain.

column1: ekārṇavajalabhraṣṭām ekārṇavagataḥ prabhuḥ // daṃṣṭrāgreṇa samuddhṛtya lokānāṃ hitakāmyayā /
column2: The lord, the creator, the great Yogin, plunging into the one ocean from love of the world,

Raised up, with the edge of his tusks, the earth bounded by the sea together with its mountains, forests, and groves, which was immersed in the water of (the seven oceans now become) one ocean, and created the universe anew.

column1: evaṃ yajñavarāheṇa bhūtvā bhūtahitārthinā / uddhṛtā pṛthivī devī rasātalagatā purā //
column2: Thus the whole earth, after having sunk into (the lower region called) Rasâtala, was in the first place raised in the boar-incarnation by Vishnu, who took compassion upon the living beings.

column1: uddhṛtya niścale sthāne sthāpayitvā tathā svake / yathāsthānaṃ vibhajyāpas tadgatā madhusūdanaḥ // sāmudryaś ca samudreṣu nādeyīś ca nadīṣu ca /
column2: Then, after having raised the earth, the destroyer of Madhu placed and fixed it upon its own (former) seat (upon the oceans) and distributed the waters upon it according to their own (former) station, conducting the floods of the oceans into the oceans, the water of the rivers into the rivers, the water of the tanks into the tanks, and the water of the lakes into the lakes.

column1: pātālasaptakaṃ cakre lokānāṃ saptakaṃ tathā / dvīpānām udadhīnāṃ ca sthānāni vividhāni ca //
column2: He created the seven (lower regions called) Pâtâlas and the seven worlds, the seven Dvîpas.

column1: sthānapālān lokapālān nadīḥ śailavanaspatīn / ṛṣīṃś ca sapta dharmajñān vedān sānṅān surāsurān //
column2: (He created) the rulers of the (seven) Dvîpas and the (eight) guardians of the world (Indra and the rest), the rivers, mountains, and trees, the seven Rishis, who know (and practise) the law, the Vedas together with their Angas, the Suras, and the Asuras.

column1: piśācoragagandharva yakṣarākṣasamānuṣān / paśupakṣimṛgādyāṃś ca bhūtagrāmaṃ caturvidham / meghendracāpaśampādyān yajñāṃś ca vividhāṃs tathā //
column2: (He created) Pisâkas (ogres), Uragas (serpents), Gandharvas (celestial singers), Yakshas (keepers of Kubera's treasures), Rakshasas (goblins), and men, cattle, birds, deer and other animals, (in short) all the four kinds of living beings, and clouds, rainbows, lightnings, and other celestial phenomena or bodies (such as the planets and the asterisms), and all kinds of sacrifices.

column1: evaṃ varāho bhagavān kṛtvedaṃ sacarācaram / jagaj jagāma lokānām avijñātāṃ tadā gatim //
column2: Bhagavat, after having thus created, in theshape of a boar, this world together with all animate and inanimate things in it, went away into a place hidden from the world.

column1: avijñātāṃ gatiṃ yāte devadeve janārdane / vasudhā cintayām āsa kā dhṛtir me bhaviṣyati //
column2: Ganârdana, the chief of the gods, having become invisible, the goddess of the earth began to consider, 'How shall I be able to sustain myself (henceforth)?'

column1: pṛcchāmi kaśyapaṃ gatvā sa me vakṣyaty asaṃśayam / madīyāṃ vahate cintāṃ nityam eva mahāmuniḥ //
column2: 'I will go to Kasyapa to ask: he will tell me the truth. The great Muni has my welfare under constant consideration.'

column1: evaṃ sā niścayaṃ kṛtvā devī strīrūpadhāriṇī / jagāma kaśyapaṃ draṣṭuṃ dṛṣṭavāṃs tāṃ ca kaśyapaḥ //
column2: Having thus decided upon her course, the goddess, assuming the shape of a woman, went to see Kasyapa, and Kasyapa saw her.
her face was radiant like the moon in the autumn season;
her lip was (red) like the Bandhugîva flower;
Her eyebrows were fine; her teeth exceedingly small;
her neck shaped like a shell;

column1: virejatuḥ stanau yasyāḥ samau pīnau nirantarau /
column2: and they were fleshy thighs, which adorned her loins.
Her arms were as delicate as lotus fibres;

column1: rukmastambhanibhāv ūrū gūḍhe śliṣṭe ca jānunī //
column2: her thighs were resplendent like golden pillars;
Her legs were smooth and exquisitely proportioned;

column1: jaghanaṃ ca ghanaṃ madhyaṃ yathā kesariṇaḥ śiśoḥ //
column2: and her waist like that of a lion's cub.
Her reddish nails shone (like rubies); her beauty was the delight of every looker-on;
and with her glances she filled at every step all the quarters of the sky as it were with lotus-flowers.

column1: kurvāṇāṃ prabhayā devīṃ tathā vitimirā diśaḥ /
column2: Radiant with divine lustre, she illuminated all the quarters of the sky with it;
her clothing was most exquisite and perfectly white; and she was decorated with the most precious gems.
With her steps she covered the earth as it were with lotuses;
she was endowed with beauty and youthful charms;

column1: samīpam āgatāṃ dṛṣṭvā pūjayitvātha kaśyapaḥ / uvāca tāṃ varārohe vijñātaṃ hṛdgataṃ mayā //
column2: and made her approach with modest bearing. Having seen her come near, Kasyapa saluted her reverentially, and said, 'O handsome lady, O earth, radiant with divine lustre, I am acquainted with thy thoughts.

column1: dhare tava viśālākṣi gaccha devi janārdanam /
column2: 'Go to visit Ganârdana, O large-eyed lady;

column1: sa te vakṣyaty aśeṣeṇa bhāvinī te yathā dhṛtiḥ //
column2: he will tell thee accurately, how thou shalt henceforth sustain thyself.

column1: kṣīrode vasatis tasya mayā jñātā śubhānane / dhyānayogena cārvaṅgi tvadarthaṃ tatprasādataḥ //
column2: For thy sake, O (goddess), whose face is lovely and whose limbs are beautiful, I have found out, by profound meditation, that his residence is in the Kshîroda (milk-ocean).'

column1: ity evam uktā saṃpūjya kaśyapaṃ vasudhā tataḥ / prayayau keśavaṃ draṣṭuṃ kṣīrodam atha sāgaram //
column2: The goddess of the earth answered, 'Yes, (I shall do as you bid me),saluted Kasyapa reverentially,and proceeded to the Kshîroda sea, in order to see Kesava (Vishnu).
She beheld (then) the ocean, from which the Amrita arose. It was lovely, like the rays of the moon, and agitated by hundreds of waves produced by stormy blasts of wind.
(With its waves) towering like a hundred Himâlayas it seemed another terrestrial globe, calling near as it were the earth with its hands;
the rolling waves.

column1: tair eva śuklatāṃ candre vidadhānam ivāniśam /
column2: With those hands it was as it were constantly producing the radiancy of the moon;
and every stain of guilt was removed from it by Hari's (Vishnu's) residence within its limits.

column1: yasmāt tasmād dhārayantaṃ suśuklāṃ tanum ūrjitām /
column2: Because (it was entirely free from sin) therefore it was possessed of a pure and shining frame;
it was inaccessible to birds and its seat was in the lower regions.

column1: indranīlakaḍārāḍhyaṃ viparītam ivāmbaram / phalāvalīsamudbhūta- vanasaṃgham ivācitam //
column2: It was rich in blue and tawny gems (sapphires, coral, and others), and looking therefore as if the atmosphere had descended upon the earth, and as if a number of forests adorned with a multitude of fruits had descended upon its surface.

column1: taṃ dṛṣṭvā tatra madhyasthaṃ daḍṛśe keśavālayam //
column2: Its size was immense, like that of the skin of (Vishnu's) serpent Sesha. After having seen the milk-ocean, the goddess of the earth beheld the dwelling of Kesava (Vishnu) which was in it:

column1: anirdeśyaparīmāṇam anirdeśyarddhisaṃyutam / śeṣaparyaṅkagaṃ tasmin dadarśa madhusūdanam //
column2: (His dwelling), the size of which cannot be expressed in words, and, the sublimity of which is also beyond the power of utterance. In it she saw the destroyer of Madhu seated upon Sesha.
The lotus of his face was hardly visible onaccount of the lustre of the gems decorating the neck of the snake Sesha;
he was shining like a hundred moons; and his splendour was equal to the rays of a myriad of suns.
imperturbable; decorated with all kinds of gems;
and shining with the lustre of a diadem resembling the sun in colour, and with (splendid) ear-rings.
Lakshmî was stroking his feet with her soft palms;
and his attributes (the shell, the discus, the mace, and the lotus-flower) wearing bodies were attending upon him on all sides.
Having espied the lotus-eyed slayer of Madhu, she knelt down upon the ground and addressed him as follows:

column1: uddhṛtāhaṃ tvayā deva rasātalatalaṃ gatā / svasthāne sthāpitā viṣṇo lokānāṃ hitakāmyayā //
column2: 'When formerly I was sunk into the region of Rasâtala, I was raised by thee, O God, and restored to my ancient seat, O Vishnu, thanks to thy benevolence towards living beings.

column1: tatrādhunā hi deveśa kā dhṛtir me bhaviṣyati / evam uktas tayā devyā devo vacanam abravīt //
column2: 'Being there, how am I to maintain myself upon it, O lord of the gods?' Having been thus addressed by the goddess, the god enunciated the following answer:

column1: varṇāśramācāraratāḥ santaḥ śāstraikatatparāḥ / tvāṃ dhare dhārayiṣyanti teṣāṃ tvadbhāra āhitaḥ //
column2: 'Those who practise the duties ordained for each caste and for each order, and who act up strictly to the holy law, will sustain thee, O earth;

column1: evam uktā vasumatī devadevam abhāṣata / varṇānām āśramāṇāṃ ca dharmān vada sanātana //
column2: Having received this answer, the goddess of the earth said to the chief of the gods, 'Communicate to me the eternal laws of the castes and of the orders.

column1: tvatto 'ham śrotum icchāmi tvaṃ hi me paramā gatiḥ /
column2: I desire to learn them from thee;
for thou art my chief stay. Adoration be to thee, O brilliant chief of the gods, who annihilatest the power of the (Daityas and other) enemies of the gods.
'O Nârâyana (son of Nara), O Gagannâtha (sovereign of the world);
thou hast a lotus (Brahman) springing from thy navel;
thou art the lord of the senses;
thou art Govinda (the herdsman); thou art of old; thou art Purushottama (the spirit supreme).
'Thy hair is golden;
thou art the "field." (the corporeal frame);
thou art the principle of life;
thou art the teacher of religious rites;
thou art Purushottama.
thou art kind to faithful attendants; thou art the purifier (of sinners);

column1: tvaṃ gatiḥ sarvadevānāṃ tvaṃ gatir brahmavādinām //
column2: thou art the protector of all the gods thou art the protector of the pious.

column1: tathā viditavedyānāṃ gatis tvaṃ puruṣottama / prapannāsmi jagannātha dhruvaṃ vācaspatiṃ prabhum //
column2: 'Thou art also the protector of those who know the Veda, O Purushottama. I have come, O Gagannâtha, to the immovable Vâkaspati (the lord of holy speech), the lord;
Vasushena (who has treasures for his armies);
who bestows largesses upon his followers, who is endowed with the power of intense devotion; who is the germ of the ether;
'To Vâsudeva; the great soul of the universe; whose eyes are like lotuses;
who is eternal; the preceptor of the Suras and of the Asuras;

column1: ekavyūhaṃ caturbāhuṃ jagatkāraṇakāraṇam / brūhi me bhagavan dharmāṃś cāturvarṇyasya śāśvatān // āśramācārasaṃyuktān sarahasyān sasaṃgrahān /
column2: who is the producer of (the five grosser elements, ether, air, fire, water, and earth), the producers of the world. Teach me concisely, O Bhagavat, the eternal laws ordained for the aggregate of the four castes,

column1: evam uktas tu deveśaḥ kṣoṇyā kṣoṇīm abhāṣata //
column2: 'Together with the customs to be observed by each order and with the secret ordinances.' The chief of the gods, thus addressed by the goddess of the earth, replied to her as follows:

column1: śṛṇu devi dhare dharmāṃś cāturvarṇyasya śāśvatān / āśramācārasaṃyuktān sarahasyān sasaṃgrahān //
column2: Learn from me, in a concise form, O radiant goddess of the earth, the eternal laws for the aggregate of the four castes, together with the customs to be observed by each order, and with the secret ordinances,

column1: ye tu tvāṃ dhārayiṣyanti santas teṣāṃ parāyaṇān / niṣaṇṇā bhava vāmoru kāñcane 'smin varāsane //
column2: 'Which will effect the final liberation of the virtuous persons, who will support thee. Be seated upon this splendid golden seat, O handsome-thighed goddess.

column1: śuśruve vaiṣṇavān dharmān sukhāsīnā dharā tadā //
column2: 'Seated at ease, listen to me proclaiming the sacred laws.' The goddess of the earth, thereupon, seated at case, listened to the sacred precepts as, they came from the mouth of Vishnu.

column1: om / brāhmaṇaḥ kṣatriyo vaiśyaḥ śūdraś ceti varṇāś catvāraḥ //
column2: Brâhmanas, Kshatriyas, Vaisyas, and Sûdras are the four castes.
The first three of these are (called) twice-born.
For them the whole number of ceremonies, which begin with the impregnation and end with the ceremony of burning the dead body, have to be performed with (the recitation of) Mantras.
Their duties are.
For a Brâhmana, to teach (the Veda);
For a Kshatriya, constant practice in arms;
For a Vaisya, the tending of cattle;
For a Sûdra, to serve the twice-born;
For all the twice-born, to sacrifice and to study (the Veda).
Again, their modes of livelihood are:
For a Brâhmana, to sacrifice for others and to receive alms;
For a Kshatriya, to protect the world (and receive due reward, in form of taxes);
For a Vaisya, tillage, keeping cows (and other cattle), traffic, lending money upon interest, and growing seeds;
For a Sûdra, all branches of art (such as painting and the other fine arts);

column1: kṣamā satyam damaḥ śaucaṃ dānam indriyasaṃyamaḥ / ahiṃsā guruśuśrūṣā tīrthānusaraṇaṃ dayā //
column2: Forbearance, veracity, restraint, purity, liberality, self-control, not to kill (any living obedience towards one's Gurus, visiting places of pilgrimage, sympathy (with the afflicted),

column1: ārjavaṃ lobhaśūnyatvaṃ devabrāhmaṇapūjanam / anabhyasūyā ca tathā dharmaḥ sāmānya ucyate //
column2: Straightforwardness, freedom from covetousness, reverence towards gods and Brâhmanas, and freedom from anger are duties common (to all castes).
Now the duties of a king, are:
To protect his people,
And to keep the four castes and the four orders in the practice of their several duties.

column1: rājā ca jāṅgalaṃ paśavyaṃ sasyopetaṃ deśam āśrayet //
column2: Let the king fix his abode in a district containing open plains, fit for cattle, and abounding in grain;
And inhabited by many Vaisyas and Sûdras.

There let him reside in a stronghold (the strength of which consists) either in (its being surrounded by) a desert, or in (a throng of) armedmen, or in fortifications (of stone, brick, or others), or in water (enclosing it on all sides), or in trees, or in mountains (sheltering it against a foreign invasion).
(While he resides) there, let him appoint chiefs (or governors) in every village;
Also, lords of every ten villages;
And lords of every hundred villages;
And lords of a whole district.
If any offence has been committed in a village, let the lord of that village suppress the evil (and give redress to those that have been wronged).
If he is unable to do so, let him announce it to the lord of ten villages;
If he too is unable, let him announce it to the lord of a hundred villages;
If he too is unable, let him announce it to the lord of the whole district.
The lord of the whole district must eradicate the evil to the best of his power.
Let the king appoint able officials for the working of his mines, for the levying of taxes and of the fares to be paid at ferries, and for his elephants and forests.
(Let him appoint) pious persons for performing acts of piety (such as bestowing gifts on the indigent, and the like);
Skilled men for financial business (such as examining gold and other precious metals);
Brave men for fighting;
Eunuchs for his wives (as their guardians).

column1: prajābhyo balyarthaṃ saṃvatsareṇa dhānyataḥ ṣaṣṭham aṃśam ādadyāt //
column2: He must take from his subjects as taxes a sixth part every year of the grain;
And (a sixth part) of all (other) seeds;
Two in the hundred, of cattle, gold, and clothes;

A sixth part of flesh, honey, clarified butter, herbs, perfumes, flowers, roots, fruits, liquids and condiments, wood, leaves (of the Palmyra, tree and others), skins, earthen pots, stone vessels, and anything made of split bamboo.
Let him not levy any tax upon Brâhmanas.
For they pay taxes to him in the shape of their pious acts.
A sixth part both of the virtuous deeds and of the iniquitous acts committed by his subjects goes to the king.
Let him take a tenth part of (the price of) marketable commodities (sold) in his own country;
And a twentieth part of (the price of) goods (sold) in another country.
Any (seller or buyer) who (fraudulently) avoids a toll-house (situated on his road), shall lose all his goods.

column1: śilpinaḥ karmajīvinaś ca māsenaikaṃ rājñaḥ karma kuryuḥ // svāmyamātyadurgakośadaṇḍarāṣṭramitrāṇi prakṛtayaḥ //
column2: Artizans (such as blacksmiths), manual labourers (such as carpenters), and Sûdras shall do work for the king for a day in each month.
(The king) must punish those who try to subvert any one among them.
He must explore, by means of spies, both the state of his own kingdom and of his foe's.
Let him show honour to the righteous;
And let him punish the unrighteous.

Towards his (neighbour and natural) enemy, his ally (or the power next beyond his enemy), a neutral power (situated beyond the latter), and a power situated between (his natural enemy and an aggressive power): let him adopt (alternately), as the occasion and the time require, (the four modes of obtaining success, viz.) negotiation, division, presents, and force of arms.

Let him have resort, as the time demands, to (the six measures of a military monarch, viz.) making alliance and waging war, marching to battle and sitting encamped, seeking the protection (of a more powerful king) and distributing his forces.
Let him set out on an expedition in the months of Kaitra or Mârgasîrsha;
Or when some calamity has befallen his foe.
Having conquered the country of his foe, let him not abolish (or disregard) the laws of that country.
And when he has been attacked by his foe, let him protect his own realm to the best of his power.
There is no higher duty for men of the military caste, than to risk their life in battle.
Those who have been killed in protecting a cow, or a Brâhmana, or a king, or a friend, or their own property, or their own wedded wife, or their own life, go to heaven.
Likewise, those (who have been killed) in trying to prevent mixture of castes (caused by adulterous connections).
A king having conquered the capital of his foe, should invest there a prince of the royal race of that country with the royal dignity.
Let him not extirpate the royal race
Unless the royal race bc of ignoble descent.
He must not take delight in hunting, dice, women, and drinking;
Nor in defamation and battery.
And let him not injure his own property (by bootless expenses).
He must not demolish (whether in his own town, or in the town of his foe conquered by him,or in a fort) doors which had been built there before his time (by a former king).
He must not bestow largesses upon unworthy persons (such as dancers, eulogists, bards, and the like).
Of mines let him take the whole produce.
Of a treasure-trove he must give one half to the Brâhmanas;
He may deposit the other half in his own treasury.
A Brâhmana who has found a treasure may keep it entire.

column1: kṣatriyaś caturtham aṃśaṃ rājñe dadyāt, caturtham aṃśaṃ brāhmaṇebhyaḥ, ardham ādadyāt //
column2: A Kshatriya (who has found a treasure) must give one fourth of it to the king, another fourth to the Brâhmanas, and keep half of it to himself

column1: vaiṣyas tu caturtham aṃśaṃ rājñe dadyāt, brāhmaṇebhyo 'rdhaṃ, caturtham aṃśam ādadyāt //
column2: A Vaisya (who has found a treasure) must give a fourth part of it to the king, one half to the Brâhmanas, and keep the (remaining fourth) part to himself.

column1: śūdraś cāvāptaṃ dvādaśadhā vibhajya pañcāṃśān rājñe dadyāt, pañcāṃśān brāhmaṇebhyaḥ, aṃśadvayam ādadyāt //
column2: A Sûdra who has found a treasure must divide it into twelve parts, and give five parts to the king, five parts to the Brâhmanas, and keep two parts to himself.
Let the king compel him who (having found a treasure) does not announce it (to the king) and is found out afterwards, to give up the whole.

column1: svanihitād rājñe brāhmaṇavarjaṃ dvādaśam aṃśaṃ dadyuḥ //
column2: Of a treasure anciently hidden by themselves let (members of) all castes, excepting Brâhmanas, give a twelfth part to the king.

column1: paranihitaṃ svanihitam iti bruvaṃs tatsamaṃ daṇḍam āvahet //
column2: The man who falsely claims property hidden by another to have been hidden by himself, shall becondemned to pay a fine equal in amount to the property falsely claimed by him.
The king must protect the property of minors, of (blind, lame or other) helpless persons (who have no guide), and of women (without a guardian).

column1: caurahṛtaṃ dhanam avāpya sarvam eva sarvavarṇebhyo dadyāt //
column2: Having recovered goods stolen by thieves, let him restore them entire to their owners, to whatever caste they may belong.
If he has been unable to recover them, he must pay (their value) out of his own treasury.
Let him appease the onsets of fate by ceremonies averting evil omens and propitiatory ceremonies;
And the onsets of his foe (let him repel) by force of arms.

column1: vedetihāsadharmaśāstrārthakuśalaṃ kulīnam avyaṅgaṃ tapasvinaṃ purohitaṃ ca varayet //
column2: Let him appoint as Purohita (domestic priest) a man conversant with the Vedas, Epics, the Institutes of Sacred Law, and (the science of) what is useful in life, of a good family, not deficient in limb, and persistent in the practice of austerities.

column1: śucīn alubdhān avahitān śaktisaṃpannān sarvārtheṣu ca sahāyān //
column2: And (let him appoint) ministers (to help and advise him) in all his affairs, who are pure, free from covetousness, attentive, and able.

column1: svayam eva vyavahārān paśyed vidvadbhir brāhmaṇaiḥ sārdham //
column2: Let him try causes himself, accompanied by well-instructed Brâhmanas.
Or let him entrust a Brâhmana, with the judicial business.

column1: janmakarmavratopetāś ca rājñā sabhāsadaḥ kāryāḥ, ripau mitre ca ye samāḥ, kāmakrodhabhayalobhādibhiḥ kāryārthabhir anāhāryāḥ //
column2: Let the king appoint as judges men of goodfamilies, for whom the ceremonies (of initiation and so forth) have been performed, and who are eager in keeping religious vows, impartial towards friend and foe, and not likely to be corrupted by litigants either by (ministering to their) lustful desires or by (stimulating them to) wrath or by (exciting their) avarice or by other (such practices).
Let the king in all matters listen to (the advice of) his astrologers.
Let him constantly show reverence to the gods and to the Brâhmanas.
Let him honour the aged;
And let him offer sacrifices;
And he must not suffer any Brâhmana in his realm to perish with want;
Nor any other man leading a pious life.
Let him bestow landed property upon Brâhmanas.

column1: yeṣāṃ ca pratipādayet teṣāṃ svavaṃśyān bhuvaḥ parimāṇaṃ dānacchedopavarṇanaṃ ca paṭe tāmrapaṭṭe vā likhitaṃ svamudrāṅkitaṃ cāgāminṛpativijñāpanārthaṃ  # dadyāt //
column2: To those upon whom he has bestowed (land) he must give a document, destined for the information of a future ruler, which must be written upon a piece of (cotton) cloth, or a copper-plate, and must contain the names of his (three) immediate ancestors, a declaration of the extent of the land, and an imprecation against him who should appropriate thedonation to himself, and should be signed with his own seal.
Let him not appropriate to himself landed property bestowed (upon Brâhmanas) by other (rulers).
Let him present the Brâhmanas with gifts of every kind.
Let him be on his guard, whatever he may be about.
Let him be splendid (in apparel and ornaments).
Let him be conversant with incantations dispelling the effects of poison and sickness.
Let him not test any aliments, that have not been tried before (by his attendants, by certain experiments).
Let him smile before he speaks to any one.
Let him not frown even upon (criminals) doomed to capital punishment.
Let him inflict punishments, corresponding to the nature of their offences, upon evil-doers.
Let him inflict punishments according to justice (either personally or through his attendants).

column1: dvitīyam aparādhaṃ na sa kasyacit kṣameta //
column2: Let him pardon no one for having offended twice.
He who deviates from his duty must certainly not be left unpunished by the king.

column1: yatra śyāmo lohitākṣo daṇḍaś carati nirbhayaḥ / prajās tatra vivardhante netā cet sādhu paśyati //
column2: Where punishment with a black hue and a red eye advances with irresistible might, the king deciding causes justly, there the people will prosper.

column1: svarāṣṭro nyāyadaṇḍaḥ syād bhṛśadaṇḍaś ca śatruṣu / suhṛtsv ajihmaḥ snigdheṣu brāhmaṇeṣu kṣamānvitaḥ //
column2: Let a king in his own domain inflict punishments according to justice, chastise foreign foes with rigour, behave without duplicity to his affectionate friends, and with lenity to Brâhmanas.

column1: evaṃvṛttasya nṛpateḥ śiloñchenāpi jīvataḥ / vistīryate yaśo loke tailabindur ivāmbhasi //
column2: Of a king thus disposed, even though he subsist by gleaning, the fame is far spread in the world, like a drop of oil in the water.

column1: prajāsukhe sukhī rājā tadduḥkhe yaś ca duḥkhitaḥ / sa kīrtiyukto loke 'smin pretya svarge mahīyate //
column2: That king who is pleased when his subjects are joyful, and grieved when they are in grief, will obtain fame in this world, and will be raised to a high station in heaven after his death.
The (very small mote of) dust which may be discerned in a sun-beam passing through a lattice is called trasarenu (trembling dust).
Eight of these (trasarenus) are equal to a nit.
Six of these are equal to a barley-corn.
Three of these equal a Krishnala.
Five of these equal a Mâsha.
Twelve of these are equal to half an Aksha.
The weight of half an Aksha, with four Mâshas added to it, is called a Suvarna.
Four Suvarnas make a Nishka.
Two Krishnalas of equal weight are equal to one Mâshaka of silver.
Sixteen of these are equal to a Dharana (of silver).
A Karsha (or eighty Raktikâs) of copper is called Kârshâpana.

column1: paṇānāṃ dve śate sārdhe prathamaḥ sāhasaḥ smṛtaḥ / madhyamaḥ pañca vijñeyaḥ sahasraṃ tv eṣa cottamaḥ //
column2: Two hundred and fifty (copper) Panas are declared to be the first (or lowest) amercement, five hundred are considered as the middlemost, and a thousand as the highest.
Great criminals should all be put to death.
In the case of a Brâhmana. no corporal punishment must be inflicted.
A Brâhmana must be banished from his own country, his body having been branded.

column1: tasya ca brahmahatyāyām aśiraskaṃ puruṣaṃ lalāṭe kuryāt //
column2: For murdering another Brâhmana, let (the figure of) a headless corpse be impressed on his forehead;
For drinking spirits, the flag of a seller of spirituous liquor;
For stealing (gold), a dog's foot,
For incest, (the mark of) a female part.

column1: anyatrāpi vadhyakarmaṇi tiṣṭhantaṃ samagradhanam akṣataṃ vivāsayet //
column2: If he has committed any other capital crime, he shall be banished, taking with him all his property, and unhurt.
Let the king put to death those who forge royal edicts;
And those who forge (private) documents;
Likewise poisoners, incendiaries, robbers, and killers of women, children, or men;

column1: ye ca dhānyaṃ daśabhyaḥ kumbhebhyo 'dhikam apahareyuḥ //
column2: And such as steal more than ten Kumbhas of grain,
Or more than a hundred Mâshas of such things as are usually sold by weight (such as gold and silver);
Such also as aspire to sovereignty, though being of low birth;
Breakers of dikes;
And such as give shelter and food to robbers,
Unless the king be unable (to protect his subjects against robbers);
And a woman who violates she owes to her lord, the latter being unable to restrain her.

column1: hīnavarṇo 'dhikavarṇasya yenāṅgenāparādhaṃ kuryāt tad evāsya śātayet //
column2: With whatever limb an inferior insults or hurts his superior in caste, of that limb the king shall cause him to be deprived.

column1: ekāsanopaveśī kaṭyāṃ kṛtāṅko nirvāsyaḥ // niṣṭhīvyauṣṭhadvayavihīnaḥ kāryaḥ //
column2: If he places himself on the same seat with his superior, he shall be banished with a mark on his buttocks. he shall lose both lips;
If he breaks wind against him, his hindparts;
If he uses abusive language, his tongue.

column1: darpeṇa dharmopadeśakāriṇāṃ rājā taptam āsecayet tailam āsye //
column2: If a (low-born) man through pride give instruction (to a member of the highest caste) concerning his duty, let the king order hot oil to be dropped into his mouth.

column1: droheṇa ca nāmajātigrahaṇe daśāṅgulo 'sya śaṅkur nikheyaḥ //
column2: If a (low-born man) mentions the name or caste of a superior revilingly, an iron pin, ten inches long, shall be thrust into his mouth (red hot).

He who falsely denies the sacred knowledge, the country, or the caste (of such), or who saysthat his religious duties have not been fulfilled by (or that the initiatory and other sacramental rites have not been performed for) him, shall be fined two hundred Panas.
If a man is blind with one eye, or lame, or defective in any similar way, and another calls him so, he shall be fined two Kârshâpanas, though he speaks the truth.
He shall be fined a hundred Kârshâpanas for defaming a Guru.
He shall pay the highest amercement for imputing to another (a great crime) entailing loss of caste;
The second amercement for (imputing to another) a minor offence (such as the slaughter of a cow);
The same for reviling a Brâhmana versed in the three Vedas, or an old man, or a (whole) caste or corporation (of judges or others);
For reviling a village or district, the lowest amercement;
For using insulting language (such as 'I shall visit your sister,' or 'I shall visit your daughter'), a hundred Kârshâpanas;
For abusing a man of his own caste, he shall be fined twelve Panas.
For abusing a man of a lower caste, he shall be fined six (Panas).
For insulting a member of the highest caste or of his own caste (he having been insulted by him) at the same time, the same fine is ordained;
Or (if he only returns his insult, a fine amounting to) three Kârshâpanas.
An adulterer shall be made to pay the highest amercement if he has had connection with a woman of his own caste;
For adultery with women of a lower caste, the second amercement;
The same (fine is ordained) for a bestial crime committed with a cow.
He who has had connection with a woman of one of the lowest castes, shall be put to death.
For a bestial crime committed with cattle (other than cows) he shall be fined a hundred Kârshâpanas.
(The same fine is ordained) for giving a (blemished) damsel in marriage, without indicating her blemish (whether the bride be sick, or no longer a maid, or otherwise faulty);
And he shall have to support her.
He who says of an unblemished damsel, that she has a blemish (shall pay) the highest amercement.
For killing an elephant, or a horse, or a camel, or a cow, (the criminal) shall have one hand, or one foot, lopped off
A seller of forbidden meat (such as pork, shall be punished in the same way).
He who kills domestic animals, shall pay a hundred Kârshâpanas.
He shall make good their value to the owner of those animals.
He who kills wild animals, shall pay five hundred Kârshâpanas.
A killer of birds, or of fish, (shall pay) ten Kârshâpanas.
A killer of insects shall pay one Kârshâpanas.
A feller of trees yielding fruit (shall pay) the highest amercement.
A feller of trees yielding blossoms only (shall pay) the second amercement.
He who cuts creepers, shrubs, or climbing plants (shall pay) a hundred Kârshâpanas.
He who cuts grass (shall pay) one Kârshâpanas.
And all such offenders (shall make good) to the owners (of the trees or plants cut down by them) the revenue which they yield.
If any man raises his hand (against his equal in caste, with intent to strike him, he shall pay) ten Kârshâpanas;
If he raises his foot, twenty;
If he raises a piece of wood, the first amercement;
If he raises a stone, the second amercement;
If he raises a weapon, the highest amercement.
If he seizes him by his feet, by his hair, byhis garment, or by his hand, he shall pay ten Panas as a fine.

column1: śoṇitena vinā duḥkham utpādayitā dvātriṃśat paṇān //
column2: If he causes pain to him, without fetching blood from him, (he shall pay) thirty-two Panas;
For fetching blood from him, sixty-four.
For mutilating or injuring a hand, or a foot, or a tooth, and for slitting an ear, or the nose, the second amercement (is ordained).
For rendering a man unable to move about, or to eat, or to speak, or for striking him (violently, the same punishment is ordained).
For wounding or breaking an eye, or the neck, or an arm, or a bone, or a shoulder, the highest amercement (is ordained).

column1: ubhayanetrabhedinaṃ rājā yāvaj jīvaṃ bandhanān na muñcet //
column2: For striking out both eyes of a man, the king shall (confine him and) not dismiss him from jail as long as he lives;
Or he shall order him to be mutilated in the same way (i.e. deprived of his eyes).

column1: ekaṃ bahūnāṃ nighnatāṃ pratyekam uktād daṇḍād dviguṇaḥ //
column2: Where one is attacked by many, the punishment for each shall be the double of that which has been ordained for (attacks by) a single person.
(The double punishment is) likewise (ordained) for those who do not give assistance to one calling for help, though they happen to be on the spot, or (who run away) after having approached it.
All those who have hurt a man, shall pay the expense of his cure.
Those who have hurt a domestic animal (shall also pay the expense of his cure).
He who has stolen a cow, or a horse, or a camel, or an elephant, shall have one hand, or one foot, cut off;
He who has stolen a goat, or a sheep, (shall have) one hand (cut off).
He who steals grain (of those sorts which grow in the rainy season), shall pay eleven times its value as a fine;
Likewise, he who steals grain (of those sorts, which grow in winter and spring, such as rice and barley).

column1: suvarṇarajatavastrāṇāṃ pañcāśatas tv abhyadhikam apaharan vikaraḥ //
column2: A stealer of gold, silver, or clothes, at a value of more than fifty Mâshas, shall lose both hands.
He who steals a less amount than that, shall pay eleven times its value as a fine.

A stealer of thread, cotton, cow-dung, sugar, sour milk, milk, butter-milk, grass, salt, clay, ashes, birds, fish, clarified butter, oil, meat, honey, basketwork, canes of bamboo, earthenware, or iron pots, shall pay three times their value as a fine.
(The same fine is ordained for stealing) dressed food.
For stealing flowers, green (grain), shrubs, creepers, climbing plants or leaves, (he shall pay) five Krishnalas.
For stealing pot-herbs, roots, or fruits (the same punishment is ordained).
He who steals gems, (shall pay) the highest amercement.
He who steals anything not mentioned above, (shall make good) its value (to the owner).
Thieves shall be compelled to restore all stolen goods to the owners.
After that, they shall suffer the punishment that has been ordained for them.

column1: yeṣāṃ deyaḥ panthās teṣām apathadāyī kārṣāpaṇapañcaviṃśatiṃ daṇḍyaḥ //
column2: He who does not make way for one forwhom way ought to be made, shall be fined twenty-five Kârshâpanas.
(The same fine is ordained) for omitting to offer a seat to (a guest or others) to whom it ought to be offered.
For neglecting to worship such as have a claim to be worshipped, (the same fine is ordained);
Likewise, for neglecting to invite (at a Srâddha) a Brâhmana, one's neighbour;
And for offering him no food, after having invited him.
He who does not eat, though he has received and accepted an invitation, shall give a gold Mâshaka as a fine;
And the double amount of food to his host.
He who insults a Brâhmana by offering him uneatable food (such as excrements and the like, or forbidden food, such as garlic, must pay) sixteen Suvarnas (as a fine).
(If he insults him by offering him) such food as would cause him to be degraded (were he to taste it, he must pay) a hundred Suvarnas.
(If he offers him) spirituous liquor, he shall be put to death.
If he insults a Kshatriya (in the same way), he shall have to pay half of the above amercement;
If he insults a Vaisya, half of that again;
If he insults a Sûdra, the first amercement.

column1: aspṛśyaḥ kāmakāreṇa spṛśan spṛśyaṃ traivarṇikaṃ vadhyaḥ //
column2: If one who (being a member of the Kandâla or some other low caste) must not be touched, intentionallydefiles by his touch one who (as a member of a twice-born caste) may be touched (by other twice-born persons only), he shall be put to death.
If a woman in her courses (touches such a person), she shall be lashed with a whip.
If one defiles the highway, or a garden, or the water (by voiding excrements) near them (or in any other way), he shall be fined a hundred Panas;
And he must remove the filth.
If he demolishes a house, or a piece of ground (a court-yard or the like), or a wall or the like, he shall have to pay the second amercement;
And he shall have it repaired (at his own cost).
If he throws into another man's house (thorns, spells, or other) such things as might hurt some one, he shall pay a hundred Panas.
(The same punishment is ordained) for falsely denying the possession of common property;
And for not delivering what has been sent (for a god or for a Brâhmana).

(The same punishment is) also (ordained) for father and son, teacher (and pupil), sacrificer and officiating priest, if one should forsake the other, provided that he has not been expelled from caste.
And he must return to them (to the parents and the rest).
(The same punishment is) also (ordained) for hospitably entertaining a Sûdra or religious ascetic at an oblation to the gods or to the manes;
And for following an unlawful occupation(such as studying the Vedas without having been initiated);
And for breaking open a house on which (the king's) seal is laid;
And for making an oath without having been asked to do so (by the king or a judge);
And for depriving cattle of their virility.
The fine for the witnesses in a I dispute between father and son shall be ten Panas.
For him who acts as surety for either of the two parties in such a contest, the highest amercement (is ordained).
(The same punishment is ordained) for forging a balance, or a measure;

(The same punishment is) also (ordained) for selling adulterated commodities; And for a company of merchants who prevent the sale of a commodity (which happens to be abroad) by selling it under its price.
(The same punishment is ordained) for those (members of such a company) who sell (an article belonging to the whole company for more than it is worth) on their own account.

column1: pratyekaṃ vikrīṇatāṃ ca // gṛhītamūlyaṃ yaḥ paṇyaṃ kretur naiva dadyāt,
column2: He who does not deliver to the purchaser a commodity (sold), after its price has been paid to him, shall be compelled to deliver it to him with interest;
And he shall be fined a hundred Panas by the king.

column1: krītam akrīṇato yā hāniḥ sā kretur eva syāt //
column2: If there should be a loss upon a commodity purchased, which the purchaser refuses to accept (though it has been tendered to him), the loss shall fall upon the purchaser.
He who sells a commodity on which the king has laid an embargo, shall have it confiscated.

column1: tarikaḥ sthalajaṃ śulkaṃ gṛhṇan daśapaṇān daṇḍyaḥ //
column2: A ferry-man who takes a toll payable (for commodities conveyed) by land shall be fined ten Panas.

Likewise, a ferry-man, or an official at a toll-office, who takes a fare or toll from a student, or Vânaprastha (hermit), or a Bhikshu (ascetic or religious mendicant), or a pregnant woman, or one about to visit a place of pilgrimage;
And he shall restore it to them.
Those who use false dice in gaming shall lose one hand.
Those who resort to (other) fraudulent practices in gaming shall lose two fingers (the thumb and the index).

column1: granthibhedakānāṃ ca // utkṣepakānāṃ ca karacchedaḥ // divā paśūnāṃ vṛkādyupaghāte pāle tv anāyati pāladoṣaḥ //
column2: Cattle being attacked, during day-time, by wolves or other ferocious animals, and the keeper not going (to repel the attack), the blame shall fall upon him;
And he shall make good to the owner the value of the cattle that has perished.
If he milks a cow without permission, (he shall pay) twenty-five Kârshâpanas (as a fine).

column1: mahiṣī cet sasyanāśaṃ kuryāt, tatpālas tv aṣṭau māṣān daṇḍyaḥ //
column2: If a female buffalo damages grain, her keeper shall be fined eight Mâshas.
If she has been without a keeper, her owner (shall pay that fine).
(For mischief done by) a horse, or a camel, or an ass (the fine shall be the same).
(For damage done by) a cow, it shall be half.
(For damage done by) a goat, or a sheep, (it shall be) half of that again.
For cattle abiding (in the field), after having eaten (grain), the fine shall be double.
And in every case the owner (of the field) shall receive the value of the grain that has been destroyed.
There is no offence if the damage has been done near a highway, near a village, or (in a field adjacent to) the common pasture-ground for cattle;
Or (if it has been done) in an uninclosed field;
Or if the cattle did not abide long;

column1: yas tūttamavarṇān dāsye niyojayet tasyottamasāhaso daṇḍaḥ //
column2: He who commits members of the highest (or Brâhmana) caste to slavery, shall pay the highest amercement.
An apostate from religious mendicity shall become the king's slave.

column1: bhṛtakaś cāpūrṇe kāle bhṛtiṃ tyajan sakalam eva mūlyaṃ dadyāt //
column2: A hired workman who abandons his work before the term has expired shall pay the whole amount (of the stipulated wages) to his employer .
And he shall pay a hundred Panas to the king.
What has been destroyed through his want of care, (he must make good) to the owner;
Unless the damage have been caused by an accident.

column1: svāmī cet bhṛtakam apūrṇe kāle jahyāt, tasya sarvam eva mūlyaṃ dadyāt //
column2: If an employer dismisses a workman (whom he has hired) before the expiration of the term, he shall pay him his entire wages;
And (he shall pay) a hundred Panas to the king;

column1: yaḥ kanyāṃ pūrvadattām anyasmai dadyāt, sa cauravac chāsyaḥ //
column2: He who, having promised his daughter to one suitor, gives her in marriage to another, shall be punished as a thief;
Unless the (first) suitor have a blemish.
The same (punishment is ordained for a suitor) who abandons a faultless girl;
(And for a husband who forsakes) a (blameless) wife.

column1: ajānānaḥ prakāśaṃ yaḥ paradravyaṃ krīṇīyāt, tatra tasya na doṣaḥ //
column2: He who buys unawares in open market the property of another man (from one not authorised to sell it) is not to blame;
(But) the owner shall recover his property.

column1: yady aprakāśaṃ hīnamūlyaṃ ca krīṇīyāt, tadā kretā vikretā ca cauravac chāsyau //
column2: If he has bought it in secret and under its price, the purchaser and the vendor shall be punished as thieves.
He who embezzles goods belonging to a corporation (of Brâhmanas, and which have been sent to them by the king or by private persons), shall be banished.
He who violates their established. rule (shall) also (be banished).
He who retains a deposit shall restore the commodity deposited to the owner, with interest.
The king shall punish him as a thief
(The same punishment is ordained for him) who claims as a deposit what he never deposited.

column1: sīmābhettāram uttamasāhasaṃ daṇḍayitvā punaḥ sīmāṃ kārayet //
column2: A destroyer of landmarks shall be compelled to pay the highest amercement and to mark the boundary anew with landmarks.
He who (knowingly) eats forbidden food effecting loss of caste shall be banished.
He who sells forbidden food (such as spirituous liquor and the like), or food which must not be sold, and he who breaks an image of a deity, shall pay the highest amercement;
Also, a physician who adopts a wrong method of cure in the case of a patient of high rank (such as a relative of the king's);
The second amercement in the case of another patient;
The lowest amercement in the case of an animal.
He who does not give what he has promised, shall be compelled to give it and to pay the first amercement.
To a false witness his entire property shall be confiscated.
(The same punishment is ordained) for a judge who lives by bribes.

column1: gocarmamātrādhikāṃ bhuvam anyasyādhīkṛtāṃ tasmād anirmocyānyasya yaḥ prayacchet sa vadhyaḥ //
column2: He who has mortgaged more than a bull's hide of land to one creditor, and without having redeemed it mortgages it to another, shall be corporally punished (by whipping or imprisonment).
If the quantity be less, he shall pay a fine of sixteen Suvarnas.

column1: eko 'śnīyād yad utpannaṃ naraḥ saṃvatsaraṃ phalam /
column2: That land, whether little or much, on the produce of which one man can subsist for a year, is called the quantity of a bull's hide.

column1: yayor nikṣipta ādhis tau vivadetāṃ yadā narau / yasya bhuktiḥ phalaṃ tasya balāt kāraṃ vinā kṛtā //
column2: If a dispute should arise between two (creditors) concerning (a field or other immovable property) which has been mortgaged to both at the same time, that mortgagee shall enjoy its produce who holds it in his possession, without having obtained it by force.

column1: sāgamena tu bhogena bhuktaṃ samyag yadā tu yat /
column2: What has been possessed in order and with a legitimate title (such as purchase, donation, and the like), the possessor may keep;

column1: āhartā labhate tatra nāpahāryaṃ tu tat kvacit //
column2: it can never be taken from him.

column1: pitrā bhuktaṃ tu yad dravyaṃ bhuktyācāreṇa dharmataḥ /
column2: Where (land or other) property has been held in legitimate possession by the father (or grandfather), the son's right to it, after his death, cannot be contested;

column1: tasmin prete na vācyo 'sau bhuktyā prāptaṃ hi tasya tat //
column2: for it has become his own by force of possession.
If possession has been held of an estate by three (successive) generations in due course, the fourth in descent shall keep it as his property, even without a written title.

column1: nakhināṃ śṛṅgiṇāṃ caiva daṃṣṭriṇām ātatāyinām / hastyaśvānāṃ tathānyeṣāṃ vadhe hantā na doṣabhāk //
column2: He who kills (in his own defence a tiger or other) animal with sharp nails and claws, or a (goat or other) horned animal (excepting cows), or a (boar or other) animal with sharp teeth, or an assassin, or an elephant, or a horse, or any other (ferocious animal by whom he has been attacked), commits no crime.

column1: guruṃ vā bālavṛddhau vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā bahuśrutam / ātatāyinam āyāntaṃ hanyād evāvicārayan //
column2: Any one may unhesitatingly slay a man who attacks him with intent to murder him, whether his spiritual teacher, young or old, or a Brâhmana,or even (a Brâhmana) versed in many branches of sacred knowledge.
By killing an assassin who attempts to kill, Whether in public or in private, no crime is committed by the slayer: fury recoils upon fury.

column1: udyatāsiviṣāgniṃ ca śāpodyatakaraṃ tathā / ātharvaṇena hantāraṃ piśunaṃ caiva rājasu // bhāryātikramiṇaṃ caiva vidyāt saptātatāyinaḥ /
column2: Assassins should be known to be of seven kinds: such as try to kill with the sword, or with poison, or with fire, such as raise their hand in order to pronounce a curse, such as recite a deadly incantation from the Atharva-veda, such as raise a false accusation which reaches the ears of the king,

And such as have illicit intercourse with another man's wife. The same designation is given to other (evil-doers) who deprive others of their worldly fame or of their wealth, or who destroy religious merit (by ruining pools, or other such acts), or property (such as houses or fields).

column1: uddeśatas te kathito dhare daṇḍavidhir mayā / sarveṣām aparādhānāṃ vistarād ativistaraḥ //
column2: Thus I have declared to thee fully, O Earth, the criminal laws, enumerating at full length the punishments ordained for all sorts of offences.

column1: aparādheṣu cānyesu jñātvā jātiṃ dhanaṃ vayaḥ / daṇḍaṃ prakalpayed rājā saṃmantrya brāhmaṇaiḥ saha //
column2: Let the king dictate due punishments for other offences also, after having ascertained the class and the age (of the criminal) and the amount (of the damage done or sum claimed), and after having consulted the Brâhmanas (his advisers).

column1: daṇḍyaṃ pramocayan daṇḍyād dviguṇaṃ daṇḍam āvahet / niyuktaś cāpy adaṇḍyānāṃ daṇḍakārī narādhamaḥ //
column2: That detestable judge who dismisses without punishment such as deserve it, and punishes such as deserve it not, shall incur twice as heavy a penalty as the criminal himself.

column1: yasya cauraḥ pure nāsti nānyastrīgo na duṣṭavāk / na sāhasikadaṇḍaghnau sa rājā śakralokabhāk //
column2: A king in whose dominion there exists neither thief, nor adulterer, nor calumniator, nor robber, nor murderer, attains the World of Indra.
A creditor shall receive his principal back from his debtor exactly as he had lent it to him.

column1: dvikaṃ trikaṃ catuṣkaṃ pañcakaṃ ca śataṃ varṇānukrameṇa pratimāsam //
column2: (As regards the interest to be paid), he shall take in the direct order of the castes two, three, four, or five in the hundred by the month (if no pledge has been given).

column1: sarve varṇā vā svapratipannāṃ vṛddhiṃ dadyuḥ //
column2: Or let debtors of any caste pay as much interest as has been promised by themselves.
After the lapse of one year let them pay interest according to the above rule, even though it have not been agreed on.

column1: daivarājopaghātād ṛte vinaṣṭam ādhim uttamarṇo dadyāt //
column2: The creditor must make good the loss of a, pledge, unless it was caused by fate or by the king.
(The pledge must) also (be restored to the debtor) when the interest has reached its maximum amount (on becoming equal to the principal, and has all been paid).
But he must not restore an immovable pledge without special agreement (till the principal itself has been paid).

column1: gṛhītadhanapraveśārtham eva yat sthāvaraṃ dattaṃ tat gṛhītadhanapraveśe dadyāt //
column2: That immovable property which has been delivered, restorable when the sum borrowed is made good, (the creditor) must restore when the sum borrowed has been made good.

column1: dīyamānaṃ prayuktam artham uttamarṇasyāgṛhṇatas tataḥ paraṃ na vardhate //
column2: Property lent bears no further interest after it has been tendered, but refused by the creditor.
On gold the interest shall rise no higher than to make the debt double;
On grain, (no higher than to make it) threefold;.
On cloth, (no higher than to make it) fourfold;
On liquids, (no higher than to make it) eightfold;
Of female slaves and cattle, the offspring (shall be taken as interest).
On substances from which spirituous liquoris extracted, on cotton, thread, leather, weapons, bricks, and charcoal, the interest is unlimited.
On such objects as have not been mentioned it may be double.

column1: prayuktam arthaṃ yathā kathaṃcit sādhayan na rājño vācyaḥ syāt //
column2: A creditor recovering the sum lent by any (lawful) means shall not be reproved by the king.

column1: sādhyamānaś ced rājānam abhigacchet tatsamaṃ daṇḍyaḥ //
column2: If the debtor, so forced to discharge the debt, complains to the king, he shall be fined in an equal sum.

column1: uttamarṇaś ced rājānam iyāt, tadvibhāvito 'dhamarṇo rājñe dhanadaśabhāgasaṃmitaṃ daṇḍaṃ dadyāt //
column2: If a creditor sues before the king and fully proves his demand, the debtor shall pay as a fine to the king a tenth part of the sum proved;
And the creditor, having received the sum due, shall pay a twentieth part of it.
If the whole demand has been contested by the debtor, and even a part of it only has been proved against him, he must pay the whole.

column1: tasya ca bhāvanās tisro bhavanti likhitaṃ sākṣiṇaḥ samayakriyā ca //
column2: There are three means of proof in case of a demand having been contested, viz. a writing, witnesses, and proof by ordeal.
A debt contracted before witnesses should be discharged in the presence of witnesses.
A written contract having been fulfilled, the writing should be torn.
Part only being paid, and the writing not being at hand, let the creditor give an acquittance.

column1: dhanagrāhiṇi prete prevrajite dvidaśāḥ samāḥ pravasite vā tatputrapautrair dhanaṃ deyam //
column2: If he who contracted the debt should die, orbecome a religious ascetic, or remain abroad for twenty years, that debt shall be discharged by his sons or grandsons;
But not by remoter descendants against their will.

column1: saputrasya vāpy aputrasya vā rikthagrāhī ṛṇaṃ dadyāt //
column2: He who takes the assets of a man, leaving or not leaving male issue, must pay the sum due (by him);
And (so must) he who has the care of the widow left by one who had no assets.
A woman (shall) not (be compelled to pay) the debt of her husband or son;
Nor the husband or son (to pay) the debt of a woman (who is his wife or mother);
. Nor a father to pay the debt of his son.

column1: avibhaktaiḥ kṛtam ṛṇaṃ yas tiṣṭhet sa dadyāt //
column2: A debt contracted by parceners shall be paid by any one of them who is present.
And so shall the debt of the father (be paid) by (any one of) the brothers (or of their sons) before partition.
But after partition they shall severally pay according to their shares of the inheritance.
And (so must he pay that debt) which wascontracted by any person for the behoof of the family.

column1: yo gṛhītvā ṛṇaṃ sarvaṃ śvo dāsyāmīti sāmakam / na dadyāl lobhataḥ paścāt tathā vṛddhim avāpnuyāt //
column2: He who on receiving the whole amount of a loan, promises to repay the principal on the following day (or some other date near at hand), but from covetousness does not repay it, shall give interest for it.
Suretiship is ordained for appearance, for honesty, and for payment;

column1: ādyau tu vitathe dāpyāv itarasya sutā api //
column2: the first two (sureties, and not their sons), must pay the debt on failure of their engagements, but even the sons of the last (may be compelled to pay it).

column1: bahavaś cet pratibhuvo dadyus te 'rthaṃ yathākṛtam / arthe 'viśeṣite tv eṣu dhanikacchandataḥ kriyā //
column2: When there are several sureties (jointly bound), they shall pay their proportionate shares of the debt, but when they are bound severally, the payment shall be made (by any of them), as the creditor pleases.

column1: yam arthaṃ pratibhūr dadyād dhanikenopapīḍitaḥ / ṛṇikas taṃ pratibhuve dviguṇaṃ dātum arhati //
column2: If the surety, being harassed by the creditor, discharges the debt, the debtor shall pay twice as much to the surety.
Documents are of three kinds:
Attested by the king, or by (other) witnesses, or unattested.

A document is (said to be) attested by the king when it has been executed (in a court of judicature), on the king ordering it, by a scribe, hisservant, and has been signed by his chief judge, with his own hand.

column1: yatra kvacana yena kenacil likhitaṃ sākṣibhiḥ svahastacihnitaṃ sasākṣikam //
column2: It is (said to be) attested by, witnesses when, having been written anywhere, and by any one, it is signed by witnesses in their own hands.
It is (said to be) unattested when it has been written (by the party himself) with his own hand.
Such a document, if it has been caused to be written by force, makes no evidence.
Neither does any fraudulent document (make evidence);
Nor a document (which), though attested, (is vitiated) by the signature of a witness bribed (by one party) or of bad character;
Nor one written by a scribe of the same description;
Nor one executed by a woman, or a child, or a dependant person, or one intoxicated or insane, or one in danger or in bodily fear.

(That instrument is termed) proof which is not adverse to peculiar local usages, which defines clearly the nature of the pledge given, and is free from confusion in the arrangement of the subject matter and (in the succession of) the syllables.

column1: varṇaiś ca tatkṛtaiś cihnaiḥ patrair eva ca yuktibhiḥ / saṃdigdhaṃ sādhayel lekhyaṃ tadyuktipratirūpitaiḥ //
column2: If the authenticity of a document is contested, it should be ascertained by (comparing with it other)letters or signs (such as the flourish denoting the word Srî and the like) or documents executed by the same man, by (enquiring into) the probabilities of the case, and by (finding out such writings as show) a mode of writing similar (to that contained in the disputed document).

column1: yatra+ṛṇī dhaniko vāpi sākṣī vā lekhako 'pi vā / mriyate tatra tallekhyaṃ tatsvahastaiḥ prasādhayet //
column2: Should the debtor, or creditor, or witness, or scribe be dead, the authenticity of the document has to be ascertained by (comparing with it other.) specimens of their handwriting.
Now follow (the laws regarding) witnesses.
nor a person not his own master;
nor one oppressed by a (sudden) calamity (such as the death of his father or the like), or wholly absorbed in evil passions; Nor an enemy or a friend;

column1: anirdiṣṭas tu sākṣitve yaś copetya brūyāt //
column2: Nor one who, without having been appointed, comes and offers his evidence;
Nor can one man alone be made a witness.
In cases of theft, of violence, of abuse and assault, and of adultery the competence of witnesses must not be examined too strictly.
Now (those who are fit to be) witnesses (shall he enumerated):

column1: kulajā vṛttavittasaṃpannā yajvānas tapasvinaḥ putriṇo dharmajñā adhīyānāḥ satyavantas traividyavṛddhāś ca //
column2: Descendants of a noble race, who are virtuous and wealthy, sacrificers, zealous in the practice of religious austerities, having male issue, well versed in the holy law, studious, veracious, acquainted with the three Vedas, and aged (shall be witnesses).
If he is endowed with the qualities just mentioned, one man alone can also be made a witness.

column1: dvayor vivadamānayor yasya pūrvavādas tasya sākṣiṇaḥ praṣṭavyāḥ //
column2: In a dispute between two litigants, the witnesses of that party have to be examined from which the plaint has proceeded.

column1: ādharyaṃ kāryavaśād yatra pūrvapakṣasya bhavet tatra prativādino 'pi //
column2: Where the claim has been refuted as not agreeing with the facts (as e. g. the sum claimedhaving been repaid by the debtor), there the witnesses of the defendant have to be examined as well.

column1: uddiṣṭasākṣiṇi mṛte deśāntaragate ca tadabhihitaśrotāraḥ pramāṇam //
column2: An appointed witness having died or gone abroad, those who have heard his deposition may give evidence.
(The evidence of) witnesses is (of two kinds): either of what was seen, or of what was heard.
Witnesses are free from blame if they give true evidence.
Whenever the death of a member of any of the four castes (would be occasioned by true evidence, they are free from blame) if they give false evidence.
In order to expiate the sin thus committed, such a witness), if he belongs to a twice-born caste, must pour an oblation in the fire, consecrating it with the texts called Kûshmândî.

column1: śūdra ekāhikam godaśakasya grāsaṃ dadyāt // svabhāvavikṛtau mukhavarṇavināśe 'saṃbaddhapralāpe ca kūṭasākṣiṇaṃ vidyāt //
column2: If he is a Sûdra, he must feed ten cows for one day.IS. A false witness may be known by his altered looks, by his countenance changing colour, and by his talk wandering from the subject.
Let the judge summon the witnesses, at the time of sunrise, and examine them after having bound them by an oath.
A Brâhmana he must address thus, 'Declare.'
A Kshatriya he must address thus, 'Declare the truth.'
A Vaisya he must address thus, 'Thy kine, grain, and gold (shall yield thee no fruit, if thou wert to give false evidence).'
A Sûdra he must address thus, 'Thou shalt have to atone for all (possible) heavy crimes (if thou wert to give false evidence).'
Let him exhort the witnesses (with the following speeches):

column1: ye mahāpātakināṃ lokā ye copapātakināṃ te kūṭasākṣiṇām api //
column2: 'Whatever places (of torture) await (the killer of a Brâhmana and other) great criminals and (the killer of a cow and other) minor offenders, those places of abode are ordained for a witness who gives false evidence;
'Truth makes the sun spread his rays.
'Truth makes the moon shine.
'Truth makes the wind blow.
'Truth makes the earth bear (all that is upon it).
'Truth makes waters flow.
'Truth makes the fire burn.
'The atmosphere exists through truth.
'So do the gods.
'And so do the offerings.

column1: aśvamedhasahasraṃ ca satyaṃ ca tulayā dhṛtam / aśvamedhasahasrād dhi satyam eva viśiṣyate //
column2: 'If veracity and a thousand horse-sacrificesare weighed against each other, (it is found that) truth ranks even higher than a thousand horse-sacrifices.

column1: jānanto 'pi hi ye sākṣye tūṣṇīṃbhūtā udāsate / te kūṭasākṣiṇāṃ pāpais tulyā daṇḍena cāpy atha // evaṃ hi sākṣiṇaḥ pṛcched varṇānukramato nṛpaḥ //
column2: 'Those who, though acquainted with the facts, and appointed to give evidence, stand mute, are equally criminal with, and deserve the same punishment as, false witnesses.' (After having addressed them) thus, let. the king examine the witnesses in the order of their castes.

column1: yasyocuḥ sākṣiṇaḥ satyāṃ pratijñāṃ sa jayī bhavet /
column2: That plaintiff whose statement the witnesses declare to be true, shall win his suit;

column1: anyathā vādino yasya dhruvas tasya parājayaḥ //
column2: but he whose statement they declare to be wrong, shall certainly lose it.
If there is contradictory evidence, let the king decide by the plurality of witnesses;
if equality in number, by superiority in virtue; if parity in virtue, by the evidence of the best among the twice-born.

column1: yasmin yasmin vivāde tu kūṭasākṣy anṛtaṃ vadet /
column2: Whenever a perjured witness has given false evidence in a suit, (the king) must reverse the judgment;

column1: tattatkāryaṃ nivarteta kṛtaṃ cāpy akṛtaṃ bhavet //
column2: and whatever has been done, must be considered as undone.
Now follows (the rule regarding) the performance of ordeals.
In cases of a criminal action directed against the king, or of violence (they may be administered) indiscriminately.
In cases of (denial of) a deposit or of (alleged.)theft or robbery they must be administered each according to the value (of the property claimed).
In all such cases the value (of the object claimed) must be estimated in gold.
Now if its value amounts to less than one Krishnala, a Sûdra must be made to swear by a blade of Dûrvâ grass, (which he must hold in his hand);
If it amounts to less than two Krishnala, by a blade of Tila;
If it amounts to less than three Krishnala, by a blade of silver;
If it amounts to less than four Krishnala, by a blade of gold;
If it amounts to less than five Krishnala, by a lump of earth taken from a furrow;

column1: suvarṇārdhone kośo deyaḥ śūdrasya // tataḥ paraṃ yathārhaṃ dhaṭāgnyudakaviṣāṇām anyatamam //
column2: If it amounts to less than half a Suvarna, a Sûdra must be made to undergo the ordeal by sacred libation;
If the amount (of the matter in contest) is twice as high (as in each of the last-mentioned cases), a Vaisya must (in each case) undergo that ordeal which has (just) been ordained (for a Sûdra);
A Kshatriya (must undergo the same ordeals), if the amount is thrice as high;
A Brâhmana, if it is four times as high. He is, however, not subject to the ordeal by sacred libation.
No judge must administer the (ordeal by) sacred libation to a Brâhmana;
Except if it be done as a preliminary proof of his dealing fairly in some future transaction.

Instead of (administering the ordeal by) sacred libation to a Brâhmana (in suits regarding an object, the value of which amounts to less than two Suvarnas), let the judge cause him to swear by a lump of earth taken from a furrow.

column1: prāgdṛṣṭadoṣe svalpe 'py arthe divyānām anyatamam eva kārayet //
column2: To one formerly convicted of a crime (or of perjury) he must administer one of the ordeals, even though the matter in contest be ever so trifling.

column1: satsu viditaṃ sac caritaṃ na mahaty arthe 'pi //
column2: But to one who is known (and esteemed) among honest men and virtuous, he must not (administer any ordeal), even though the matter in contest be ever so important.
The claimant must declare his willingness to pay the fine (which is, due in case of his being defeated);
And the defendant must go through the ordeal.

In cases of a criminal action directed against the, king, or of violence (an ordeal may be administered) even without (the claimant) promising to pay the fine (due in case of defeat in ordinary suits).
To women, Brâhmanas, persons deficient in an organ of sense, infirm (old) men, and sick persons, the (ordeal by the) balance must be administered.
But it must not be administered to them while a wind is blowing.
The (ordeal by) fire must not be administered to lepers, to infirm persons, or to blacksmiths;
Nor must it ever be administered in autumn or summer.
The (ordeal by) poison must not be administered to lepers, bilious persons, or Brâhmanas;
Nor during the rainy season.

column1: na śleṣmavyādhyarditānāṃ bhīrūṇāṃ śvāsakāsinām ambujīvināṃ codakam //
column2: The (ordeal by) water must not be administered to persons afflicted with phlegm or (another) illness, to the timid, to the asthmatic, nor to those who gain their subsistence from water (such as fishermen and the like);
Nor during (the two cold seasons) Hemanta and Sisira (or from middle of November to middle of March);
The (ordeal by) sacred libation must not be administered to atheists;
Nor when the country is afflicted with disease or pestilence.

column1: sacailasnātam āhūya sūryodaya upoṣitam / kārayet sarvadivyāni devabrāhmaṇasaṃnidhau //
column2: Let the judge summon the defendant at the time of sunrise, after having, fasted on the previous day and bathed in his clothes, and make him go through all the ordeals in the presence of (images of) the gods and of the (assessors and other) Brâhmanas.
Now follows the (rule regarding the ordeal by) balance.
The transverse beam, by which the balance is to be suspended, should be fastened upon two posts, four Hastas above the ground (each), and should be made two Hastas long.

The beam of the balance should be made of strong wood (such as that of the Khadira or Tinduka trees), five Hastas long, and the two scales must be suspended on both sides of it, (and the whole suspended upon the transverse beam by means of an iron hook).
A man out of the guild of goldsmiths, or of braziers, should make it equal on both sides.

column1: pratimānapuruṣau samadhṛtau sucihnitau kṛtvā puruṣam avatārayet //
column2: The equivalent and the man having been made equal in weight and (the position of the scales) well marked, the man should be caused to descend from the balance.
Next (the judge) should adjure by (the following) imprecations the balance
And the person appointed to look after the weighing:

column1: brahmaghnāṃ ye smṛtā lokā ye lokāḥ kūṭasākṣiṇām /
column2: Those places of torture which have been prepared for the murderer of a Brâhmana, or for a false witness, the same places are ordained for a who person appointed to look after the weighing, who acts fraudulently in his office.
'Thou, O balance (dhata), art called by the same name as holy law (dharma);

column1: tvam eva dhaṭa jānīṣe na vidur yāni mānuṣāḥ //
column2: thou, O balance, knowest what mortal., do not comprehend.

column1: vyavahārābhiśasto 'yaṃ mānuṣas tolyate tvayi / tad enaṃ saṃśayād asmād dharmatas trātum arhasi //
column2: 'This man, being arraigned in a cause, is weighed upon thee. Therefore mayest thou deliver him lawfully from this perplexity.'

column1: tatas tv āropayec chikye bhūya evātha taṃ naram / tulito yadi vardheta tataḥ śuddhaḥ sa dharmataḥ //
column2: Thereupon the judge should have him placed, into the one scale again. If he rises in it, he is freed from the charge according to law.

In case of the strings bursting, or of the splitting of the transverse beam, the man should be placed in the scale once more. Thus the facts will be ascertained positively, and a just sentence be the result.
Now follows the (rule regarding the ordeal by) fire.
He must make seven circles, sixteen Angulas in breadth each, the intervals being of the same breadth.

column1: tataḥ prāṅmukhasya prasāritabhujadvayasya saptāśvatthapatrāṇi karayor dadyāt //
column2: Thereupon he must place seven leaves of theholy fig-tree into the hands of the person (about to perform the ordeal), who must turn his face towards the east and stretch out both arms.
Those (leaves) and his hands he must bind together with a thread.

column1: tatas tatrāgnivarṇaṃ lohapiṇḍaṃ pañcāśatpalikaṃ samaṃ nyaset //
column2: Then he must place into his hands a ball made of iron, red-hot, fifty Palas in weight, and smooth.

column1: tam ādāya nātidrutaṃ nātivilambitaṃ maṇḍaleṣu pādanyāsaṃ kurvan vrajet //
column2: Having received this, the person must proceed through the (seven) circles, without either walking at a very hurried pace, or lingering on his way.

column1: tataḥ saptamaṃ maṇḍalam atītya bhūmau lohapiṇḍaṃ jahyāt //
column2: Finally, after having passed the seventh circle, he must put down the ball upon the ground.

column1: yo hastayoḥ kvacid dagdhas tam aśuddhaṃ vinirdiṣet /
column2: That man whose hands are burnt ever so little, shall be deemed guilty;

column1: na dagdhaḥ sarvathā yas tu sa viśuddho bhaven naraḥ //
column2: but if he remains wholly unburnt, he is freed from the charge.

column1: bhayād vā pātayed yas tu dagdho vā na vibhāvyate / punas taṃ hārayel lohaṃ samayasyāviśodhanāt //
column2: If he lets the ball drop from fear, or if there exists a doubt as to whether he is burnt or not, let him take the ball once more, because the proof has not been decided.

column1: abhimantryāsya karayor lohapiṇḍaṃ tato nyaset // tvam agne sarvabhūtānām antaś carasi sākṣivat / tvam evāgne vijānīṣe na vidur yāni mānavāḥ //
column2: At the beginning (of the whole ceremony) the judge shall cause the person to rub some rice in his hands, and shall mark (with red sap, or the like, the already existing scars, eruptions of the skin, &c., which will thus have become visible). Then the judge, after having addressed the iron ball (with the following prayer), shall place it in his hands:'Thou, O fire, dwellest in the interior of all creatures, like a witness. O fire, thou knowest what mortals do not comprehend.

column1: vyavahārābhiśasto 'yaṃ mānuṣaḥ śuddhim icchati / tad enaṃ saṃśayād asmād dharmatas trātum arhasi //
column2: 'This man being arraigned in a cause, desires to be cleared from guilt. Therefore mayest thou deliver him lawfully from this perplexity.'
Now follows the (rule regarding the ordeal by) water.

(The defendant must enter) water which is free from mud, aquatic plants, (crabs and other) vicious animals, (porpoises or other) large rapacious animals living in water, fish, leeches, and other (animals or plants),

column1: tatra ...nābhimagnasyārogadveṣiṇaḥ puruṣasyānyasya jānunī gṛhītvābhimantritam ambhaḥ praviśet //
column2: The water having been addressed with the Mantras (mentioned hereafter), he must enter it, seizing the knees of another man, who must be free from friendship or hatred, and must dive into the water up to his navel.

column1: tatsamakālaṃ ca nātikrūramṛdunā dhanuṣā puruṣo 'paraḥ śarakṣepaṃ kuryāt //
column2: At the same time another man must discharge an arrow from a bow, which must neither be too strong nor too weak.

column1: taṃ cāparaḥ puruṣo javena śaram ānayet //
column2: That arrow must be fetched quickly by another man.

column1: anyathā hy aviśuddhaḥ syād ekāṅgasyāpi darśane //
column2: He who is not seen above the water in the mean time is proclaimed innocent. But in the contrary case he is (declared) guilty, even though one limb of his only has become visible.

column1: tvam ambhaḥ sarvabhūtānām antaś carasi sākṣivat / tvam evāmbho vijānīṣe na vidur yāni mānuṣāḥ //
column2: 'Thou, O water, dwellest in the interior of all creatures, like a witness. O water, thou knowest what mortals do not comprehend.

column1: vyavahārābhiśato 'yaṃ mānuṣas tvayi majjati / tad enaṃ saṃśayād asmād dharmatas trātum arhasi //
column2: 'This man being arraigned in a cause, desires to be cleared from guilt. Therefore mayest thou deliver him, lawfully from this perplexity.'
Now follows the (rule regarding the ordeal by) poison.
All (other) sorts of poison must be avoided (in administering this ordeal),
Except poison from the Sringa tree, which grows on the Himâlayas.

column1: tasya ca yavasaptakaṃ ghṛtaplutam abhiśastāya dadyāt //
column2: (Of that) the judge must give seven grains, mixed with clarified butter, to the defendant (while reciting the prayer hereafter mentioned).

column1: viṣaṃ vegaklamāpetaṃ sukhena yadi jīryate / viśuddhaṃ tam iti jñātvā divasānte visarjayet //
column2: If the poison is digested easily, without violent symptoms, he shall recognise him as innocent, and dismiss him at the end of the day.

column1: viṣatvād viṣamatvāc ca krūraṃ tvaṃ sarvadehinām /
column2: 'On account of thy venomous and dangerous nature thou art destruction to all living creatures;

column1: tvam eva viṣa jānīṣe na vidur yāni mānuṣāḥ //
column2: thou, O poison, knowest what mortals, do not comprehend.

column1: vyavahārābhiśasto 'yaṃ mānuṣaḥ śuddhim icchati / tad enaṃ saṃśayād asmād dharmatas trātum arhasi //
column2: 'This man being arraigned in a cause, desires to be cleared from guilt. Therefore mayest thou deliver him lawfully from this perplexity.'

column1: ugrān devān samabhyarcya tatsnānodakāt prasṛtitrayaṃ pibet //

Now there are twelve kinds of sons.

column1: svakṣetre saṃskṛtāyām utpāditaḥ svayam aurasaḥ prathamaḥ //
column2: The first is the son of the body, viz. he who is begotten (by the husband) himself on his own lawfully wedded wife.
The second is the soil begotten on a wife, viz. one begotten by a kinsman allied by funeral oblations, or by a member of the highest caste, on an appointed (wife or widow).
The third is the son of an appointed daughter.

column1: yas tv asyāḥ putraḥ sa me putro bhaved iti yā pitrā dattā sā putrikā //
column2: She is called an appointed daughter, who is given away by her father with the words, 'The son whom she bears be mine.'
A damsel who has no brother is also (in every case considered) an appointed daughter, though she has not been given away according to the rule of an appointed daughter.
The son of a twice-married woman is the fourth.
She who, being still a virgin, is married for the second time is called twice married (punarbhû).
She also is called twice married (punarbhû) who, though not legally married more than once, has lived with another man before her lawful marriage.
The son of an unmarried damsel is the fifth.
(He is called so who is) born by an unmarried daughter in the house of her father.
And he belongs to the man who (afterwards) marries the mother.
The son who is secretly born in the house is the sixth.
He belongs to him in whose bed he is born.
The son received with a bride is the seventh.
He (is called so who) is the son of a woman married while she was pregnant.
And he belongs to the husband (of the pregnant bride).
The adopted son (dattaka) is the eighth.
And he belongs to him to whom he is given by his mother or father.
The son bought is the ninth.
And he belongs to him by whom he is bought.
The son self-given is the tenth.
And he belongs to him to whom he gave himself
The son cast away is the eleventh.
(He is called so) who was forsaken by his father or mother (or by both).
And he belongs to him by whom he is received.
The son born by any woman whomsoever is the twelfth.
Amongst these (sons) each preceding one is preferable (to the one next in order).
And he takes the inheritance (before the next in order).
And let him maintain the rest.
He should marry unmarried (sisters) in a manner correspondent with the amount of his property.
Outcasts, eunuchs, persons incurably diseased, or deficient (in organs of sense or actions, such as blind, deaf, dumb, or insane persons, or lepers) do not receive a share.
They, should be maintained by those who take the inheritance.

column1: teṣāṃ caurasāḥ putrā bhāgahāriṇaḥ // na tu patitasya //
column2: And their legitimate sons receive a share. But not the children of an outcast;

And he who inherits the wealth, presents the funeral oblation (to the deceased).

column1: ekoḍhānām apy ekasyāḥ putraḥ sarvāsāṃ putra eva //
column2: Amongst wives of one husband also the son of one is the son of all (and must present funeral oblations to them after their death).

Let a son present the funeral oblations to his father, even though he inherit no property.

column1: punnāmno narakād yasmāt pitaraṃ trāyate sutaḥ / tasmāt puttra iti proktaḥ svayam eva svayaṃbhuvā //

column2: and the father obtains immortality, if he sees the face of a loving son.

column2: Through a son he conquers the worlds. through a grandson he obtains immortality, and through the soil's grandson he gains the world of the sun.

column2: for even a daughter's son works the salvation of a childless man, just like a son's son.
On women equal in caste (to their husbands) sons are begotten, who are equal in caste (to their fathers).
On women of lower caste than their husbands sons are begotten, who follow the caste of their mothers.
Among these, the son of a Sûdra with a Vaisya woman is called Âyogava.
The Pukkasa and Mâgadha are sons of a Vaisya and Sûdra respectively with a Kshatriya woman.
The Kandâla, Vaidehaka, and Sûta are the sons of a Sûdra, Vaisya, and Kshatriya respectively with a Brâhmana woman.
Besides these, there are innumerable other mixed castes produced by further intermixture between those that have been mentioned.
Âyogavas must live by artistic performances (such as public wrestling, dancing, and the like).
Pukkasas must live by hunting.
Mâgadhas must live by calling out in public the good qualities (of saleable commodities).
Kandâlas must live by executing criminals sentenced to death.
Vaidehakas must live by keeping (dancing girls and other public) women and profiting by what they earn.
Sûtas must live by managing horses.

column1: caṇḍālānāṃ bahir grāmanivasanaṃ mṛtacailadhāraṇam iti viśeṣaḥ //
column2: Kandâlas must live out of the town, and their clothes must be the mantles of the deceased. In this their condition is different (from, and lower than that of the other mixed castes).
