(In the lower castes also) the son inherits the property of his father.

column1: pracchannā vā prakāśā vā veditavyāḥ svakarmabhiḥ //

column1: pitā cet putrān vibhajet tasya svecchā svayam upārjite 'rthe //

column1: paitāmahe tv arthe pitṛputrayos tulyaṃ svāmitvam //
column2: But in regard to wealth 'inherited of the paternal grandfather, the ownership of father and son is equal.

On failure of her, to his daughter;
On failure of her, to his father;
On failure of him, to his mother;

On failure of him, to his brother's son;

column1: saṃsṛṣṭinas tu saṃsṛṣṭī sodarasya tu sodaraḥ / dadyād apaharec cāṃśaṃ jātasya ca mṛtasya ca //

column1: yasya yat paitṛkaṃ rikthaṃ sa tad gṛhṇīta netaraḥ // brāhmaṇasya caturṣu varṇeṣu cet putrā bhaveyuḥ, te paitṛkaṃ rikthaṃ daśadhā vibhajeyuḥ //

column1: dvijātīnāṃ śūdras tv ekaḥ putro 'rdhaharaḥ // aputrarikthasya yā gatiḥ,
column2: A Sûdra, who is the only son of a father belonging to a twice-born caste, shall inherit one-half of his property;
Mothers shall receive shares proportionate to their son's shares;

A best part (the twentieth part of the inheritance, &c.) shall be given to the eldest, as his additional share.

column1: yadi dvau brāhmaṇīputrau syātām ekaḥ śūdrāputraḥ, tadā navadhā vibhaktasyārthasya brāhmaṇīputrāv aṣṭau bhāgān ādadyātām ekaṃ śūdrāputraḥ //

and of these, the son of the Brâhmana wife shall take four parts, and the two sons of the Sûdra wife together shall take two parts.

column2: If (brothers), who after a previous division of the estate live again together as parceners, should make a second partition, the shares must be equal in that case, and the eldest has no right to an additional share.

column2: Apparel, vehicles (carriages or riding-horses), and ornaments (such as are usually worn according to the custom of the caste), prepared food, water (in a well or pool), females (slaves or mistresses of the deceased), property destined for pious uses or sacrifices, a common pasture-ground, and a book, are indivisible.
He must not cause a member of a twice-born caste to be carried out by a Sûdra (even though he be a kinsman of the deceased);

And they must sleep apart.

column1: grāmān niṣkramyāśaucānte kṛtaśmaśrukarmāṇas tilakalkaiḥ sarṣapakalkair vā snātāḥ parivartitavāsaso gṛhaṃ praviśeyuḥ //

column1: brāhmaṇābhihitaṃ vākyaṃ na mithyā jāyate kvacit //

column1: yad brāhmaṇās tuṣṭatamā vadanti tad devatāḥ pratyabhinandayanti /

column1: duḥkhānvitānāṃ mṛtabāndhavānām āśvāsanaṃ kuryur adīnasattvāḥ / vākyais tu yair bhūmi tavābhidhāsye vākyāny ahaṃ tāni mano 'bhirāme //
column2: The mourners, who lament the loss of a relative, shall be addressed by men gifted with a tranquil frame of mind with such consolatory speeches as I shall now recite to thee, O Earth, who art cherished to my, mind.
The northern progress of the sun is a day, with the gods.
The southern progress of the sun is (with them) a night.
A year is (with them) a day and a night;
Thirty such are a month;
Twelve such months are a year.
Twelve hundred years of the gods are a Kaliyuga.
Twice as many (or two thousand four hundred) are a Dvâpara (Yuga).S. Thrice as many (or three thousand six hundred) are a Tretâ (Yuga).
Four times as many (or four thousand eight hundred) are a Krita Yuga.
(Thus) twelve thousand years make a Katuryuga (or period of four Yugas).
Seventy-one Katuryugas make a Manvantara (or period of a Manu).
A thousand Katuryugas make a Kalpa.
And that is a day of the forefather (Brahman).
His night also has an equal duration.

column1: evaṃvidhenāhorātreṇa māsavarṣagaṇanayā sarvasyaiva brahmaṇo varṣaśatam āyuḥ //

When it ends, a Mahâkalpa is over.
The night following upon it is as long.
The days and nights of Purusha that have gone by are innumerable;
And so are those that will follow.
For Kâla (time) is without either beginning or end.

column1: evam asmin nirālambe kāle satatayāyini / na tadbhūtaṃ prapaśyāmi sthitir yasya bhaved dhruvā //

column1: gaṅgāyāḥ sikatā dhārās tathā varṣati vāsave /

column1: caturdaśa vinaśyanti kalpe kalpe sureśvarāḥ / sarvalokapradhānāś ca manavaś ca caturdaśa //

column1: te 'pi kālena nīyante kālo hi duratikramaḥ //
column2: for Kâla (time) is hard to overcome.

column1: ākramya sarvaḥ kālena paralokaṃ ca nīyate / karmapāśavaśo jantus tatra kā paridevanā //
column2: Every creature is seized upon by Kâla and carried into the other world. It is the slave of its actions (in a former existence). Wherefore then should you wail (on its death)?

column1: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyur dhruvaṃ janma mṛtasya ca / arthe duṣparihārye 'smin nāsti loke sahāyatā //
column2: Those who are born are sure to die, and those who have died are sure to be born again. This is inevitable, and no associate can follow a man (in his passage through mundane existence).

column1: śocanto nopakurvanti mṛtasyeha janā yataḥ / ato na roditavyaṃ hi kriyā kāryā svaśaktitaḥ //
column2: As mourners will not help the dead in this world, therefore (the relatives) should not weep, but perform the obsequies to the best of their power.

column1: sukṛtaṃ duṣkṛtaṃ cobhau sahāyau yasya gacchataḥ / bāndhavais tasya kiṃ kāryaṃ śocadbhir atha vā na vā //
column2: As both his good and bad actions will followhim (after death) like associates. what does it matter to a man whether his relatives mourn over him or no?

column1: arvāk sapiṇdīkaraṇāt preto bhavati yo mṛtaḥ /
column2: Till the Sapindîkarana has been performed, the dead man remains a disembodied spirit (and is afflicted with hunger and thirst). Give rice and a jar with water to the man who has passed into the abode of disembodied spirits.
Having passed into the abode of the manes (after the performance of the Sapindîkarana) he enjoys in the shape of celestial food his portion of the Srâddha (funeral oblation);
offer the Srâddha, therefore, to him who has passed into the abode of the manes.

column1: mānuṣye ca tathāpnoti śrāddhaṃ dattaṃ svabāndhavaiḥ //
column2: Whether he has become a god, or stays in hell, or has entered the body of an animal, or of a human being, he will receive the Srâddha offered to him by his relatives.

column1: pretasya śrāddhakartuś ca puṣṭiḥ śrāddhe kṛte dhruvam / tasmāc chrāddhaṃ sadā kāryaṃ śokaṃ tyaktvā nirarthakam //
column2: The dead person and the performer of the Srâddha are sure to be benefitted by its performance. Perform the Srâddha always, therefore, abandoning bootless grief.

column1: etāvad eva kartavyaṃ sadā pretasya bandhubhiḥ /
column2: This is the duty which should be constantly discharged towards a dead person by his kinsmen;

column1: nopakuryān naraḥ śocan pretasyātmana eva ca //
column2: by mourning a man will neither benefit the dead nor himself.

column1: dṛṣṭvā lokam anākrandaṃ mriyamāṇāṃś ca bāndhavān / dharmam ekaṃ sahāyārthaṃ varayadhvaṃ sadā narāḥ //
column2: Having seen that no help is to be had from this world, and that his relations are dying (one afterthe other), you must choose virtue for your only associate, O ye men.

column1: mṛto 'pi bāndhavaḥ śakto nānugantuṃ naraṃ mṛtam / jāyāvarjaṃ hi sarvasya yāmyaḥ panthā virudhyate //
column2: Even were he to die with him, a kinsman is unable to follow his dead relative: all excepting his wife are forbidden to follow him on the path of Yama.

column1: dharma eko 'nuyāty enaṃ yatra kvacana gāminam /
column2: Virtue alone will follow him, wherever he, may go;

column1: nanv asāre nṛloke 'smin dharmaṃ kuruta mā ciram //
column2: therefore do your duty unflinchingly in this wretched world.

column1: śvaḥ kāryam adya kurvīta pūrvāhṇe cāparāhṇikam /
column2: To-morrow's business should be done to-day, and the, afternoons business in the forenoon;

column1: na hi pratīkṣate mṛtyuḥ kṛtaṃ vāsya na vākṛtam //
column2: for death will not wait, whether a person has done it or not.

column1: kṣetrāpaṇagṛhāsaktam anyatra gatamānasam / vṛkīvoraṇam āsādya mṛtyur ādāya gacchati //
column2: While his mind is fixed upon his field, or traffic, or his house, or while his thoughts are engrossed by some other (beloved) object, death suddenly carries him away as his, prey, as a she-wolf catches a lamb.

column1: na kālasya priyaḥ kaścid dveṣyaś cāsya na vidyate / āyuṣye karmaṇi kṣīṇe prasahya harate janam //
column2: Kâla (time) is no one's friend and no one's enemy: when the effect of his acts in a former existence, by which his present existence is caused, has expired, he snatches a man away forcibly.
He will not die before his time has come, even though he has been pierced by a thousand shafts;
he will not live after his time is out, even though he has only been touched by the point of a blade of Kusa grass.

column1: nauśadhāni na mantrāś ca na homā na punar japāḥ / trāyante mṛtyunopetaṃ jarayā vāpi mānavam //
column2: Neither drugs, nor magical formulas, norburnt-offerings, nor prayers will save a man who is in the bonds of death or old age.
An impending evil cannot be averted even by a hundred precautions;

column1: na nivārayituṃ śaktas tatra kā paridevanā //
column2: what reason then for you to complain?

column1: yathā dhenusahasreṣu vatso vindati mātaram / tathā pūrvakṛtaṃ karma kartāraṃ vindate dhruvam //
column2: Even as a calf finds his mother among a thousand cows, an act formerly done is sure to find the perpetrator.
Of existing beings the beginning is unknown, the middle (of their career) is known, and the end again unknown;

column1: dehino 'smin yathā dehe kaumāraṃ yauvanaṃ jarā /
column2: what reason then for you to complain? As the body of mortals undergoes (successively the vicissitudes of) infancy, youth, and old age, even so will it be transformed into another body (hereafter);

column1: tahtā dehāntaraprāptir dhīras tatra na muhyati //
column2: a sensible man is not mistaken about that.

column1: gṛhṇātīha yathā vastraṃ tyaktvā pūrvadhṛtaṃ naraḥ / gṛhṇāty evaṃ navaṃ dehī dehaṃ karmanibandhanam //
column2: As a man puts on new clothes in this world, throwing aside those which he formerly wore, even so the self of man puts on new bodies, which are in accordance with his acts (in a former life).

column1: nainaṃ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṃ dahati pāvakaḥ / na cainaṃ kledayanty āpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ //
column2: No weapons will hurt the self of man, no fire burn it, no waters moisten it, and no wind dry it up.
It is not to be hurt, not to be burnt, not to be moistened, and not to be dried up;

column1: nityaḥ satatagaḥ sthāṇur acalo 'yaṃ sanātanaḥ // avyakto 'yam acintyo 'yam avikāryo 'yam ucyate /
column2: it is imperishable, perpetual, unchanging, immovable, without beginning.
It is (further) said to be immaterial, passing all thought, and immutable. Knowing the self of man to be such, you must not grieve (for the destruction of his body).

column1: athāśaucavyapagame susnātaḥ suprakṣālitapāṇipādaḥ svācāntas tv evaṃvidhān eva brāhmaṇān yathāśakti udaṅmukhān gandhamālyavastrālaṃkārādibhiḥ  # pūjitān bhojayet //
column2: Now then , (on the day) after the impurity is over, let him bathe duly (during the recitation of Mantras), wash his hands and feet duly, and sip water duly, (and having invited some Brâhmanas), as many as possible, who must cleanse themselves in the same way and turn their faces towards the north, let him bestow presents of perfumes, garlands, clothes and other things (a lamp, frankincense, and the like) upon them, and hospitably entertain them.

column1: ekavanmantrān ūhed ekoddiṣṭe // ucchiṣṭasaṃnidhāv ekam eva tannāmagotrābhyāṃ piṇḍaṃ nirvapet //
column2: At the Ekoddishta (or Srâddha for one recently deceased) let him alter the Mantras so as to refer to (the) one person (deceased).

column1: bhuktavatsu brāhmaṇeṣu dakṣiṇayābhipūjiteṣu pretanāmagotrābhyāṃ dattākṣayyodakaḥ caturaṅgulapṛthvīḥ tāvadantarāḥ tāvadadhaḥkhātāḥ vitastyāyatāḥ  #
column2: The Brâhmanas having taken food and having been honoured with a gift, let him offer, as imperishable food, water to the Brâhmanas, after having called out the name and Gotra of the deceased;

and let him dig three trenches, each four Angulas in breadth, their distance from one another and their depth also measuring (four Angulas), and their length amounting to one Vitasti (or twelve Angulas).

column1: karṣūsamīpe cāgnitrayam upasamādhāya paristīrya tatraikaikasmin āhutitrayaṃ juhuyāt //
column2: Close by the trenches let him light three fires, and having added fuel to them, let him make three oblations (of boiled rice) in each (fire, saying),
'Svadhâ and reverence to Soma, accompanied by the manes.
'Svadhâ and reverence to Agni, who conveys the oblations addressed to the manes.
'Svadhâ and reverence to Yama Angiras.'
Then let him offer balls of rice as (ordained) before  on the three mounds of earth (adjacent to the three trenches).

column1: annadadhighṛtamadhumāṃsaiḥ karṣūtrayaṃ pūrayitvā etat ta iti japet //
column2: After having filled the three trenches with {p. }rice, sour milk, clarified butter, honey, and meat, let him mutter (the Mantra), 'This is for you.'
This ceremony he must repeat monthly, on the day of his death.

column1: saṃvatsarānte pretāya tatpitre tatpitāmahāya tatprapitāmahāya ca brāhmaṇān devapūrvān bhojayet //
column2: At the close of the year let him give food to the Brâhmanas, after having fed the gods first, in honour of the deceased and of his father, grandfather, and great-grandfather.
At (the Ekoddishta belonging to) this ceremony let him perform the burnt-offering, the invitation, and (the offering of) water for washing the feet.

column1: saṃsṛjatu tvā pṛthivī samānī ca iti ca pretapādyapātre pitṛpādyapātratraye yojayet //
column2: Then he must pour the water for washing the feet and the Arghya (water libation) destined for the deceased person into the three vessels containing the water for washing the feet, and the three other vessels containing the Arghya of his three ancestors. At the same time he must mutter(the two Mantras), 'May earth unite thee ,' and 'United your minds.'
Near the leavings he must make (and put) four balls of rice.

column1: brāhmaṇāṃś ca svācāntān dattadakṣiṇāṃś cānuvrajya visarjayet //
column2: Let him show out the Brâhmanas, after they have sipped water duly and have been presented by him with their sacrificial fee.
Then let him knead together the ball of the deceased person with the three balls (of the three ancestors), as (he has mixed up) his water for washing the feet and his Arghya (with theirs).
Let him do the same (with the balls placed) near the three trenches.

column1: sapiṇḍīkaraṇaṃ māsikārthavat dvādaśāhaṃ śrāddhaṃ kṛtvā trayodaśe 'hni vā kuryāt //
column2: Or  the Sapindîkarana must be performed on the thirteenth, after the monthly Srâddha has been performed on the twelfth day.
For Sûdras it should be performed on the twelfth day, without Mantras.

column1: saṃvatsarābhyantare yady adhimāso bhavet, tadā māsikārthe dinam ekaṃ vardhayet //
column2: If there be an intercalary month in that year, he must add one day to the (regular days of the) monthly Srâddha.

column1: sapiṇḍīkaraṇaṃ strīṇāṃ kāryam evaṃ tathā bhavet / yāvaj jīvaṃ tathā kuryāc chrāddhaṃ tu prativatsaram //
column2: The ceremony of investing women with the relationship of Sapinda has to be performed in the same manner. Later, he must perform a Srâddha every year, while he lives, (on the anniversary of the deceased relative's death).

column1: arvāk sapiṇḍīkaraṇaṃ yasya saṃvatsarāt kṛtaṃ / tasyāpy annaṃ sodakumbhaṃ dadyād varṣaṃ dvijanmane //
column2: He, for whom the ceremony of investing him with the, relationship of Sâpinda is performed after the lapse of a year, shall be honoured by the gift, (on each day) of that year, of food and a jar with water to a Brâhmana.
The impurity of a Brâhmana caused by the birth or death of Sapindas lasts ten days.
In the case of a Kshatriya (it lasts) twelve days.
In the case of a Vaisya (it lasts) fifteen days.
In the case of a Sûdra (it lasts) a month.
The relationship of Sapinda ceases with the seventh man (in descent or ascent).
During the period of impurity oblations (to the Visvedevâs), gifts and receiving of alms, and study have to be interrupted.
No one must eat the food of one impure (unless he be a Sapinda of his).

column1: brāhmaṇādīnām aśauce yaḥ sakṛd evānnam atti tasya tāvad āśaucaṃ yāvat teṣām //
column2: He who eats but once the food of Brâhmanas or others, while they are impure, will remain impure as long as they.
When the (period of) impurity is over, he must perform a penance (as follows):

column1: savarṇasyāśauce dvijo bhuktvā sravantīm āsādya tannimagnas triraghamarṣaṇaṃ japtvottīrya gāyatryaṣṭasahasraṃ japet //
column2: If a twice-born man has eaten (the food) of a member of his own caste, while the latter was impure, he must approach a river and plunge into it, mutter the (hymn of) Aghamarshana three times, and, after having emerged from the water, must mutter the Gâyatrî one thousand and eight times.

column1: kṣatriyāśauce brāhmaṇas tv etad evopoṣitaḥ kṛtvā śudhyati //
column2: If a Brâhmana has eaten the food of a Kshatriya, while the latter was impure, he is purified by performing the same penance and by fasting (on the previous day).
(The same penance is ordained for) a Kshatriya who has eaten the food of a Vaisya, while the latter was impure.
(The same penance is ordained for) a Brâhmana (who has eaten the food) of an impure Vaisya; but he must fast besides during the three (previous) days.

column1: brāhmaṇāśauce rājanyaḥ kṣatriyāśauce vaiśyaś ca sravantīm āsādya gāyatrīśatapañcakaṃ japet //
column2: If a Kshatriya or a Vaisya (have eaten the food) of a Brâhmana or a Kshatriya respectively, who were impure, they must approach a river and mutter the Gâyatrî five hundred times.
A Vaisya, who has eaten the food of a Brâhmana, while the latter was impure, must (go to a river and) mutter the Gâyatrî one hundred and eight times.
A twice-born man (who has eaten the food), of a Sûdra, while the latter was impure must (go to a river and) perform the Prâgâpatya (penance).
A Sûdra (who has eaten the food) of an impure man of a twice-born caste must bathe (in a river).
A Sûdra (who has eaten the food) of another Sûdra, while the latter was impure, must bathe (in a river) and drink Pañkagavya.

column1: patnīnāṃ dāsānām ānulomyena svāminas tulyam āśaucam //
column2: Wives and slaves in the direct order of the castes (i. e. who do not belong to a higher caste than their lord) remain impure as long as their lord.
If their lord is dead (or if they live apart from him, they remain impure) as long as (members of) their own caste.
If Sapindas of a higher caste (are born or have died) the period of impurity has for their lower caste relations the same duration as for members of the higher caste.
A Brâhmana (to whom) Sapindas of the Kshatriya, Vaisya, or Sûdra castes (have been born or have died) becomes pure within six nights, or three nights, or one night, respectively.
A Kshatriya (to whom Sapindas of the) Vaisya or Sûdra castes (have been born or have died) is purified within six and three nights, respectively.
A Vaisya (to whom Sapindas of the) Sûdra caste (have been born or have died) becomes pure within six nights.
In a number of nights equal to the number of months after conception, a woman is purified from an abortion.

column1: jātamṛte mṛtajāte vā kulasya sadyaḥ śaucam //
column2: The relatives of children that have died immediately after birth (before the cutting of the navel-string), and of still-born children, are purified at once.
(The relatives) of a child that has died before having teethed (are also purified) at once.
For him no ceremony with fire is performed, nor offering of water.
. For a child that has teethed but has not yet been shorn, purity is obtained in one day and night;
For a child that has been shorn but not initiated, in three nights;
From that time forward (i. e. for initiated persons) in the time that has been mentioned above
In regard to women, the marriage ceremony is (considered as their) initiation.
For married women there is no impurity for the relatives on the father's side.

column1: tatprasavamaraṇe cet pitṛgṛhe syātāṃ , tadā ekarātraṃ trirātraṃ ca //
column2: If they happen to stay at their father's house during childbirth or if they die there, (their distant relatives are purified) in one night, and their parents (in three nights).

column1: jananāśaucamadhye yady aparaṃ jananāśaucaṃ syāt , tadā pūrvāśaucavyapagame śuddhiḥ //
column2: If, while the impurity, caused by a birth lasts,another impurity caused by childbirth intervenes, it ends when the former impurity terminates.
If it intervenes when one night (only of the period of impurity remains, the fresh impurity terminates) two days later.
If it intervenes when one watch (only of the last night remains, the impurity ends) three days later.
The same rule is observed if a relative dies during a period of impurity caused by the death (of another relative).
If a man, while staying in another country, hears of the birth or death (of a relative), he becomes purified after the lapse of the period still wanting (to the ten days).
if the period of impurity, but not a whole year, has elapsed, (he is purified in one night.)
After that time (he is purified) by a bath.
If his teacher or maternal grandfather has died, (he is purified) in three nights.

column1: anauraseṣu putreṣu jāteṣu ca mṛteṣu ca / parapūrvāsu bhāryāsu prasūtāsu mṛtāsu ca //
column2: Likewise, if sons other than a son of the body have been born or have died, and if wives who had another husband before have been delivered of a child or have died.

(He becomes pure) in one day, if the wife or son of his teacher, or his Upâdhyâya (sub-teacher), or his maternal uncle, or his father-in-law, or a brother-in-law, or a fellow-student, or a pupil has died.
Likewise, if a man not his Sapinda has died at his house.

The relatives of those who have been killed by (falling from) a precipice, or by fire, or (have killed themselves by) fasting, or (have been killed by) water, in battle, by lightning, or by the king (on account of a crime committed by them), do not become impure;

Nor do kings (become impure) while engaged in the discharge of their ditties (such as the protection of their subjects, the trial of lawsuits, &c.) Devotees fulfilling a vow (also do not become impure);
Nor do sacrificers engaged in a sacrificial ceremony;
Nor workmen (such as carpenters or others) while engaged in their work;
Nor those who perform the king's orders, if the king wishes them to be pure.
Nor (can impurity arise) during the installation of the monument of a deity, nor duringa marriage ceremony, if those ceremonies have actually begun;
Nor when the whole country is afflicted with a calamity;
Nor in times if great public distress (such as an epidemic or a famine).
Suicides and outcasts do not cause impurity or receive offerings of water.

column1: patitasya dāsī mṛte 'hni padā apāṃ ghaṭam apavarjayet //
column2: On the death-day of an outcast a female slave of his must upset a pot with water with her feet, (saying, 'Drink thou this.')

column1: udbandhanamṛtasya yaḥ pāśaṃ chindyāt sa taptakṛcchreṇa śudhyati //
column2: He who cuts the rope by which (a suicide) has hung himself, becomes pure by performing the Taptakrikkhra ('hot penance').
So does he who has been (in any way) concerned with the funeral of a suicide;
And he who sheds tears for such.

column1: sarvasyaiva pretasya bāndhavaiḥ sahāśrupātaṃ kṛtvā snānena //
column2: He who sheds tears for any deceased person together with the relations of the latter (becomes pure) by a bath.
If he has done so, before the bones (of the deceased) had been collected, (he becomes pure) by bathing with his apparel.

column1: dvijaḥ śūdrapretānugamanaṃ kṛtvā sravantīm āsādya tannimagnaḥ triraghamarṣaṇaṃ japtvottīrya gāyatryaṣṭasahasraṃ japet //
column2: If a member of a twice-born caste has followed the corpse of a dead Sûdra, he must go to a river, and having plunged into it, mutter the Aghamarshana three times, and then, after having emerged from it, mutter the Gâyatrî one thousand and eight times.
(If he has followed) the corpse of a dead member of a twice-born caste,  one hundred and eight times only.
If a Sûdra has followed the corpse of a member of a twice-born caste, he must bathe.
Members of any caste, who have come near to the smoke of a funeral pile, must bathe.
(Bathing is also ordained) after sexual intercourse, bad dreams (of having been mounted upon an ass, or the like), when blood has issued from the throat, and after having vomited or been purged;
Also, after tonsure of the head;
And after having touched one who has touched a corpse (a carrier of a corpse), or a woman in her courses, or a Kândâla (or other low-caste persons, such as Svapakas), or a sacrificial post;
And (after having touched) the corpse of a five-toed animal, except of those kinds that may be eaten, or their bones still moist with fat.

column1: sarveṣv eteṣu snāneṣu vastraṃ nāprakṣālitaṃ bibhṛyāt //
column2: In all such ablutions he must not wear his (defiled) apparel without having washed it before.
A woman in her courses becomes pure after four days by bathing.

column1: rajasvalā hīnavarṇāṃ rajasvalāṃ spṛṣṭvā na tāvad aśnīyāt yāvan na śuddhā //
column2: A woman in her courses having touched another woman in her courses, who belongs to a lower caste than she does, must not eat again till she is purified.

column1: savarṇām adhikavarṇāṃ vā spṛṣṭvā sadyaḥ snātvā śudhyati //
column2: If she has (unawares) touched a woman of her own caste, or of a higher caste than her own, she becomes pure at once, after having taken a bath.

column1: kṣutvā suptvā bhuktvā bhojanādhyayanepsuḥ pītvā snātvā niṣṭhīvya vāsaḥ paridhāya rathyām ākramya mūtrapurīṣaṃ kṛtvā pañcanakhāsthy asnehaṃ  # spṛṣṭvā cācamet //
column2: Having sneezed, having slept, having eaten,going to eat or to study, having drunk (water), having bathed, having spat, having put on his garment, having walked on the high road, having discharged urine or voided excrements, and having touched the bones no longer moist with fat of a five-toed animal, he must sip water;
Likewise, if he has talked to a Kândâla or to a Mlekkha (barbarian).

column1: nābher adhastāt prabāhuṣu ca kāyikair malaiḥ surābhir madyaiś copahato mṛttoyais tadaṅgaṃ prakṣālya śudhyet //
column2: If the lower part of his body, below the navel, or one of his fore-arms, has been defiled by one of the impure excretions of the body, or by one of the spirituous liquors or of the intoxicating drinks (hereafter mentioned), he is purified by cleansing the limb in question with earth and water.
If another part of his body (above the navel) has been defiled, (he becomes pure by cleansing it) with earth and water, and by bathing.
If his mouth has been defiled (he becomes pure) by fasting, bathing, and drinking Pañkagavya;

column1: daśanacchadopahataś ca // vasā śukram asṛṅ majjā mūtraṃ viṭ karṇaviṇnakhāḥ / śleṣmāśru dūṣikā svedo dvādaśaite nṛṇāṃ malāḥ //
column2: Adeps, semen, blood, dandruff, urine, fæces, earwax, nail-parings, phlegm, tears, rheum, and sweat, are the twelve impure excretions of the body.

column1: gauḍī mādhvī ca paiṣṭī ca vijñeyā trividhā surā /
column2: Distilled from sugar, or from the blossoms of the Madhûka. (Mâdhvi wine), or from flour: these three kinds of spirituous liquor have to be discerned;

column1: yathaivaikā tathā sarvā na pātavyā dvijātibhiḥ //
column2: as one, so are all: none of them must be tasted by the twice-born.

Again, distilled from the blossoms of theMadhûka tree (Madhûka wine), from molasses, from the fruits of the Tanka (or Kapittha tree), of the jujube tree, of the Khargûra tree, or of the breadfruit tree, from wine-grapes, from Madhûka blossoms (Mâdhvîka wine), Maireya, and the sap of the cocoanut tree:
These ten intoxicating drinks are unclean for a Brâhmana;

column1: rājanyaś caiva vaiśyaś ca spṛṣṭvaitāni na duṣyataḥ //
column2: but a Kshatriya and a Vaisya commit no wrong in touching (or drinking) them.

column1: guroḥ pretasya śiṣyas tu pitṛmedhaṃ samācaran / pretāhāraiḥ samaṃ tatra daśarātreṇa śudhyati //
column2: A pupil having performed (on failure of other mourners) the funeral of his dead Guru, becomes pure after ten nights, like those (kinsmen) who carry out the dead.

column1: ācāryaṃ svam upādhyāyaṃ pitaraṃ mātaraṃ gurum / nirhṛtya tu vratī pretān na vratena viyujyate //
column2: A student does not infringe the rules of his order by carrying out, when dead, his teacher, or his sub-teacher, or his father, or his mother, or his Guru.

column1: ādiṣṭī nodakaṃ kuryād ā vratasya samāpanāt /
column2: A student must not offer a libation of water to a deceased relative (excepting his parents) till the term of his studentship has expired;
but if, after its expiration, he offers a libation of water, he becomes pure after three nights.

column1: jñānaṃ tapo 'gnir āhāro mṛnmano vāryupāñjanam / vāyuḥ karmārkakālau ca śuddhikartṝṇi dehinām //
column2: Sacred knowledge , religious austerities (see go), fire , holy food (Pañkagavya), earth , the mind, water , smearing , air  religious acts, the sun, and time (by the lapse of the ten days of impurity and the like) are purifiers of animate objects.

column1: sarveṣām eva śaucānām annaśaucaṃ paraṃ smṛtam /
column2: Of all pure things, pure food is pronounced the most excellent;

column1: yo 'nne śuciḥ sa hi śucir na mṛdvāriśuciḥ śuciḥ //
column2: for he who eats pure food only, is truly pure, not he who is only purified with earth and water.
By forgiveness of injuries the learned are purified; by liberality, those who have done forbidden acts;
by muttering of prayers, those who have sinned in secret; by religious austerities, those who best know the Veda.

column1: mṛttoyaiḥ śudhyate śodhyaṃ nadī vegena śudhyati /
column2: By water and earth is purified what should be purified (because it has been defiled); a river is purified by its current (carrying away all slime and mud);
a woman, whose thoughts have been impure, by her menses,; and the chief among the twice-born (the Brâhmanas), by renouncing the world.

column1: adbhir gātrāṇi śudhyanti manaḥ satyena śudhyati /
column2: Bodies (when defiled) are purified by water; the mind is purified (from evil thoughts) by truth;
the soul (is purified or freed from worldly vanity) by sacred learning and austerities; the understanding (when unable to resolve some doubt), by knowledge.

column1: eṣa śaucasya te proktaḥ śārīrasya vinirṇayaḥ /
column2: Thus the directions for purifying animate bodies have been declared to thee;
hear now the rules for cleaning all sorts of inanimate objects.

column1: śārīrair malaiḥ surābhir madyair vā yad upahataṃ tad atyantopahatam //
column2: What has been defiled by the impure excretions of the body, by spirits, or by intoxicating drinks, is impure in the highest degree.

column1: atyantopahataṃ sarvaṃ lohabhāṇḍam agnau prakṣiptaṃ śudhyet //
column2: All vessels made of iron (or of other metals or of composition metals such as bell-metal and the like), which are impure in the highest degree, become pure by exposure to the fire.

column1: maṇimayam aśmamayam abjaṃ ca saptarātraṃ mahīnikhananena //
column2: Things made of gems or stones or water-shells, (such as conch-shells or mother-of-pearl, become pure) by digging them into the earth for seven days.
Vessels made of wood or earthenware must be thrown away.

column1: atyantopahatasya vastrasya yat prakṣālitaṃ sad virajyate tac chindyāt //
column2: Of a garment, which has been defiled in the highest degree, let him cut off that part which, having been washed, is changed in colour.
Objects made of gold, silver, water-shells, or gems, when (they are only defiled by leavings of food, and the like, and) not smeared (with greasy substances), are cleansed with water.
So are stone cups and vessels used at Soma-sacrifices (when not smeared).

column1: carusruksruvāṇām uṣṇenāmbhasā // yajñakarmaṇi yajñapātrāṇāṃ pāṇinā saṃmārjanena //
column2: Vessels used for oblations (of butter, fruits, and the like are cleansed) by rubbing them with the hand (with blades of Kusa grass) at the time of the sacrifice.
Sword-shaped pieces of wood for stirring the boiled rice, winnowing baskets, implements used for preparing grain, pestles and mortars (are cleansed) by sprinkling water over them.
So are beds, vehicles, and seats (when defiled even by the touch of a Sûdra).
Likewise, a large quantity (of anything).

Grain, skins (of antelopes, &c.), ropes, woven cloth, (fans and the like) made of bamboo, thread, cotton, and clothes (which have only just come from the manufactory, or which are dyed with saffron and will not admit of washing for that reason, are cleansed in the same way, when there is a large quantity of them);
Also, pot-herbs, roots, fruits, and flowers;
Likewise, grass, firewood, dry cow-dung (used as fuel), and leaves (of the Madhûka, Palâsa, or other trees).
The same (when smeared with excrements and the like, are cleansed) by washing
And so , when there is only a small quantity of them;
Silk and wool, with saline earths;
(Blankets or plaids) made of the hair of the mountain-goat, with the fruits of the soap plant;
Clothes made of the bark of trees, with Bèl fruit;
Linen cloth, with white sesamum;
Likewise, things made of horns, bone, or teeth;
(Rugs or covers) made of deer's hair, with lotus-seeds;
Vessels of copper, bell-metal, tin, and lead, with acidulated water;
Vessels of white copper and iron, with ashes;
Wooden articles, by planing;
Vessels made of fruits (such as cocoa-nuts, bottle-gourds, and Be] fruits), by (rubbing them with) cows' hair.
Liquids (such as clarified butter, milk, &c.), by straining them;

column1: utpavanena dravāṇām // guḍādīnām ikṣuvikārāṇāṃ prabhūtānāṃ gṛhanihitānāṃ vāryagnidānena //
column2: Lumps of sugar and other preparations from the sugar-cane, stored up in large quantities (exceeding a Drona) and kept in one's own house, by water and fire;
All sorts of salt, in the same manner;
Earthern vessels (if smeared with excrements and the like), by a second burning;
Images of gods (if smeared), by cleansing them in the same way as the material (of which they are made is generally cleansed), and then installing them anew (in their former place).

column1: asiddhasyānnasya yanmātram upahataṃ tanmātraṃ parityajya śeṣasya kaṇḍanaprakṣālane kuryāt //
column2: Of undressed grain let him remove so much only as has been defiled, and the remainder let him pound in a mortar and wash.

column1: droṇābhyadhikam siddham annam upahataṃ na duṣyati //
column2: A quantity of prepared grain not exceeding a Drona is not spoiled by being defiled (by dogs, crows, and other unclean animals).

column1: tasyopahatamātram apāsya gāyatryābhimantritaṃ suvarṇāmbhaḥ prakṣipet bastasya ca pradarśayed agneś ca // pakṣijagdhaṃ gavā ghrātam avadhūtam avakṣutam / dūṣitaṃ keśakīṭaiś ca mṛtprakṣepeṇa śudhyati //
column2: He must throw away thus much of it only as has been defiled, and must sprinkle over the remainder water, into which a piece of gold has been dropped, and over which the Gâyatrî has been pronounced, and must hold it tip before a goat (or before a horse) and before the fire.animals whose flesh may be eaten), has died, or which has been defiled in the highest degree, he must take out all the waters and dry up the remainder with a cloth.

column1: apaḥ samuddharet sarvāḥ śeṣaṃ vastreṇa śodhayet // vahniprajvālanaṃ kuryāt kūpe pakveṣṭakācite / pañcagavyaṃ nyaset paścān navatoyasamudbhave //
column2: If it is a well constructed with burnt bricks (or stones,) he must light a fire and afterwards throw Pañkagavya into it, when fresh water is coming forth.
For small reservoirs of water and for ponds the same mode of purification has been prescribed as for wells, O Earth;

column1: kūpavat kathitā śuddhir mahatsu ca na dūṣaṇam //
column2: but large tanks (excepting Tîrthas) are not defiled (by dead animals, &c.)
The gods have declared, as peculiar to Brâhmanas, three causes effecting purity: if an (existing) impurity has not been perceived by them;

column1: adṛṣṭam adbhir nirṇiktaṃ yac ca vācā praśasyate //
column2: if they, sprinkle the object (supposed to be impure) with water;

column1: nityaṃ śuddhaḥ kāruhastaḥ paṇyaṃ yac ca prasāritam / brāhamaṇāntaritaṃ bhaikṣyam ākarāḥ sarva eva ca //
column2: The hand of a (cook or other) artizan, things exposed for sale in a shop (though they may, have passed through the hands of many customers), food given to a Brâhmana (by other Brâhmanas, or by, Kshatriyas, &c., but not by Sûdras), and all manufactories or mines (of sugar, salt, and the like, but not distilleries of spirituous liquor), are always pure.

column1: nityam āsyaṃ śuci strīṇāṃ śakuniḥ phalapātane /
column2: The mouth of a woman is always pure (for the purpose of a kiss); a bird is pure on the fall of fruit (which he has pecked);

column1: prasrave ca śucir vatsaḥ śvā mṛgagrahaṇe śuciḥ // śvabhir hatasya yan māṃsaṃ śuci tat parikīrtitam /
column2: a dog, on his catching the deer. Flesh of an animal which has been killed by dogs is pronounced pure;

column1: kravyādbhiś ca hatasyānyaiś caṇḍālādyaiś ca dasyubhiḥ //
column2: and so is that of ananimal slain by other carnivorous creatures (such as tigers) or by huntsmen such as Kandâlas (Svapakas, Kshattris, or other low-caste men).

column1: ūrdhvaṃ nābher yāni khāni tāni medhyāni nirdiśet /
column2: The cavities above the navel must be considered as pure;

column1: yāny adhastāny amedhyāni dehāc caiva malāś cyutāḥ //
column2: those below it are impure; and so are all excretions that fall from the body.

column1: makṣikā vipruṣaś chāyā gaur gajāśvamarīcayaḥ / rajo bhūr vāyur agniś ca mārjāraś ca sadā śuciḥ //
column2: Flies, saliva dropping from the mouth, a shadow, a cow, an elephant, a horse, sun-beams, dust, the earth, air, fire, and a cat are always pure.

column1: nocchiṣṭaṃ kurvate mukhyā vipruṣo 'ṅge na yānti yāḥ / na śmaśrūṇi gatāny āsyaṃ na dantāntaraveṣṭitam //
column2: Such drops as fall from the mouth of a man upon any part of his body do not render it impure, nor do hairs of the beard that enter his mouth, nor remnants of his food adhering to his teeth.

column1: spṛśanti bindavaḥ pādau ya ācāmayataḥ parān / bhaumikais te samā jñeyā na tair aprayato bhavet // ucchiṣṭena tu saṃspṛṣṭo dravyahastaḥ kathaṃcana /
column2: Drops which trickle on the feet of a man holding water for others to sip it, are considered as equal to waters springing from the earth: by them he is not soiled.

column1: mārjanopāñjanair veśma prokṣaṇenaiva pustakam / saṃmārjanenāñjanena sekenollekhanena ca // dāhena ca bhuvaḥ śuddhir vāsenāpy atha vā gavām /
column2: A house is purified by scouring it with a broom and plastering the ground with cow-dung, and a manuscript or book by sprinkling water over it. Land is cleansed by scouring, by plastering it with cow-dung,
By sprinkling, by scraping, by burning, or by letting cows (or goats) pass (a day and a night) on it. Cows are auspicious purifiers, upon cows depend the worlds,

column1: gāvo vitanvate yjñaṃ gāvaḥ sarvāghasūdanāḥ / gomūtraṃ gomayaṃ sarpiḥ kṣīraṃ dadhi ca rocanā //
column2: Cows alone make sacrificial oblations possible (by producing sacrificial butter), cows take away every sin. The urine of cows, their dung, clarified butter, milk, sour milk, and Gorokanâ:

column1: ṣaḍaṅgam etat paramaṃ maṅgalyaṃ paramaṃ gavām / śṛṅgodakaṃ gavāṃ puṇyaṃ sarvāghaviniṣūdanam //
column2: Those six excellent (productions) of a cow are always propitious. Drops of water falling from the horns of a cow are productive of religious merit, and have the power to expiate all sins (of those who bathe in, or rub themselves with, them).

column1: gavām kaṇḍūyanaṃ caiva sarvakalmaṣanāśanam / gavāṃ grāsapradānena svargaloke mahīyate //
column2: Scratching the back of a cow destroys all guilt, and giving her to eat procures exaltation in heaven.

column1: gavāṃ hi tīrthe vasatīha gaṅgā puṣṭis tathāsāṃ rajasi pravṛddhā / lakṣmīḥ karīṣe praṇatau ca dharmas tāsāṃ praṇāmaṃ satataṃ ca kuryāt //
column2: In the urine of cows dwells the Ganges, prosperity (dwells) in the dust (rising from their couch), good fortune in cow-dung, and virtue in saluting them. Therefore should they be constantly saluted.

column1: atha brāhmaṇasya varṇānukrameṇa catasro bhāryā bhavanti //
column2: Now a Brâhmana may take four wives in the direct order of the (four) castes;
A Kshatriya, three;
A Vaisya, two;
A Sûdra, one only.
Among these (wives), if a man marries one of his own caste, their hands shall be joined.
In marriages with women of a different class, a Kshatriya bride must hold an arrow in her hand;
A Vaisya bride,. a whip;
A Sûdra bride, the skirt of a mantle.

column1: na sagotrāṃ na samānārṣapravarāṃ bhāryāṃ vindeta // mātṛtas tv ā pañcamāt puruṣāt *pitṛtaś cā saptamāt [pitṛtāś] //
column2: Nor (should he marry) one descended from his maternal ancestors within the fifth, or from his paternal ancestors within the seventh degree;
Nor one of a low family (such as an agriculturer's, or an attendant of the king's family);
Nor one diseased;
Nor one with a limb too much (as e. g. having six fingers);
Nor one with a limb too little;
Nor one whose hair is decidedly red;
Nor one talking idly.
There are eight forms of marriage

column1: brāhmo daiva ārṣaḥ prājāpatyo gāndharva āsuro rākṣasaḥ paiśācaś ceti //
column2: The Brâhma, Daiva, Ârsha, Prâgâpatya, Gândharva, Âsura, Râkshasa, and Paisâka forms.
The gift of a damsel to a fit bridegroom, who has been invited, is called a Brâhma marriage.
If she is given to a Ritvig (priest), while he is officiating at a sacrifice, it is called a Daiva marriage.
If (the giver of the bride) receives a pair of kine in return, a is called an Ârsha marriage.
(If she is given to a suitor) by his demand, it is called a Prâgâpatya marriage.
A union between two lovers, without the consent of mother and father, is called a Gândharva marriage.
If the damsel is sold (to the bridegroom), it is called an Âsura marriage.
If he seizes her forcibly, it is called a Râkshasa marriage.
If he embraces her in her sleep, or while she is unconscious, it is called a Paisâka marriage.
Among those (eight forms of marriage), the four first forms are legitimate (for a Brâhmana);
And so is the Gândharva form for a Kshatriya.
A son procreated in a Brâhma marriage redeems (or sends into the heavenly abodes hereafter mentioned) twenty-one men (viz. ten ancestors, ten descendants, and him who gave the damsel in marriage).
A son procreated in a Daiva marriage, fourteen;
A son procreated in an Ârsha marriage, seven;
A son procreated in a Prâgâpatya marriage, four.

column1: brāhmeṇa vivāhena kanyāṃ dadat brahmalokaṃ gamayati //
column2: He who gives a damsel in marriage according to the Brâhma rite, brings her into the world of Brahman (after her death, and enters that world himself).
(He who gives her in marriage) according to the Daiva rite, (brings her) into Svarga (or heaven, and enters Svarga himself).
(He who gives her in marriage) according to the Ârsha rite, (brings her) into the world of Vishnu (and enters that world himself).
(He who gives her in marriage) according to the Prâgâpatya rite, (brings her) into the world of the gods (and enters that world himself).
(He who gives her in marriage) according to the Gândharva rite, will go to the world of Gandharvas.

column1: pitā pitāmaho bhrātā sakulyo mātāmaho mātā ceti kanyāpradāḥ //
column2: A father, a paternal grandfather, a brother, a kinsman, a maternal grandfather, and the mother (are the persons) by whom a girl may be given in marriage.
On failure of the preceding one (it devolves upon) the next in order (to give her in marriage), in case he is able.

column1: ṛtutrayam upāsyaiva kanyā kuryāt svayaṃ varam /
column2: When she has allowed three monthly periods to pass (without being married), let her choose a husband for herself;

column1: ṛtutraye vyatīte tu prabhavaty ātmanaḥ sadā //
column2: three monthly periods having passed, she has in every case full power to dispose of herself (as she thinks best).

column1: pitṛveśmani yā kanyā rajaḥ paśyaty asaṃskṛtā /
column2: A damsel whose menses begin to appear (while she is living) at her father's house, before she has been betrothed to a man, has to be considered as a degraded woman: by taking her (without the consent of her kinsmen) a man commits no wrong.
Now the duties of a woman (are as follows):
To live in harmony with her husband;
To show reverence (by embracing their feet and such-like attentions) to her mother-in-law, father-in-law, to Gurus (such as elders), to divinities, and to guests;
To keep household articles (such as the winnowing basket and the rest) in good array;
To maintain saving habits;
To be careful with her (pestle and mortar and other) domestic utensils;
Not to practise incantations with roots (or other kinds of witchcraft);
To observe auspicious customs;
Not to decorate herself with ornaments (or to partake of amusements) while her husband is absent from home;
Not to resort to the houses of strangers (during the absence of her husband);
Not to stand near the doorway or by the windows (of her house);
Not to act by herself in any matter;
To remain subject, in her infancy, to her father; in her youth, to her husband; and in her old age, to her sons.

column1: mṛte bhartari brahmacaryaṃ tadanv ārohaṇaṃ vā //
column2: After the death of her husband, to preserve her chastity, or to ascend the pile after him.

column1: nāsti strīṇāṃ pṛthagyajño na vrataṃ nāpy upoṣitam /
column2: No sacrifice, no penance, and no fasting is allowed to women apart from their husbands;

column1: patiṃ śuśrūṣate yat tu tena svarge mahīyate //
column2: to pay obedience to her lord is the only means for a woman to obtain bliss in heaven.

column1: patyau jīvati yā yoṣid upavāsavrataṃ caret / āyuḥ sā harate bhartur narakaṃ caiva gacchati //
column2: A woman who keeps a fast or performs a penance in the lifetime of her lord, deprives her husband of his life, and will go to hell.

column1: svargaṃ gacchaty aputrāpi yathā te brahmacāriṇaḥ //
column2: A good wife, who perseveres in a chaste life after the death of her lord, will go to heaven like (perpetual) students, even though she has no son.

column1: savarṇāsu bahubhāryāsu vidyamānāsu *jyeṣṭhayā saha dharmakāryaṃ kuryāt [jyeṣṭayā] //
column2: If a man has several wives of his own caste,he shall perform his religious duties together with the eldest (or first-married) wife.
(If he has several) wives of divers castes (he shall perform them) even with the youngest wife if she is of the same caste as himself.
On failure of a wife of his own caste (he shall perform them) with one belonging to the caste next below his own;
But no twice-born man ever with a Sûdra wife.

column1: dvijasya bhāryā śūdrā tu dharmārthaṃ na kvacid bhavet /
column2: A union of a twice-born man with a Sûdra wife can never produce religious merit;

column1: ratyartham eva sā tasya rāgāndhasya prakīrtitā //
column2: it is from carnal desire only that he marries her, being blinded by lust.

column1: hīnajātiṃ striyaṃ mohād udvahanto dvijātayaḥ / kulāny eva nayanty āśu sasaṃtānāni śūdratāṃ //
column2: Men of the three first castes, who through folly marry a woman of the lowest caste, quickly degrade their families and progeny to the state of Sûdras.

column1: daivapitryāthiteyāni tatpradhānāni yasya tu / nāśnanti pitṛdevās tu na ca svargaṃ sa gacchati //
column2: , If his oblations to the gods and manes and (his hospitable attentions) to guests are offered principally through her hands, the gods and manes (and the guests) will not eat such offerings, and he will not go to heaven.
The Nishekakarman (ceremony of impregnation)must be performed when the season fit for procreating children distinctly appears (for the first time).
The Pumsavana (ceremony to cause the birth of a male) must be performed before the embryo begins to move.
The Sîmantonnayana (ceremony of parting the hair) should take place in the sixth or eighth month (of pregnancy).
The Gâtakarman (birth-ceremony) should take place on the birth of the child.
The Nâmadheya (naming-rite) must be performed as soon as the term of impurity (caused by the birth of the child) is over.
(The name to be chosen should be) auspicious in the case of a Brâhmana;
Indicating power in the case of a Kshatriya;
Indicating wealth in the case of a Vaisya;
Indicating contempt in the case of a Sûdra.
The Âdityadarsana, (ceremony of taking the child out to see the sun) should take place in the fourth month (after birth).
The Annaprâsana (ceremony of first feeding) should take place in the sixth month.
The Kûdâkarana '(tonsure rite) should take place in the third year .
For female children the same ceremonies, (beginning with the birth ceremony, should be performed, but) without Mantras.
The marriage ceremony only has to be performed with Mantras for them.
The initiation of Brâhmanas (should take plate) in the eighth year after conception;
Of Kshatriyas, in the eleventh year after conception;
Of Vaisyas,, in the twelfth year after conception;
Their girdles should be made of Muñga grass, a bow-string, and Balbaga (coarse grass) respectively.
Their sacrificial strings and their garments should be made of cotton, hemp, and wool respectively.
Their staves should be made of Palâsa, Khadira, and Udumbara wood respectively.
Their staves should be of such a length as to reach the hair, the forehead, and the nose respectively.
Or all (kinds of staves may be used for all castes indiscriminately).
And they should not be crooked, nor should the bark be stripped off.
In begging alms, they should put in the word 'Lady' at the beginning, in the middle, and at the end of their request (according to their caste).
The ceremony of initiation must not be delayed beyond the sixteenth year in the case of a Brâhmana;

column1: ā dvāviṃśāt kṣatrabandhor ā caturviṃśater viśaḥ //
column2: beyond the twenty-second, in the case of a Kshatriya; and beyond the twenty-fourth, in the case of a Vaisya.

column1: ata ūrdhvaṃ trayo 'py ete yathākālam asaṃskṛtāḥ / sāvitrīpatitā vrātyā bhavanty āryavigarhitāḥ //
column2: After that, the youths belonging to any of those three castes, who have not been initiated at the proper time, are excluded from initiation, and contemned by the twice-born, and are called Vrâtyas.

column1: yady asya vihitaṃ carma yat sūtraṃ yā ca mekhalā / yo daṇḍo yac ca vasanaṃ tat tad asya vrateṣv api //
column2: That skin, that cord, that girdle, that staff, and that garment which has been given to any one (on his initiation), that he must for ever wear when performing any religious observance.

column1: mekhalām ajinaṃ daṇḍam upavītaṃ kamaṇḍalum / apsu prāsya vinaṣṭāni gṛhṇītānyāni mantravat //
column2: His girdle, his skin, his staff, his string, and his ewer he must throw into the water when broken (or spoiled by use), and receive others consecrated with Mantras.
Now students shall dwell at their Guru's (spiritual teacher's) house.
They shall recite their morning and evening prayers.

column1: pūrvāṃ saṃdhyāṃ japet tiṣṭhan paścimām āsīnaḥ //
column2: (A student) shall mutter the morning prayer standing, and the evening prayer sitting.
He shall perform twice a day (in the mornings and evenings) the religious acts of sprinkling the ground (round the altar) and of putting fuel on the fire.
He must plunge into the waters like a stick.
Let him study when called (by his teacher).
He shall act so as to please his Guru (spiritual teacher) and to be serviceable to him.
He shall wear his girdle, his staff, his skin, and his sacrificial string.
He shall go begging at the houses of virtuous persons, excepting those of his Guru's (and of his own) relatives.
He may eat (every morning and evening) some of the food collected by begging, after having received permission to do so from his Guru.

He must avoid Srâddhas, factitious salt, food turned sour, stale food, dancing, singing, women, honey, meat, ointments, remnants of the food (of other persons than his teacher), the killing of living beings, and rude speeches.
. He must occupy a low couch.
He must rise before his Guru and go to rest after him.
He must salute his Guru, after having performed his morning devotion.
Let him embrace his feet with crossed hands.
The right foot with his right hand, and the left foot with his left.
After the salutation (abhivâdaye, 'I salute') he must mention his own name and add the word 'bhos' (Venerable Sir) at the end of his address.

column1: tiṣṭhann āsīnaḥ śayāno bhuñjānaḥ parāṅmukhaś ca nāsyābhibhāṣaṇaṃ kuryāt //
column2: He must not speak to his Guru while he is himself standing, or sitting, or lying, or eating, or averting his face. And let him speak, if his teacher sits, standing up; if he walks, advancing towards him;

column1: āsīnasya sthitaḥ kuryād abhigacchaṃs tu gacchataḥ /
column2: if he is coming near, meeting him;

column1: āgacchataḥ pratyudgamya paścād dhāvaṃs tu dhāvataḥ //
column2: if he runs, running after him;
If his face is averted, turning round so as to face him;
If he is at some distance, approaching him;
If he is in a reclining position, bending to him;

column1: tasya ca cakṣurviṣaye na yatheṣṭāsanaḥ syāt //
column2: Let him not sit in a careless attitude (such as e. g. having a cloth tied round his legs and knees, while sitting on his hams) before the eyes of his teacher,
Neither must he pronounce his mere name (without adding to it the word Srî or a similar term at the beginning).
He must not mimic his gait, his manner, his speech, and so on.

column1: yatrāsya nindāparivādau syātāṃ na tatra tiṣṭhet //
column2: Where his Guru is censured or foully belied, there let him not stay.
Nor must he sit on the same seat with him,
Unless it be on a rock, on a wooden bench, in a boat, or in a carriage.
If his teacher's teacher is near, let him behave towards him as if he were his own teacher.

column1: anirdiṣṭaś ca guruṇā svān gurun nābhivādayet //
column2: He must nor salute his own Gurus without his teacher's leave.

column1: bāle samānavayasi vādhyāpake guruputre guruvad varteta //
column2: Let him behave towards the son of his teacher, who teaches him the Veda, as towards his teacher, even though he be younger or of an equal age with himself;
But he must not wash his feet,
Nor eat the leaving of his food.

column1: evaṃ vedaṃ vedau vedān vā svīkuryāt //
column2: Thus let him acquire by heart one Veda, or two Vedas, or (all) the Vedas.
Thereupon, the Vedângas (that treating of phonetics and the rest).

column1: yas tv anadhītavedo 'nyatra śramaṃ kuryād asau sasaṃtānaḥ śūdratvam eti //
column2: He who, not having studied the Veda, applies himself to another study, will degrade himself, and his progeny with him, to the state of a Sûdra.
From the mother is the first birth;

column1: tatrāsya mātā sāvitrī bhavati pitā tv *ācāryaḥ [ācārthaḥ] //
column2: In the latter, the Sâvitrî hymn is his mother, and the teacher his father.
It is this which entitles members of the three higher castes to the designation of 'the twice-born.'
Previous to his being girded with the sacrificial string, a member of these castes is similar to a Sûdra (and not allowed to study the Veda).
A student shall shave all his hair, or wear it tied in one lock.

column1: vedasvīkaraṇād ūrdhvaṃ gurvanujñātas tasmai varaṃ dattvā snāyāt //
column2: After having mastered the Veda, let him take leave of his teacher and bathe, after having presented, him with a gift.

column1: tato gurukula eva vā janmanaḥ śeṣaṃ nayet //
column2: Or let him spend the remainder of his life at his teacher's house.

column1: tatrācārye prete guruvat guruputre varteta // gurudāreṣu savarṇeṣu vā //
column2: If, while he is living there, his teacher should die, let him behave to his teacher's son as towards his teacher himself;
On failure of such, let him pay homage to the fire, and live as a perpetual student.

column1: evaṃ carati yo vipro brahmacaryam atandritaḥ / sa gacchaty uttamaṃ sthānaṃ na cehājāyate punaḥ //
column2: A Brâhmana who passes thus without tiring (of the discharge of his duties) the time of his studentship will attain to the most exalted heavenly abode (that of Brahman) after his death, and will not be born again in this world.

A voluntary effusion of the semen by a twice-born youth (in sexual intercourse with a woman), during the period of his studentship, has been pronounced a transgression of the rule prescribed for students by expounders of the Vedas well acquainted with the system of duties.

column1: etasminn enasi prāpte vasitvā gardabhājinam / saptāgāraṃ cared bhaikṣaṃ svakarma parikīrtayan //
column2: Having loaded himself with that crime, be must go begging to seven houses, clothed only with the skin of an ass, and proclaiming his deed.

column1: tebhyo labdhena bhaikṣyeṇa vartayann ekakālikam / upaspṛśaṃs triṣavaṇam abdena sa viśudhyati //
column2: Eating once a day only a meal consisting of the alms obtained at those (houses), and bathing at the three Savanas (dawn, noon, and evening), he will be absolved from guilt at the end of the year.

column1: svapne siktvā brahmacārī dvijaḥ śukram akāmataḥ / snātvārkam arcayitvā triḥ punar mām ity ṛcaṃ japet //
column2: After an involuntary effusion of the semen during sleep, a twice-born student must bathe (on the next morning), worship the sun (by offerings of perfumes and the like), and mutter three times the Mantra, 'Again shall my strength return to me.'

column1: akṛtvā bhaikṣacaraṇam asamiddhya ca pāvakam / anāturaḥ saptarātram avakīrṇivrataṃ caret //
column2: He who for seven days omits to collect alms and to kindle the sacred fire, must perform the penance of an Avakîrnin (breaker of his vow), provided that he has not been prevented from the discharge of his duties by an illness.

column1: taṃ ced abhyudiyāt sūryaḥ śayānaṃ kāmakārataḥ / nimloced vāpy+avijñānāj japann upavased dinam //
column2: If the sun should rise or set while a student is purposely indulging in sleep, ignoring (the precepts of law), he must fast for a day, muttering (the Gâyatrî one thousand and eight times).

column1: yas tūpanīya vratādeśaṃ kṛtvā vedam adhyāpayet tam ācāryaṃ vidyāt //
column2: He who teaches him (after he has been initiated by another) either (an entire branch of the Veda) in consideration of a fee, or part of a Veda (without taking a fee), is called Upâdhyâya (sub-teacher).

column1: yo yasya yajñnakarmāṇi kuryāt tam ṛtvijaṃ vidyāt //
column2: He who performs sacrifices (whether based upon Sruti or upon Smriti) is called Ritvig (officiating priest).
He must not engage a priest for the performance of sacrifices without having ascertained (his descent, character, and conduct).
Neither must he admit to his teaching (one whom he does not know).
And he must not initiate such a one.

column1: adharmeṇa ca yaḥ prāha yaś cādharmeṇa pṛcchati /
column2: If one answers improperly, or the other asks improperly, that one (or both) will perish or incur hatred.

column1: tayor anyataraḥ praiti vidveṣaṃ vādhigacchati // dharmārthau yatra na syātāṃ śuśrūṣā vāpi tadvidhā / tatra vidyā na vaktavyā śubhaṃ bījam ivoṣare //
column2: If by instructing a pupil neither religious merit nor wealth are acquired, and if no sufficient attention is to be obtained from him (for his teacher's words), in such soil divine knowledge must not be sown: it would perish like fine seed in barren soil.

column1: vidyā ha vai brahmaṇam ājagāma gopāya mā śevadhiṣṭe 'ham asti / asūyakāyānṛjave 'yatāya na māṃ brūyā avīryavatī tathā syām //
column2: The deity of sacred knowledge approached a Brâhmana (and said to him), 'Preserve me, I am thy treasure, reveal me not to a scorner, nor to a wicked man, nor to one of uncontrolled passions: thus I shall be strong

column1: yas te na druhyet katamac ca nāha tasmai māṃ brūyā nidhipāya brahman //
column2: 'Reveal me to him, as to a keeper of thy gem, O Brâhmana, whom thou shalt know to be pure, attentive, possessed of a good memory, and chaste, who will not grieve thee, nor revile thee.'

column1: śrāvaṇyāṃ prauṣṭhapadyāṃ vā chandāṃsy upākṛtyārdhapañcamān māsān adhīyīta //
column2: After having performed the Upâkarman ceremony on the full moon of the month Srâvana, or of the month Bhâdra, the student must (pass over the two next days without studying, and then) study for four months and a half.
After that, the teacher must perform out of town the ceremony of Utsarga for those students (that have acted up to this injunction);

but not for those who have failed to perform the ceremony of Upâkarman. During the period (subsequent upon the ceremony of Upâkarman and) intermediate between it and the ceremony of Utsarga, the student must read the Vedângas.
He must interrupt his study for a day and a night on the fourteenth and eighth days of a month.
(He must interrupt his study for the next dayand night) after a season of the year has begun, (and for three nights) after an eclipse of the moon.
(He must not study for a day and a night) when Indra's flag is hoisted or taken down.
(He must not study) when a strong wind is going,
(He must not study for three days) when rain, lightning, and thunder happen out of season.
(He must not study till the same hour next day) in the case of an earthquake, of the fall of a meteor, and when the horizon is preternaturally red, as if on fire.
(He must not study) in a village in which a corpse lies;
Nor during a battle;
Nor while dogs are barking, jackals yelling. or asses braying;
Nor while the sound of a musical instrument is being, heard;
Nor while Sûdras or outcasts are near;
Nor in the vicinity of a temple, of a burial-ground, of a place where four ways meet, or of a high road;
Nor while immersed in water;
Nor with his foot placed upon a bench;
Nor while riding upon an elephant, a horse, or a camel, (or in a carriage drawn by any of those animals), or being borne in a boat, or in a carriage drawn by oxen;
Nor after having vomited;
Nor after having been purged;
Nor during an indigestion.
When a five-toed animal has passed between the teacher and the pupil (the latter must interrupt his study for a day and a night).
When a king or a learned Brâhmana (who has mastered one Veda), or a cow, or a Brâhmana (in general) has met with an accident (he must not study).
After the Upâkarman (he must not study for three days).
And after the Utsarga, (he must interrupt his study for as many days).
Let him not lie down to sleep again when he has begun to study in the second half of the night.
Let him avoid studying at times when there ought to be an intermission of study, even though a question has been put to him (by his teacher);
Since to study on forbidden days neither benefits him in this nor in the other world.
To study on such days destroys the life of both teacher and pupil.

column1: tasmād anadhyāyavarjaṃ guruṇā brahmalokakāmena vidyā satśiṣyakṣetreṣu vaptavyā //
column2: Therefore should a teacher, who wishes to obtain the world of Brahman, avoid improper days, and sow (on proper days) the seed of sacred knowledge on soil consisting of virtuous pupils.
At the beginning and at the end of the lecture let the pupil embrace his teacher's feet;
And let him pronounce the sacred syllable Om.

column1: tatra ca yad ṛco 'dhīte tenāsyājyena pitṝṇāṃ tṛptir bhavati //
column2: Now he who studies the hymns of the Rig-veda (regularly), feeds the manes with clarified butter.
He who studies the Yagus texts, (feeds them) with honey.
He who studies the Sâman melodies, (feeds them) with milk.
He who studies the Atharva-veda, (feeds them) with meat.
He who studies the Purânas, Itihâsas, Vedângas, and the Institutes of Sacred Law, feeds them with rice.

column1: yaś ca vidyām āsādyāsmin loke tayā jīvet,
column2: He who having collected sacred knowledge, gains his substance by it in this world, will derive no benefit from it in the world to come.

column1: na sā tasya paraloke phalapradā bhavet // yaś ca vidyayā yaśaḥ pareṣāṃ hanti //
column2: Neither will he (derive such benefit from it), who uses his knowledge in order to destroy the reputation of others (by defeating them in argument).

column1: ananujñātaś cānyasmād adhīyānān na vidyām ādadyāt //
column2: Let no one acquire sacred knowledge, without his teacher's permission, from another who is studying divine science.
. Acquiring it in that way constitutes theft of the Veda, and will bring him into hell.

column1: laukikaṃ vaidikaṃ vāpi tathādhyātmikam eva vā / ādadīta yato jñānaṃ na taṃ druhyet kadācana //
column2: Let (a student) never grieve that man from whom he has obtained worldly knowledge (relating to poetry, rhetoric, and the like subjects), sacred knowledge (relating to the Vedas and Vedângas), or knowledge of the Supreme Spirit.
Of the natural progenitor and the teacher who imparts the Veda to him, the giver of the Veda is the more venerable father;

column1: saṃbhūtiṃ tasya tāṃ vidyād yad yonāv iha jāyate //
column2: for it is the new existence acquired by his initiation in the Veda, which will last him both in this life and the next.

column1: ācāryas tv asya yāṃ jātiṃ vidhivad vedapāragaḥ / utpādayati sāvitryā sā satyā sājarāmarā //
column2: That existence which his teacher, who knows all the Vedas, effects for him through the prescribed rites of initiation with (his divine mother) the Gâyatrî, is a true existence;

column1: ya āvṛṇoty avitathena karṇāv aduḥkhaṃ kurvann amṛtaṃ saṃprayacchan / taṃ manyeta pitaraṃ mātaraṃ ca tasmai na druhyet kṛtam asya jānan //
column2: He who fills his ears with holy truths, whofrees him from all pain (in this world and the next). and confers immortality (or final liberation) upon him, that man let the student consider as his (true) father and mother: gratefully acknowledging the debt he owes him, he must never grieve him.
A man has three Atigurus (or specially venerable superiors):
His father, his mother, and his spiritual teacher.
To them he must always pay obedience.
What they say, that he must do.
And he must do what is agreeable and serviceable to them.

column1: na tair ananujñātaḥ kiṃcid api kuryāt //
column2: Let him never do anything without their leave.

column1: eta eva trayo vedā eta eva trayaḥ surāḥ / eta eva trayo lokā eta eva trayo 'gnayaḥ //
column2: Those three are equal to the three Vedas (Rig-veda, Sâma-veda, and Yagur-veda), they are equal to the three gods (Brahman, Vishnu, and Siva), they are equal to the three worlds (of men, of gods, and of Brahman), they are equal to the three fires.

column1: pitā gārhaptyo 'gniḥ dakṣināgnir mātā gurur āhavanīyaḥ //
column2: The father is the Gârhapatya (or household) fire, the mother is the Dakshina (or ceremonial) fire, and the spiritual teacher is the Âhavanîya (or sacrificial) fire.

column1: sarve tasyādṛtā dharmā yasyaite traya ādṛtāḥ /
column2: He pays regard to all his duties, who pays regard to those three;

column1: anādṛtyās tu yasyaite sarvās tasyāphalāḥ kriyāḥ //
column2: he who shows no regard tothem, derives no benefit from any religious observance.

column1: imaṃ lokaṃ mātṛbhaktyā pitṛbhaktyā tu madhyamam /
column2: By honouring his mother, he gains the present world; by honouring his father, the world of gods;
and by paying strict obedience to his spiritual teacher, the world of Brahman.

A king, a priest, a learned Brâhmana, one who stops wicked proceedings, an Upâdhyâya, a paternal uncle, a maternal grandfather, a maternal uncle, a father-in-law, an eldest brother, and the parents-in-law of a son or a daughter are equal to a teacher;
And so are their wives, who are equal in caste to them.
And their mother's sister, their father's sister, and I their eldest sister.
A father-in-law, a paternal uncle, a maternaluncle, and a priest he must honour by rising to meet and saluting them, even though they be younger than himself.

column1: hīnavarṇānāṃ gurupatnīnāṃ dūrād abhivādanaṃ na pādopasparśanam //
column2: The wives of Gurus (superiors), who are of a lower class than their husbands (such as Kshatriya or Vaisya or Mûrdhâvasikta wives), shall be honoured by (rising to meet and) saluting them from far;

but he must not embrace their feet. He should avoid to rub and anoint the limbs of Guru's wives, or to anoint their eyes, or to arrange their hair, or to wash their feet, or to do other such services for them.

column1: asaṃstutāpi parapatnī bhaginīti vācyā putrīti māteti vā //
column2: To the wife of another, even though he does not know her, he must either say 'sister' (if she is of equal age with himself), or 'daughter' (if she is younger than himself), or 'mother' (if she is older than himself).

column1: na ca gurūṇāṃ tvam iti brūyāt //
column2: Let him not say 'thou' to his Gurus (superiors).
If he has offended one of them (by saying 'thou' to him, or in some other manner), he must keep a fast and not eat again till the end of the day, after having obtained his forgiveness.

column1: na ca guruṇā saha vigṛhya kathāḥ kuryāt //
column2: He must avoid to quarrel with his spiritual teacher and to argue with him (from emulation).
And he must not censure him;
Nor act so as to displease him.

column1: gurupatnī tu yuvatir nābhivādyeha pādayoḥ / pūrṇaviṃśativarṣeṇa guṇadoṣau vijānatā //
column2: (A pupil) must not embrace the feet of a Guru's young wife, if he has completed his twentieth year, or can distinguish virtue from vice.

column1: kāmaṃ tu gurupatnīnāṃ yuvatīnāṃ yuvā bhuvi / vidhivad vandanaṃ kuryād asāv aham iti bruvan //
column2: But a young student may at pleasure prostrate himself before a young wife of his Guru, (stretching out both hands) as ordained , 'I, N. N. (ho! salute thee).'

column1: viproṣya pādagrahaṇam anvahaṃ cābhivādanam / gurudāreṣu kurvīta satāṃ dharmam anusmaran //
column2: On returning from a journey he shall (once) embrace the feet of the wives of his Gurus (superiors), and daily, salute them, remembering the practice of the virtuous.

column1: vittaṃ bandhur vayaḥ karma vidyā bhavati pañcamī /
column2: Wealth, kindred, age, the performance of religious observances, and, fifthly, sacred knowledge are titles to respect;

column1: etāni mānasthānāni garīyo yad yad uttaram //
column2: each subsequent one is superior to the one preceding in order.

column1: brāhmaṇaṃ daśavarṣaṃ ca śatavarṣaṃ ca bhūmipam /
column2: A Brâhmana, though only ten years old, and a member of the kingly caste, though a hundred years old, must be considered as father and son;

column1: pitāputrau vijānīyād brāhmaṇas tu tayoḥ pitā //
column2: and of these two, the Brâhmana is the father.

column1: viprāṇāṃ jñānato jyaiṣṭhyaṃ kṣatriyāṇāṃ tu vīryataḥ /
column2: The seniority of Brâhmanas is founded upon sacred knowledge; of Kshatriyas, upon valour in arms;
of Vaisyas, upon grain and (other) wealth; of Sûdras, upon (priority of) birth.

column1: atha puruṣasya kāmakrodhalobhākhyaṃ riputrayaṃ sughoraṃ bhavati //
column2: Now man has three most dangerous enemies, called carnal desire, wrath, and greed.
They are specially dangerous to the order of householders, because they have (houses, wives, and other) property.
Man, being overcome by those (three enemies), commits crimes in the highest degree, high crimes, minor crimes, and crimes in the fourth degree;
Also crimes effecting loss of caste, crimes degrading to a mixed caste, and crimes rendering the perpetrator unworthy (to receive alms and the like);
And crimes causing defilement, and miscellaneous offences.

column1: trividhaṃ narakasyedaṃ dvāraṃ nāśanam ātmanaḥ / kāmaḥ krodhas tathā lobhas tasmād etat trayaṃ jyayet //
column2: This is the threefold path to hell, destructive of self: carnal desire, wrath, and greed: therefore must a man shun those three vices.
Sexual connection with one's mother, or daughter, or daughter-in-law are crimes in the highest degree.
Such criminals in the highest degree should proceed into the flames;

column1: na hy anyā niṣkṛtis teṣāṃ vidyate hi kathaṃcana //
column2: for there is not any other way to atone for their crime.

column1: brahmahatyā surāpānaṃ brāhmaṇasuvarṇaharaṇaṃ gurudāragamanam iti mahāpātakāni //
column2: Killing a Brâhmana, drinking spirituous liquor,stealing the gold of a Brâhmana, and sexual connection with a Guru's wife are high crimes.
And social intercourse with such (criminals is also a high crime).
He who associates with an outcast is outcasted himself after a year;
And so is he who rides in the same carriage with him, or who eats in his company, or who sits on the same bench, or who lies on the same couch with him.
Sexual intercourse, intercourse in sacrificing, and intercourse by the mouth (with an outcast) entails immediate loss of caste.

column1: aśvamedhena śuddhyeyur mahāpātakinas tv ime / pṛthivyāṃ sarvatīrthānāṃ tathānusaraṇena ca //
column2: Such mortal sinners are purified by a horse sacrifice and by visiting all Tîrthas (places of pilgrimage) on earth.

column1: yāgasthasya kṣatriyasya vaiśyasya ca rajasvalāyāś cāntarvatnyāś cātrigotrāyāś cāvijñātasya garbhasya śaraṇāgatasya ca ghātanaṃ brahmahatyāsamānīti
column2: Killing a Kshatriya or Vaisya engaged in a sacrifice, or a woman in her courses, or a pregnant woman, or a woman (of the Brâhmana caste) who has bathed after temporary uncleanness, or an embryoof unknown sex, or one come for protection, are crimes equal to the crime of killing a Brâhmana.
Giving false evidence and killing a friend: these two crimes are equal to the drinking of spirituous liquor.
Appropriating to one's self land belonging to a Brâhmana or a deposit (belonging to a Brâhmana and not consisting of gold) are crimes equal to a theft of gold (belonging to a Brâhmana).
Sexual connection with the wife of a paternal uncle, of a maternal grandfather, of a maternal uncle, of a father-in-law, or of the king, are crimes equal to sexual connection with a Guru's wife;
And so is sexual intercourse with the father's or mother's sister and with one's own sister;
And sexual connection with the wife of a learned Brâhmana, or a priest, or an Upâdhyâya, or a friend;

column1: svasuḥ sakhyāḥ sagotrāya uttamavarṇāyāḥ kumāryā antyajāyā rajasvalāyāḥ śaraṇāgatāyāḥ *pravrajitāyā nikṣiptāyāś ca [pravrajitāyāḥ ni] //
column2: And with a sister's female friend (or with one's own female friend), with a woman of one's own race, with a woman belonging to the Brâhmana caste, with a (Brâhmana) maiden (who is not yet betrothed to a man), with a low-caste woman, with a woman in her courses, with a woman come for protection,with a female ascetic, and with a woman entrusted to one's own care.

column1: anupātakinas tv ete mahāpātakino yathā / aśvamedhena śudhyanti tīrthānusaraṇena vā //
column2: Such minor offenders become pure, like mortal sinners, by a horse-sacrifice and by visiting Tîrthas.
Making statements, which will reach the ears of the king, regarding a (minor) offence committed by some one;
Unjustly upbraiding a Guru (as by saying 'You have neglected such a household duty');
Reviling the Veda;
(Abandoning) one's holy fire, or one's father, mother, son, or wife;
Eating the food of those whose food may not be eaten, or forbidden food;
Appropriating to one's self (grain, copper, or other) goods of another man (but not his gold);
Sexual intercourse with another man's wife;
To live by a forbidden occupation (as, if a Brâhmana lives by the occupation of a Kshatriya, or of a Vaisya).
Receiving unlawful presents;
Killing a Kshatriya, or a Vaisya, or a Sûdra, or a cow;
Selling articles that ought not to be sold (such as salt, lac, or others);
For a younger brother to marry, though his elder brother is not yet married;
To give a girl in marriage to either of those two (categories of offenders);
To teach the Veda for a reward (unless it be in an emergency);
To be taught by one who teaches the Veda for a reward (unless it be in an emergency);
To be employed (by the king's order) in the working of mines of any sort (whether gold mines, or silver mines, or others, or manufactories);
To make large (sharp) instruments (such as instruments for piercing an elephant's car);
Cutting trees, shrubs, creepers, long climbing plants (such as vines), or herbs;
Living by (prostituting) one's own wife;
Trying to overcome another by incantations (tending to kill him), or by forcible means;
Performing the act (of cooking) for one's own sole benefit;
Not to have kindled one's own sacred fire;
Omitting to pay one's debts to the gods, Rishis, and manes (or sacrificing, study of the Veda, and propagation of one's race);
Studying irreligious books;
Atheism;
Intercourse with women who drink spirits;
Thus have the crimes in the fourth degree been enumerated.

column1: upapātakinas tv ete kuryuś cāndrāyaṇaṃ narāḥ / parākaṃ ca tathā kuryur yajeyur gosavena vā //
column2: Such criminals in the fourth degree shall perform the Kândrâyana or Parâka penances, or shall sacrifice a cow (as the case may require).
Causing (bodily) pain to a Brâhmana;
Smelling at things which ought not to be smelt (such as excrements), or at spirituous liquor;
Dishonest dealing; Sexual connection with cattle;
And (sexual connection) with a man (or unnatural intercourse with a woman):
Such are the crimes effecting loss of caste.
He who has knowingly committed one of the acts effecting loss of caste shall perform the Sântapana penance;
he who has done so unawares shall perform the Prâgâpatya penance.
Killing domestic or wild animals are crimes degrading to a mixed caste.

column1: saṃkarīkaraṇaṃ kṛtvā māsam aśnīta yāvakam / kṛcchrātikṛcchram atha vā prāyaścittaṃ tu kārayet //
column2: He who has committed a crime degrading to a mixed caste shall eat barley-gruel for a month (if he has committed it knowingly), or perform the penance Krikkhrâtikrikkhra (if he has committed it unawares).

column1: ninditebhyo ghanādānaṃ vāṇijyaṃ kusīdajīvanam asatyabhāṣaṇaṃ śūdrasevanam ity apātrīkaraṇam //
column2: Receiving anything from a (Mlekkha or other) despicable person (even though not as a present, but in the form of interest, &c.), traffic (even with articles that are not forbidden to sell), subsisting by money-lending (even without exceeding the legitimate rate of interest), telling lies (even though not in giving evidence), and serving a Sûdra (even though without doing servile acts for him) are crimes rendering unworthy to receive alms.

column1: apātrīkaraṇaṃ kṛtvā taptakṛcchreṇa śudhyati / śītakṛcchreṇa vā bhūyo mahāsāṃtapanena vā //
column2: He who has committed a crime rendering unworthy to receive alms, is purified by the penance Taptakrikkhra (in case he committed it knowingly), or by the penance Sîtakrikkhra (in case he did it unawares), or by the penance Mahâsântapana (in case it was committed) repeatedly.
Killing birds, amphibious animals, and aquatic animals (such as fish);
And worms or insects;
Eating (nutmegs or other) plants similar to intoxicating drinks (in their effect upon the system):
Such are the crimes causing defilement.

The penance ordained for crimes causing defilement is the Taptakrikkhra penance (if they were committed unintentionally), or they shall be atoned for by the Krikkhrâtikrikkhra penance (if they were committed intentionally).
Miscellaneous crimes are those which have not been mentioned before.

Having committed one out of the number of miscellaneous crimes, a prudent man should always perform a penance, by the advice of a Brâhmana, after the higher or less degree of his guilt has been ascertained.
Now follow the hells. (They are called:)
Tâmisra (darkness);
Andhatâmisra (complete darkness);
Raurava (place of howling);
Mahâraurava (place of much howling);
Kâlasûtra (thread of time or death);
Mahânaraka (great hell);
Sañgîvana (restoring to life);
Avîki (waveless);
Sampratâpana (parching);
Samghâtaka, (pressing together)
Kâkola (ravens);
, Kudmala (bud);
Pûtimrittika (stinking clay);
Lohasankti (iron-spiked);
Rikîsha (frying-pan);
Vishamapanthâna (rough or uneven roads);
Kantakasâlmali (thorny Sâlmali trees);
Dîpanadî (flame river);
Asipattravana (sword-leaved forest);
Lohakâraka (iron fetters);

column1: eteṣv akṛtaprāyaścittā atipātakinaḥ paryāyeṇa kalpaṃ pacyante //
