column2: In each of those (hells) successively criminals in the highest degree, who have not performed the penance (prescribed for their crime), are tormented for the time of a Kalpa.
Mortal sinners (who have not done penance) for a Manvantara;
Minor offenders, for the same period;
Criminals in the fourth degree, for the period of a Katuryuga;
Those who have committed a crime effecting loss of caste, for a thousand years;
Those who have committed a crime degrading to a mixed caste, for the same period;
Those likewise who have committed a crime rendering unworthy to receive alms and the like.
And those who have committed a crime causing defilement;
Those who have committed one of the miscellaneous crimes, for a great number of years;

column1: kṛtapātakinaḥ pāpāḥ prāṇatyāgād anantaram / yāmyaṃ panthānam āsādya duḥkham aśnanti dāruṇam //
column2: All sinners who have committed (one of those nine kinds of) crimes have to suffer terrible pangs, when they have departed life and entered upon the path of Yama.

column1: yamasya puruṣair ghoraiḥ kṛṣyamāṇā yatas tataḥ / sakṛcchreṇānukāreṇa nīyamānāś ca te yathā //
column2: Being dragged hither and thither (upon even and uneven roads), by the dire ministers of Yama, they are conducted (to hell by them), with menacing

column1: śvabhiḥ śṛgālaiḥ kravyādaiḥ kākakaṅkabakādibhiḥ / agnituṇḍair bhakṣyamāṇā bhujaṅgair vṛścikais tathā //
column2: (There) they are devoured by dogs and jackals, by hawks, crows, herons, cranes, and other (carnivorous animals), by (bears and other) animals having fire in their mouth, and by serpents and scorpions.

column1: agninā dahyamānāś ca tudyamānāś ca kaṇṭakaiḥ / krakacaiḥ pāṭyamānāś ca pīḍyamānāś ca tṛṣṇayā //
column2: They are scorched by blazing fire, pierced by thorns, divided into parts by saws, and tormented by thirst.

column1: kṣudhayā vyathamānāś ca ghorair vyāghragaṇais tathā / pūyaśoṇitagandhena mūrchamānāḥ pade pade //
column2: They are agitated by hunger and by fearful troops of tigers, and faint away. at every step on account of the foul stenches proceeding from pus and from blood.

column1: parānnapānaṃ lipsantas tādyamānāś ca kiṃkaraiḥ / kākakaṅkabakādīnāṃ bhīmānāṃ sadṛśānanaiḥ //
column2: Casting wistful glances upon the food and drink of others, they receive blows from ministers (of Yama), whose faces are similar to those of crows, herons, cranes, and other horrid animals.

column1: kvacit tailena kvāthyante tāḍyante musalaiḥ kvacit / āyasīṣu ca vaṭyante śilāsu ca tathā kvacit //
column2: Here they are boiled in oil, and there pounded with pestles, or ground in iron or stone vessels.

column1: kvacid vāntam athāśnanti kvacit pūyam asṛk kvacit / kvacid viṣṭhāṃ kvacin māṃsaṃ pūyagandhi sudāruṇam //
column2: In one place they (are made to) eat what has been vomited, or pus, or blood, or excrements, and in another place, meat of a hideous kind, smelling like pus.

column1: andhakāreṣu tiṣṭhanti dāruṇeṣu tathā kvacit / krimibhir bhakṣyamāṇāś ca vahnituṇḍaiḥ sudāruṇaiḥ //
column2: Here, enveloped in terrible darkness, they are devoured by worms and (jackals and other) horrible animals having flames in their mouth.
There again they are tormented by frost, or have to step through unclean things (such as excrements), or the departed spirits eat one another, driven to distraction (by hunger).

column1: kvacid bhūtena tāḍyante lambamānās tathā kvacit /
column2: In one place they are beaten with their deeds in a former existence, in another they are suspended (by trees and the like, with a rope), or shot with heaps of arrows, or cut in pieces.

column1: kvacit kṣipyanti bānaughair utkṛtyante tathā kvacit // kaṇṭeṣu dattapādāś ca bhujaṅgābhogaveṣṭitāḥ /
column2: In another place again, walking upon thorns, and their bodies being encircled by snakes, they are tormented with (grinding) machines, and dragged on by their knees.
Their backs, heads, and shoulders are fractured, the necks of these poor beings are not stouter than a needle, and their bodies, of a size fit for a hut only, are unable to bear torments.

column1: kūṭāgārapramāṇaiś ca śarīrair yātanākṣamaiḥ // evaṃ pātakinaḥ pāpam anubhūya suduḥkhitāḥ /
column2: Having thus been tormented (in the hells) and suffered most acute pain, the sinners have toendure further pangs in their migration through animal bodies.

column1: atha pāpātmanāṃ narakeṣv anubhūtaduḥkhānāṃ tiryagyonayo bhavanti //
column2: Now after having suffered the torments inflicted in the hells, the evil-doers pass into animal bodies.
Criminals in the highest degree enter the bodies of all plants successively.
Mortal sinners enter the bodies of worms or insects.
Minor offenders enter the bodies of birds.
Criminals in the fourth degree enter the bodies of aquatic animals.
Those who have committed a crime degrading to a mixed caste, enter the bodies of deer.
Those who have committed a crime rendering them unworthy to receive alms, enter the bodies of cattle.
Those who have committed a crime causing defilement, enter the bodies of (low-caste) men (such as Kandâlas), who may not be touched.
Those who have committed one of the miscellaneous crimes, enter the bodies of miscellaneous wild carnivorous animals (such as tigers).
One who has eaten the food of one whose food may not be eaten, or forbidden food, becomes a worm or insect.
A thief (of other property than gold), becomes a falcon.
One who has stolen grain, becomes a rat.
One who has stolen white copper, becomes a Hamsa.
One who has stolen water, becomes a waterfowl.
One who has stolen honey, becomes a gad-fly.
One who has stolen milk, becomes a crow.
One who has stolen juice (of the sugar-cane or other plants), becomes a dog.
One who has stolen clarified butter, becomes an ichneumon.
One who has stolen meat, becomes a vulture.
One who has stolen fat, becomes a cormorant.
One who has stolen oil, becomes a cockroach.
One who has stolen salt, becomes a cricket.
One who has stolen sour milk, becomes a crane.
One who has stolen silk, becomes a partridge.
One who has stolen linen, becomes a frog.
One who has stolen cotton cloth, becomes a curlew.
One who has stolen a cow, becomes an iguana.
One who has stolen sugar, becomes a Vâlguda.
One who has stolen perfumes, becomes a musk-rat.
One who has stolen vegetables, consisting of leaves, becomes a peacock.
One who has stolen prepared grain, becomes a (boar called) Svâvidh (or Sedhâ).
One who has stolen undressed grain, becomes a porcupine.
One who has stolen fire, becomes a crane.
One who has stolen household utensils, becomes a wasp (usually called Karata).
One who has stolen an elephant, becomes a tortoise.
One who has stolen a horse, becomes a tiger
One who has stolen fruits or blossoms, becomes an ape.
One who has stolen a woman, becomes a bear.
One who has stolen a vehicle, becomes a camel.
One who has stolen cattle, becomes a vulture.

column1: yad vā tad vā paradravyam apahṛtya balān naraḥ /
column2: He who has taken by force any property belonging to another, or eaten food not first presented to the gods (at the Vaisvadeva offering), inevitably enters the body of some beast

column1: striyo 'py etena kalpena hṛtvā doṣam avāpnuyuḥ / eteṣām eva jantūnāṃ bhāryātvam upayānti tāḥ //
column2: Women, who have committed similar thefts, receive the same ignominious punishment: they become females to those male animals.

column1: narakābhibhūtaduḥkhānāṃ tiryaktvam uttīrṇānāṃ mānuṣyeṣu lakṣaṇāni bhavanti //
column2: Now after having undergone the torments inflicted in the hells, and having passed through the animal bodies, the sinners are born as human beings with (the following) marks (indicating their crime):
A criminal in the highest degree shall have leprosy;
A killer of a Brâhmana, pulmonary consumption;
A drinker of spirits, black teeth;
A stealer of gold (belonging to a Brâhmana), deformed nails;
A violator of his spiritual teacher's bed, a disease of the skin;
A calumniator, a stinking nose;
A malignant informer, stinking breath;
A stealer of grain, a limb too little;
One who steals by mixing (i. e. by taking good grain and replacing the same amount of bad grain in its stead), a limb too much;
A stealer of food, dyspepsia;
A stealer of words, dumbness;
A stealer of clothes, white leprosy;
A stealer of horses, lameness;
One who pronounces an execration against a god or a Brâhmana, dumbness;
A poisoner, a stammering tongue;
An incendiary, madness;
One disobedient to a Guru (father), the falling sickness;
The killer of a cow, blindness;
The stealer of a lamp, the same;
One who has extinguished a lamp, blindness with one eye;
A seller of tin, chowries, or lead, is born a dyer of cloth;
A seller of (horses or other) animals whose foot is not cloven, is born a hunter;
A thief (of other property than gold), is born a bard;
A usurer becomes epileptic;
One who eats dainties alone, shall have rheumatics;
The breaker of a convention, a bald head;
The breaker of a vow of chastity, swelled legs;
One who deprives another of his subsistence, shall be poor;
One who injures another (without provocation), shall have an incurable illness.

column1: evaṃ karmaviśeṣeṇa jāyante lakṣaṇānvitāḥ / rogānvitās tathāndhāś ca kubjakhañjaikalocanāḥ //
column2: Thus, according to their particular acts, are men born, marked by evil signs, sick, blind, humpbacked, halting, one-eyed;

column1: vāmanā badhirā mūkā durbalāś ca tathāpare / tasmāt sarvaprayatnena prāyaścittaṃ samācaret //
column2: Others as dwarfs, or deaf, or dumb, feeble-bodied (eunuchs, whitlows, and others). Therefore must penances be performed by all means.
Now follow the penances.
Let a man fast for three days;
And let him perform each day the three ablutions (at dawn, noon, and sunset);
And let him, at every ablution, plunge into the water three times;
And let him mutter the Aghamarshana three times, after having plunged into the water;
During day-time let him be standing;
At night let him continue in a sitting position;
At the close of the ceremony let him give a milch cow (to a Brâhmana).
Thus has the penance Aghamarshana been described.

column1: tryahaṃ sāyaṃ tryahaṃ prātas tryaham ayācitam aśnīyāt /
column2: Let a man for three days eat in the evening only; for other three days, in the morning only; for further three days, food (given to him) unsolicited;
(and let him fast entirely for three days): that is the Prâgâpatya (the penance invented by Pragâpati).

column1: tryaham uṣṇāḥ pibed apas tryaham uṣṇaṃ ghṛtaṃ tryaham uṣṇaṃ payas tryahaṃ ca nāśnīyād eṣa taptakṛcchraḥ //
column2: Let him drink for three days hot water; for other three days, hot clarified butter; and for further three days, hot milk;
Taking the same (liquids) cold is called the Sîtakrikkhra (cold penance).
The Krikkhrâtikrikkhra (the most difficult penance) consists in subsisting on milk only for twenty-one days.
Eating (nothing but) ground barley mixed with water for a whole month is called the Udakakrikkhra (water penance).
Eating nothing but lotus-fibres (for a whole month) is called the Mûlakrikkhra (root penance).
Eating nothing but Bèl fruit (for a whole month) is called the Srîphalakrikkhra (Bèl fruit penance).
Or (this penance is performed) by (eating) lotus-seeds.
A total fast for twelve days is called Parâka.

column1: gomūtraṃ gomayaṃ kṣīraṃ dadhi sarpiḥ kuśodakāny ekadivasam aśnīyāt /
column2: Subsisting for one day on the urine and fæces of a cow, milk, sour milk, butter, and waterin which Kusa grass has been boiled, and fasting the next day, is called Sântapana (the tormenting penance).

column1: etat sāṃtapanam // gomūtrādibhiḥ pratyaham abhyastair mahāsāṃtapanam //
column2: Swallowing (the same six things, viz.) cow-urine and the rest, each for one day, is called Mahâsântapana (the particularly tormenting penance).
Swallowing each for three days is called Atisântapana (the extremely tormenting penance).

Swallowing oil-cakes, foam of boiled rice, buttermilk, water, and ground barley (each for one day), with a fasting day between (every, two days), is called Tulâpurusha (a man's weight). Drinking water boiled with Kusa grass, leaves of the Palâsa and Udumbara trees, of lotuses, of the Sankhapushpî plant, of the banyan tree, and of the Brahmasuvarkalâ plant, each (for one day), is called Parnakrikkhra (leaves penance).

column1: strīśūdrapatitānāṃ ca varjayec cātibhāṣaṇam / pavitrāṇi japen nityaṃ juhuyāc caiva śaktitaḥ //
column2: And let him (while engaged in performing them) avoid to converse with women, Sûdras, or outcasts, and let him constantly, to the best of his ability, mutter purifying Mantras and make oblations in the fire.
Now follows the Kândrâyana (lunar penance).
Let a man eat single mouthfuls (of food) unchanged in size;
And let him during the moon's increase add (successively) one mouthful (every day, so as to eat one mouthful on the first day of the moon's increase, two mouthfuls on the second day, and so on;

fifteen mouthfuls on the day of full moon), and during the wane of the moon let him take off one mouthful (every day, so as to eat fourteen mouthfuls on the first day of the moon's wane, thirteen mouthfuls on the second, and one mouthful on the fourteenth day of the moon's wane), and on the day of new moon let him fast entirely: thus has the barley-shaped Kândrâyana been described.
That Kândrâyana is called 'ant-shaped' in which the day of new moon is placed in the middle.
That one is, called 'barley-shaped' in which the day of full moon is placed in the middle.

column1: aṣṭau grāsān pratidivasaṃ māsam aśnīyāt sa yaticāndrāyaṇaḥ //
column2: If a man eats for a month eight mouthfuls a day, it is (the penance called) Yatikândrâyana (an hermit's Kândrâyana).

column1: sāyaṃ prātaś caturaś caturaḥ sa śiśucāndrāyaṇaḥ //
column2: Eating (for a month) four mouthfuls each morning and evening is (the penance called) Sîsukândrâyana (a child's Kândrâyana).

column1: yathā kathaṃcit ṣaṣṭyonāṃ triśatīṃ māsenāśnīyāt sa sāmānyacāndrāyaṇaḥ //
column2: Eating anyhow three hundred minus sixty mouthfuls a month is the penance called Sâmânyakândrâyâna (general Kândrâyana).

column1: vratam etat purā bhūmi kṛtvā saptarṣayo 'malāḥ / prāptavantaḥ paraṃ sthānaṃ brahmā rudras tathaiva ca //
column2: After having performed this penance, in a former age, the seven holy Rishis, Brahman, and Rudra acquired a splendid abode, O Earth.

column1: atha karmabhir ātmakṛtair gurum ātmānaṃ manyetātmārthe prasṛtiyāvakaṃ śrapayet //
column2: Now if a man feels his conscience charged with some guilty act (such as performing a sacrifice for, or accepting a gift from, unworthy persons, or eating excrements) committed by himself (or if his conscience tells him that he has done more evil than good, or if he thinks himself less pure than others), let him boil a handful of barley-gruel for the sake of his own spiritual welfare.
Let him not make the (customary) Vaisvadeva offering after that.
Neither must he make the Bali offerings.
Let him consecrate with Mantras the barley, before it has been put to the fire, while it is being boiled, and after it has been boiled.
Let him watch the barley, while it is being boiled (muttering at the same time the following Mantra):

column1: śyeno gṛdhrāṇāṃ svadhitir vanānāṃ somaḥ pavitram atyeti rebhan //
column2: 'Soma, who is the highest priest among priests (gods), leader among the wise, Rishi among bards, the falcon among rapacious birds, the Svadhiti tree among trees, trickles murmuring through the filter.'With these words he must fasten blades of Kusa grass (round the neck of the kettle).

column1: śṛtaṃ ca tam aśnīyāt pātre niṣicya //
column2: The pulse having been boiled, he must pour it into another vessel and eat it.

column1: ye devā manojātā monojuṣaḥ sudakṣā dakṣapitaras te naḥ pāntu te no 'vantu tebhyo namas tebhyaḥ svāhety ātmani juhuyāt // athācānto nābhim ālabheta //
column2: Let him help himself to it, while muttering the Mantra, 'The gods, who have sprung up in the mind and satisfy the mind, who are gifted with great energy, and whose father is Daksha, shall protect and help us. To them be Namah (adoration), to them be Svâhâ (hail).'

column1: snātāḥ pītā bhavata yūyam āpo 'smākam udare yavāḥ,
column2: 'Be satisfied in our stomach, O ye waters, and ye barley-corns, after having been bathed;

column1: tā asmabhyam anamīvā ayakṣmā anāgasaḥ santu devīr amṛtāṃ ṛtāvṛdha iti //
column2: they shall be salubrious to us, conferring bliss, causing health, divine, causing immortality, and increasers of Rita (truth and justice).'
One desirous of wisdom (must perform this rite) for three days;
A sinner, for six days.
Any of the mortal sinners (killers of a Brâhmana, stealers of gold, and the rest) becomes purified by swallowing it for seven days.
Swallowing it for twelve nights effaces even sins committed by an ancestor;
Swallowing it for a month, every sin (whether light or heavy, and whether committed by himself or by an ancestor).
And so does swallowing barley-corns dissolved in the excrements of a cow for twenty-one days (efface every sin).
'Thou art barley, thou the king of grains,thou water mixed with honey;
the Rishis have proclaimed thee an expeller of every kind of guilt and an instrument of purification.

column1: ghṛtaṃ yavā madhu yavā āpo vā amṛtaṃ yavāḥ /
column2: 'You are clarified butter and honey, O ye barley-corns;

column1: sarve punīta me pāpaṃ yan me kiṃcana duṣkṛtam //
column2: you are water and ambrosia, O ye barley-corns. May you efface whatever sinful acts I have committed:

column1: vācā kṛtaṃ karmakṛtaṃ manasā durvicintitam / alakṣmīṃ kālakarṇīṃ ca nāśayadhvaṃ yavā mama //
column2: 'Sins committed by words, by acts, and by evil thoughts. Avert distress and ill-fortune from me, O ye barley-corns.

column1: śvasūkarāvalīḍhaṃ ca ucchiṣṭopahataṃ ca yat / mātāpitror aśuśrūṣāṃ tat punīdhvaṃ yavā mama //
column2: 'Purify food licked at by dogs or pigs, or defiled by leavings (of food), and (purify me from the stain) of disobedience towards mother and father, O ye barley-corns.

column1: gaṇānnaṃ gaṇikānnaṃ ca śūdrānnaṃ śrāddhasūtakam / caurasyānnaṃ navaśrāddhaṃ punīdhvaṃ ca yavā mama //
column2: 'Purify for me food given by a multitude of persons, the food of a harlot, or of a Sûdra, food offered at a Srâddha, food rendered impure by the birth of a child in the house, the food of a thief, and food offered at a Navasrâddha (or new Srâddha, which takes place on the first, third, fifth, seventh, ninth, and eleventh day after a person's demise).

column1: bāladhūrtam adharmaṃ ca rājadvārakṛtaṃ ca yat / suvarṇastainyam avrātyam ayājyasya ca yājanam / brāhmaṇānāṃ parīvādaṃ punīdhvaṃ ca yavā mama //
column2: 'Purify me, O ye barley-corns, from the sin of injuring a child or of causing (a punishment) to be inflicted on some one by the king, from theft of gold (or other high crimes), from the violation of a religious duty, from performing a sacrifice for an unworthy person, and from abusing a Brâhmana.'

column1: mārgaśīrṣaśuklaikādaśyām upoṣito dvādaśyāṃ bhagavantaṃ śrīvāsudevam arcayet //
column2: After having fasted during the eleventh day of the bright half of the month Mârgasîrsha, let aman worship, on the twelfth day, the venerable Vâsudeva (Vishnu).
(He shall worship him) with flowers, incense, unguents, lamps, eatables (such as milk), and repasts given to Brâhmanas.

column1: vratam etat saṃvatsaraṃ kṛtvā pāpebhyaḥ pūto bhavati //
column2: By performing this rite (on the twelfth day of the bright half of every month, from the month Mârgasîrsha to the month Kârttika) for one year, he is purified from every sin.
By performing it till he dies, he attains Svetadvîpa ('the white island,' the abode of Bhagavat).
By performing it for a year on each twelfth day of both halves of a month, he attains heaven.
By performing it (within the same intervals), till he dies, (he attains) the world of Vishnu.
The same (heavenly rewards are gained by him who performs this rite) on each fifteenth day (after having fasted during the fourteenth).

column1: brahmabhūtam amāvāsyāṃ paurṇamāsyāṃ tathaiva ca / yogabhūtaṃ paricaran keśavaṃ mahad āpnuyāt //
column2: If he worships (according to the latter rite) Kesava (Vishnu) who has become one with Brahman, on the day of full moon, and Kesava absorbed in meditation, on the day of new moon, he will obtain a great reward.

column1: dṛśyete sahitau yasyāṃ divi candrabṛhaspatī / paurṇamāsī tu mahatī proktā saṃvatsare tu sā //
column2: If in a year on a day of full moon the moon and the planet Jupiter are seen together in the sky, it is called a great full moon.

column1: tasyāṃ dānopavāsādyam akṣayaṃ parikīrtitam / tathaiva dvādaśī śuklā yā syāc chravaṇasaṃyutā //
column2: Gifts, fasts, and the like are declared to be imperishable on that day. The same is the case if a conjunction with the asterism. Sravanâ falls on the twelfth day of the bright half (of any month).
Let a man make a hut of leaves in a forest and dwell in it;
And let him bathe (and perform his prayers) three times a day;

column1: svakarma cācakṣāṇo grāme grāme bhaikṣyam ācaret //
column2: And let him collect alms, going from one village to another, and proclaiming his own deed;
And let him sleep upon grass:
This is called a Mahâvrata (great observance).

column1: brāhmaṇaṃ hatvā dvādaśasaṃvatsaraṃ kuryāt // yāgasthaṃ kṣatriyaṃ vaiśyaṃ vā //
column2: He who has killed a Brâhmana (unintentionally) must perform it for twelve years. (He who has unintentionally killed) a Kshatriya or a Vaisya engaged in a sacrifice, for the same period.
Likewise, he who has killed (unintentionally) a pregnant woman, or a woman in her courses.
Or a woman who has bathed after temporary uncleanness;
Or a friend.
He who has (unintentionally) killed a king, must perform the Mahâvrata for twice the same number of years (or twenty-four years);
He who has (unintentionally) killed. a Kshatriya (not engaged in a sacrifice, nor a king), for one quarter of that time less (or for nine years);
He who has (unintentionally) killed a Vaisya (not engaged in a sacrifice), for half of that time (or for six years).
He who has (unintentionally) killed a (virtuous) Sûdra, for half of that time again (or for three years).

column1: māsam ekaṃ kṛtavāpano gavām anugamanaṃ kuryāt //
column2: Let a man serve cows for a month, his hair and beard having been shorn.
And let him sit down to rest when they rest;
And let him stand still when they stand still;
And let him give assistance to a cow that has met with an accident (such as getting into a slough, or falling into a pit).
And let him preserve them from (the attacks of lions and tigers and other) dangers.
Let him not seek shelter himself against cold (and hot winds) and similar dangers, without having previously protected the cows against them.
Let him wash himself with cow-urine (three times a day);
And let him subsist upon the (five) productions of a cow:
This is the Govrata (cow rite), which must be performed by him who has (unintentionally) killed a cow (belonging to a Kshatriya).

column1: gajaṃ hatvā pañca nīlavṛṣabhān dadyāt // turagaṃ vāsaḥ //
column2: If a man has killed an elephant (intentionally), he must give five black (nîla) bulls.
If he has killed (unintentionally) a horse, he must give a garment.
The same if he has (intentionally) killed a ram or a goat.
If he has (intentionally) killed a camel, he must give one Krishnala of gold.
If he has (intentionally) killed a dog, he must fast for three days.

column1: hatvā mūṣakamārjāranakulamaṇḍūkaḍuṇḍubhājagarāṇām anyatamam upoṣitaḥ kṛsaraṃ brāhmaṇaṃ bhojayitvā lohadaṇḍaṃ dakṣiṇāṃ dadyāt //
column2: If he has (unintentionally) killed a mouse, or a cat, or an ichneumon, or a frog, or a Dundubha snake, or a large serpent (a boa constrictor), he must fast one day, and on the next day he must give a dish of milk, sesamum, and rice mixed together to a Brâhmana, and give him an iron hoe as his 'fee.'
If he has killed (unintentionally) an iguana, or an owl, or a crow, or a fish, he must fast for three days.
If he has killed (intentionally) a Hamsa, or a crane, or a heron, or a cormorant, or an ape, or a falcon, or the vulture called Bhâsa, or a Brâhmanî duck, he must give a cow to a Brâhmana.
If he has killed a snake, (he must give) an iron spade.
If he has killed emasculated (cattle or birds), (he must give) a load of straw.
If he has killed (intentionally) a boar, (he must give) a Kumbha of clarified butter.
If he has (intentionally) killed a partridge, (he must give) a Drona of sesamum.
If he has (intentionally) killed a parrot, (he must give) a calf two years old.
If he has (intentionally) killed a curlew, (he must give) a calf three years old.
If he has (unintentionally) killed a wild carnivorous animal, he must give a milch cow.
If he has (unintentionally) killed a wild animal not carnivorous, (he must give) a heifer.
If he has (intentionally) killed an animal not mentioned before, he must subsist upon milk for three days.
If he has (unintentionally) killed a bird (not mentioned before), he must eat at night only;
Or (if unable to do so), he must give a silver Mâsha.
If he has (unintentionally) killed an aquatic animal, he must fast (for a day and a night).

column1: asthanvatāṃ tu sattvānāṃ sahasrasya pramāpaṇe / pūrṇe cānasy anasthnāṃ tu śūdrahatyāvrataṃ caret //
column2: If he has killed a thousand (small) animals having bones, or an ox-load of animals that have no bones, he must perform the same penance as for killing a Sûdra.

column1: kiṃcid eva tu viprāya dadyād asthimatāṃ vadhe /
column2: But, if he has killed animals having bones, he must (moreover) give some trifle to a Brâhmana (for each animal which he has killed);
if he has killed boneless animals, he becomes purified by one stopping of the breath.

column1: phaladānāṃ tu vṛkṣāṇāṃ chedane japyam ṛkśatam / gulmavallīlatānāṃ ca puṣpitānāṃ ca vīrudhām //
column2: For cutting (unawares?) trees yielding fruit (such as the bread-fruit or mango trees), shrubs, creeping or climbing plants, or plants yielding blossoms (such as the jasmine tree), he must mutter a Vedic text (the Gâyatrî) a hundred times.

For killing (unintentionally) insects bred in rice or other food, or in (sweets and) the like, or in liquids (such as molasses), or elsewhere (in water and so on), or in flowers or fruits, the penance consists in eating clarified butter.

column1: kṛṣṭajānām oṣadhīnāṃ jātānāṃ ca svayaṃ vane / vṛthālambhe 'nugacched gāṃ dinam ekam payovrataḥ //
column2: If a man has wantonly cut such plants asgrow by cultivation. (such as rice and barley), or such as rise spontaneously in the wood (such as wild rice), he must wait on a cow and subsist upon milk for one day.

column1: surāpaḥ sarvakarmavarjitaḥ kaṇān varṣam aśnīyāt // malānāṃ madyānāṃ cānyatamasya prāśane cāndrāyaṇaṃ kuryāt //
column2: A drinker of spirituous liquor must abstain from all religious rites and subsist on grains separated from the husk for a year.

Likewise, if he has (knowingly) eaten garlic, or onions, or red garlic, or any plant which has a similar flavour (to that of garlic or onions), or the meat of village pigs, of tame cocks (and other tame birds), of apes, and of cows.

column1: sarveṣv eteṣu dvijānāṃ prāyaścittānte bhūyaḥ saṃskāraṃ kuryāt //
column2: In all those cases men belonging to a twice-born caste have to be initiated a second time, after the penance is over.
On their second initiation, the tonsure, the girding with the sacred string, the wearing of the staff, and the begging of alms shall be omitted.
If a man has (unawares) eaten meat of a fivetoed animal, with the exception of the hare, the porcupine, the iguana, the rhinoceros, and the tortoise, he must fast for seven days.

column1: gaṇagaṇikāstenagāyanānnāni bhuktvā saptarātraṃ payasā varteta // takṣakānnaṃ carmakartuś ca //
column2: If he has eaten the food of a multitude of persons, of a harlot, of a thief, or of a singer, he must subsist upon milk for seven days.
And (if he has eaten) the food of a carpenter or of a leather manufacturer;
Or of a dissolute woman, of a hypocrite, of a physician, of a hunter, of a hard-hearted or cruel person, and of one who eats the leavings of food;
Or of a woman who has neither husband nor son, of a goldsmith, of an enemy, or of an outcast:
Or of a malignant informer, of a liar, of one who has transgressed the law, and of one who sells himself, or who sells (molasses or other) liquids and condiments;
Or of a public dancer, of a weaver, of an ungrateful man, or of a dyer of clothes;
Or (the food) of a blacksmith, of a man of the Nishâda tribe (who subsist by fishing), of a stage-player, of a worker in cane, or of a seller of weapons;
Or of a trainer of dogs, of a distiller of spirituous liquor, of an oil manufacturer, or of a washerman;
Or (the food) of a woman in her courses (whether belonging to her, or dressed for her), or of one who lives under one roof with the paramour of his wife;

column1: bhrūṇaghnāvekṣitam udakyāsaṃspṛṣṭaṃ patatriṇāvalīḍhaṃ śunā saṃspṛṣṭaṃ gavāghrātaṃ ca //
column2: Or (food) which has been looked at by the killer of an embryo (of a Brâhmana), or which has been touched by a woman in her courses, or nibbled by a bird, or touched by a dog, or smelt at by a cow;
Or that which has been designedly touched with the foot, or that which has been sneezed at;
Or the food of insane, or wrathful, or sick persons;
Or (food that is given) in a disrespectful manner, or the meat (of animals killed) for no sacred purpose.
After having (unawares) eaten the flesh of any sort of fish, excepting the Pâthîna, Rohita, Râgîva, Simhatunda, and Sakula fishes, he must fast for three days.

column1: āpaḥ surābhāṇḍasthāḥ pītvā saptarātraṃ śaṅkhapuṣpīśṛtaṃ payaḥ pibet //
column2: After having (knowingly) drunk water from a vessel in which spirituous liquor had been kept, he must drink for seven days milk boiled together with the Sankhapushpî plant.
After having (knowingly drunk water) from a vessel in which an intoxicating beverage had been kept, (he must drink the same) for five days.

column1: somapaḥ surāpasyāghrāya gandham udakamagnas trir aghamarṣaṇaṃ japtvā ghṛtaprāśanam ācaret //
column2: A Soma-sacrificer, who has (unawares) smelt the breath of a man who had been drinking spirituous liquor, must plunge into water, (suppress his breath) and mutter the Aghamarshana three times. and eat clarified butter afterwards.
For eating (designedly) the flesh of an ass, of a camel, or of a crow, he must perform the Kândrâyana penance.
Likewise, for eating (knowingly) the flesh of an unknown (beast or bird), meat kept in a slaughterhouse, and dried meat.
For eating (unawares) the flesh of carnivorous beasts;

For (knowingly) eating a sparrow, or (the heron called) Plava, or a Brâhmanî duck, or a Hamsa, or the (wild cock called) Raggudâla, or a Sârasa crane, or a Dâtyûha, or a male or female parrot, or a crane, or a heron, or a cuckoo, or a wagtail, he must fast for three days. Likewise, for eating (unawares the flesh of) animals whose hoof is not cloven (such as horses),or of animals having a double row of teeth (such as the Rohita deer). For eating (unawares) the flesh of any bird, excepting the francoline partridge, the Kâpiñgala, the (quail called) Lâvaka, the peahen, and the peacock, (he must fast) for a day and a night.

column1: tittirikapiñjalalāvakavartikāmayūravarjaṃ sarvapakṣimāṃsāśane cāhorātram // kīṭāśane dinam ekaṃ brahmasuvarcalāṃ pibet //
column2: For eating (knowingly) insects (ants and others), he must drink for one day (water in which the plant) Brahmasuvarkalâ (has been boiled).
For eating (unawares) the flesh of dogs, he must perform the same penance.
For eating (unawares the mushroom called) Khattrâka, or (the mushroom called) Kavaka, he must perform the Sântapana penance.

column1: yavagodhūmapayovikāraṃ snehāktaṃ śuktaṃ khāṇḍavaṃ ca varjayitvā yat paryuṣitaṃ tat prāśyopavaset //
column2: For eating (unawares) stale food, other than a mess prepared with barley (such as cakes), or with wheat (such as, gruel), or with milk (boiled with rice, or mixed with coagulated milk, or otherwise dressed), and dishes sprinkled with fat (such as clarified butter), sour gruel, and sweetmeats, he must fast (for one day).
Likewise, (for eating unawares) the juice flowing from an incision in a tree, (plants raised in) unclean substances (such as excrements and the like), and the red exudation of trees.

(and for eating) rice boiled with sesamum. or with beans, Samyâva, rice boiled in milk with sugar, pastry, Sashkulî (cakes), or food destined forthe gods, if those dishes have not been announced to the gods first;
and (for eating) food destined for burnt-oblations.
And (for tasting the milk of a cow) that has been feeding upon ordures.

column1: amedhyabhujaś ca // dadhivarjaṃ kevalāni ca śuktāni //
column2: And (for tasting) any such food as has turned sour (but not that which is sour by nature, like sorrel), except sour milk (and what is made with it).
A student, who partakes (unawares) of a Srâddha repast, must fast for three days.
And he must remain in water for a whole day (afterwards).
If he eats honey or meat (at any time), he must perform the Prâgâpatya penance.
If any one eats (unawares) the leavings of thefood of a cat, of a crow, of an ichneumon, or of a rat, he must drink water in which the Brahmasuvarkalâ plant has been boiled.

column1: śvocchiṣṭāśane dinam ekam upoṣitaḥ pañcagavyaṃ pibet //
column2: For eating (unawares) what has been left by a dog, he must fast for one day, and drink Pañkagavya (afterwards).
For tasting (knowingly) the excrements of five-toed animals (excepting human excrements), he must (fast) for seven days (and drink Pañkagavya on the eighth).
If one (not a student) eats (unawares) of a Srâddha repast consisting of raw food, he must subsist on milk for seven days.
If a Brâhmana eats what has been left by a Sûdra, (he must also subsist on milk) for seven days.
If he eats what has been left by a Vaisya, (he must subsist upon milk) for five days.
If he eats what has been left by a Kshatriya, (he must subsist upon milk) for three days.
If he eats what has been left by another Brâhmana, (he must subsist upon milk) for one day.
If a Kshatriya eats what has been left by a Sûdra, (he must undergo the same penance) for five days.
If he eats what has been left by a Vaisya, (he must undergo it) for three days;
And so must a Vaisya, if he eats what has been left by a Sûdra.
For (knowingly) eating (undressed) food, which has been left by a Kandâla (or Svapaka or other member of the seven lowest castes), he must fast for three days.
For (unawares) eating dressed food (left by such), the Parâka penance is ordained.

column1: asaṃskṛtān paśūn mantrair nādyād vipraḥ kathaṃcana /
column2: Let no Brâhmana ever eat (the flesh of) beasts which has not been consecrated with Mantras;

column1: mantrais tu saṃskṛtān adyāc chāśvataṃ vidhim āsthitaḥ //
column2: but if it has been consecrated with Mantras, he may eat it, following the eternal rule (laid down in the Veda).

As many hairs as the beast has, which he has slain in this world, for so many days will the killer of a beast for other purposes than a (Srauta or Smârta) sacrifice, suffer terrible pangs in this world and in the next.

column1: yajñārthaṃ paśavaḥ sṛṣṭāḥ svayam eva svayaṃbhuvā /
column2: It is for sacrifices that beasts have been created by the Self-existent (Brahman) himself. Sacrificing causes the whole universe to prosper;

column1: yajño hi bhūtyai sarvasya tasmād yajñe vadho 'vadhaḥ //
column2: therefore is the slaughter (of beasts) for a sacrifice no slaughter.

column1: na tādṛśaṃ bhavaty eno mṛgahantur dhanārthinaḥ / yādṛśaṃ bhavati pretya vṛthā māṃsāni khādataḥ //
column2: The sin of him who kills deer for the sake of gain, is not so great (and visited less heavily) in the world to come, than the sin of him who eats meat which has not been offered to the gods.

column1: oṣadhyaḥ paśavo vṛkṣās tiryañcaḥ pakṣiṇas tathā / yajñārthaṃ nidhanam prāptāḥ prāpnuvanty ucchritīḥ punaḥ //
column2: Plants, cattle, trees, amphibious animals, and birds, which have been destroyed for the purposes of sacrifice, obtain exaltation in another existence (in which they are born as Gandharvas, or other beings of a high rank).

column1: madhuparke ca yajñe ca pitṛdaivatakarmaṇi / atraiva paśavo hiṃsyā nānyatreti kathaṃcana //
column2: When honouring a guest, at a sacrifice, or when worshipping the manes, or the gods, a man may slay cattle, but not otherwise on any account.

column1: yajñārtheṣu paśūn hiṃsan vedatattvārthavid dvijaḥ / ātmānaṃ ca paśūṃś caiva gamayaty uttamāṃ gatim //
column2: That twice-born man who, knowing the exact truth (promulgated) in the Veda, slays cattle for the sacrifices (ordained in the Veda), will convey himself and the cattle (slain by him) to a blissful abode.

column1: gṛhe gurāv araṇye vā nivasann ātmavān dvijaḥ / nāvedavihitāṃ hiṃsām āpady api samācaret // yā vedavihitā hiṃsā niyatāsmiṃś carācare /
column2: A self-controlled man of a twice-born caste, whether he be a householder, or be dwelling with his spiritual teacher, or in the forest, must never slay an animal in opposition to the precepts of the Veda, even in cases of distress.

column1: ahiṃsām eva tāṃ vidyād vedād dharmo hi nirbabhau //
column2: because it is from the Veda that law shines forth.

column1: yo 'hiṃsakāni bhūtāni hinasty ātmasukhecchayā / sa jīvaṃś ca mṛtaś caiva na kvacit sukham edhate //
column2: He who hurts animals that do not hurt any one, merely in order to afford pleasure to himself, will never obtain happiness, whether living or dead.

column1: yo bandhanavadhakleśān prāṇināṃ na cikīrṣati / sa sarvasya hitaprepsuḥ sukham atyantam aśnute //
column2: He who gives no living creature intentionally the pain of confining or killing (or hurting) it, from benevolence towards all (creatures), will enjoy everlasting happiness.

column1: yad dhyāyati yat kurute ratiṃ badhnāti yatra ca / tad evāpnoty ayatnena yo hinasti na kiṃcana //
column2: Whatever he thinks of, whatever he strives for, and whatever he desires in his heart, all that is easily obtained by him who does not injure any created being.

column1: nākṛtvā prāṇināṃ hiṃsāṃ māṃsam utpadyate kvacit / na ca prāṇivadhaḥ svargyas tasmān māṃsaṃ vivarjayet //
column2: Meat cannot be obtained without injuring ananimal, and the murder of animals excludes the murderer from heaven, therefore must meat be avoided.

column1: samutpattiṃ ca māṃsasya vadhabandhau ca dehinām / prasamīkṣya nivarteta sarvamāṃsasya bhakṣaṇāt //
column2: Reflecting upon the origin of flesh and upon the (sin of) hurting or confining animated creatures, he must abstain from animal food of any kind.

column1: na bhakṣayati yo māṃsaṃ vidhiṃ hitvā piśācavat / sa loke priyatāṃ yāti vyādhibhiś ca na pīḍyate //
column2: He who transgresses not the law and eats not flesh like a Pisâka, is beloved by men and remains free from disease.

column1: anumantā viśasitā nihantā krayavikrayī / saṃskartā copahartā ca khādakaś ceti ghātakāḥ //
column2: He who gives his consent to the killing of an animal, he who cuts it up, he who kills it, the purchaser and the seller, he who prepares it, he who serves it up, and he who eats it, all these are denominated slaughterers of an animal.

column1: svamāṃsaṃ paramāṃsena yo vardhayitum icchati / anabhyarcya pitṝn devān na tato 'nyo 'sty apuṇyakṛt //
column2: There is no greater sinner than he who, without giving their share to the manes and to the gods, wants to increase his own flesh with the flesh of another creature.

column1: varṣe varṣe 'śvamedhena yo yajeta śataṃ samāḥ / māṃsāni ca na khāded yas tayoḥ puṇyaphalaṃ samam //
column2: Those two, he who performs a horse-sacrifice annually for a hundred years and he who does not eat meat, shall both obtain the same recompense for their virtue.

column1: phalamūlāśanair divyair munyannānāṃ ca bhojanaiḥ / na tat phalam avāpnoti yan māṃsaparivarjanāt //
column2: By eating (wild rice or other) sacred fruits or roots, and by living upon such grains as are the food of hermits, a man does not reap so high a reward as by avoiding meat

column1: māṃ sa bhakṣayitāmutra yasya māṃsam ihādmy aham / etan māṃsasya māṃsatvaṃ pravadanti manīṣiṇaḥ //
column2: (An eater of flesh must say within himself), Me he (mâm sa) will eat in the next world, whoseflesh I am tasting here. This, say the learned, is the derivation of the word flesh (mâmsa).
He who has stolen the gold (of a Brâhmana), must bring a club to the king, proclaiming his deed.
Whether the king kills him with it, or dismisses him unhurt, he is purified.
Or (in case he committed the theft unawares), he must perform the Mahâvrata for twelve years.
He who appropriates (knowingly) a deposit, (must perform the same penance.)

column1: dhānyadhanāpahārī ca kṛcchram abdam // manuṣyastrīkūpakṣetravāpīnām apahāre cāndrāyaṇam //
column2: For stealing male or female slaves (not belonging to a Brâhmana, and for seizing) a well or pool (actually containing water), or a field, the Kândrâyana (penance must be performed).
(For stealing) articles of small value (such as tin or lead, not exceeding twenty-five Panas in value), the Sântapana (penance must be performed).
(For stealing) sweetmeats, (rice or other) food,(milk or other) drinks, a bed, a seat, flowers, roots, or fruit, drinking Pañkagavya (is ordained as penance).
(For stealing) grass, firewood, trees, rice in the husk, sugar, clothes, skins, or flesh, the thief must fast for three days.
(For stealing knowingly) precious stones, pearls or coral, copper, silver, iron, or white copper. he must eat grain separated from the husk for twelve days.
For stealing (unawares) cotton, silk, wool or other (stuffs), he must subsist for three days upon milk.
For stealing two-hoofed or one-hoofed animals, he must fast for three days.
For stealing birds, or perfumes, or medicinal herbs, or cords, or basket-work, he must fast for one day.

column1: yad yat parebhyas tv ādadyāt puruṣas tu niraṅkuśaḥ / tena tena vihīnaḥ syād yatra yatrābhijāyate //
column2: Whatever a man takes from others, unchecked (by the dictates of religion), of that will he be bereft in every future birth.

column1: jīvitaṃ dharmakāmau ca dhane yasmāt pratiṣṭhitau / tasmāt sarvaprayatnena dhanahiṃsāṃ vivarjayet //
column2: Because life, religious merit, and pleasure depend upon wealth, therefore let a man take care not to injure the wealth (of others by robbing them) by any means.

column1: prāṇihiṃsāparo yas tu dhanahiṃsāparas tathā / mahad duḥkham avāpnoti dhanahiṃsāparas tayoḥ //
column2: Among those two, he who injures animal life, and be who injures wealth, the one who injures wealth shall incur the heavier penalty.

column1: athāgamyāgamane mahāvratavidhānenābdaṃ cīravāsā vane prājāpatyaṃ kuryāt //
column2: One who has (unawares) had illicit sexual intercourse, must perform the Prâgâpatya penance for a year, according to the rule of the Mahâvrata, clad in a garment of bark, and living in a forest.
The same (penance is ordained) for sexual intercourse with the wife of another man (who belongs to his own caste, but is no Guru of his).
For intercourse with a cow, the Govrata (must be performed).

column1: puṃsy ayonāv ākāśe 'psu divā goyāne ca savāsāḥ snānam ācaret //
column2: For intercourse with a man, for unnatural crimes with a woman, (for wasting his manhood) in the air, (for intercourse with a woman) in water, by day, or in a go-cart, he must bathe dressed in his clothes.
By intercourse (knowingly) with a Kandâla woman, he becomes her equal in caste.
For intercourse unawares with such, he must perform the Kândrâyana twice.
For intercourse (knowingly) with cattle (other) than cows) or with a public prostitute, (he must perform) the Prâgâpatya penance.

column1: sakṛd duṣṭā ca strī yat puruṣasya paradāre tadvrataṃ kuryāt //
column2: A woman who has committed adultery once,must perform that penance which has been prescribed for an adulterer.

column1: yat karoty ekarātreṇa vṛṣalīsevanād dvijaḥ / tad bhaikṣyabhug japan nityaṃ tribhir varṣair vyapohati //
column2: That guilt which a Brâhmana incurs by intercourse with a Kandâla woman one night, he can only remove by subsisting upon alms, and constantly repeating (the Gâyatrî) for three years.

column1: yaḥ pāpātmā yena saha saṃyujyate sa tasyaiva prāyaścittaṃ kuryāt //
column2: If a man associates with one guilty of a crime, he must perform the same penance as he.

column1: mṛtapañcanakhāt kūpād atyantopahatāc codakaṃ pītvā brāhamaṇas trirātram upavaset //
column2: A Brâhmana who has drunk water from a well in which a five-toed animal has perished, or which has been defiled in the highest degree, must fast for three days.
A Kshatriya (must fast) for two days (in the same case).
A Vaisya (must fast) for one day (and one night).
A Sûdra (must fast) for a night only.
And all (the former, but not a Sûdra) must drink Pañkagavya, when their penance has been completed.

column1: pañcagavyaṃ pibec chūdro brāhmaṇas tu surāṃ pibet / ubhau tau narakaṃ yāto mahārauravasaṃjñitam //
column2: If a Sûdra drinks Pañkagavya, or if a Brâhmana drinks spirituous liquor, they both go to the hell called Mahâraurava.

column1: parvānārogyavarjam ṛtāv avagacchan patnīṃ trirātram upavaset //
column2: If a man has not connection with his wife in the natural season, unless it be on the days of the full and new moon, or because she is ill, he must fast for three days.
A false witness must perform the penance ordained for killing a Brâhmana.
He who has (unawares) voided excrements without water (being near), must bathe in his clothes, pronounce the 'great words,' and offer a burnt-oblation.
One who has been surprised asleep by the sun rising or setting, must bathe in his clothes and mutter the Gâyatrî one hundred -and eight times.

column1: śvasṛgālaviḍvarāhakharavānaravāyasapuṃścalībhir daṣṭaḥ sravantīm āsādya ṣoḍaśa prāṇāyāmān kuryāt //
column2: He who has been bitten by a dog, a jackal, a tame pig, an ass, an ape, a crow, or a public prostitute, shall approach a river and (standing in it, shall) stop his breath sixteen times.

column1: nāstiko nāstikavṛttiḥ kṛtaghnaḥ kūṭavyavahārī brāhmaṇavṛttighnaś caite saṃvatsaraṃ bhaikṣyeṇa varteran //
column2: One who forgets the Vedic texts which he has studied, or who forsakes the sacred fires, must subsist upon alms for a year, bathing at the tree Savanas  an ungrateful man, one who buys or sells with false weights, and one who deprives Brâhmanas of their livelihood (by robbing them of a grant made to them by the king or private persons, or by other bad practices), all those persons must subsist upon alms for a year.

column1: parivittiḥ parivettā ca yayā ca parividyate dātā yājakaś ca cāndrāyaṇaṃ kuryāt //
column2: An unmarried elder brother whose younger brother is married, a younger brother married before the elder, an unmarried elder sister whose younger sister is married, the relative who gives such a damsel in marriage, and the priest who officiates at such a marriage, must perform the Kândrâyana.
, He who sells living beings, land, religious merit (obtained by a sacrifice or otherwise), or Soma, must perform the Taptakrikkhra.

He who sells fresh ginger, (edible) plants (such as rice or barley), perfumes, flowers, fruits, roots, skins, canes, (winnowing baskets or fans and the like) made of split bamboo, chaff, potsherds, hair, ashes, bone, cow-milk or curds, oil-cakes, sesamum, or oil, must perform the Prâgâpatya.

He who sells the fruit of the Sleshmâtaka tree, lac, bees-wax, shells, mother-of-pearl, tin, lead, iron, copper, or, (sacrificial) vessels made of the horn of the rhinoceros, must perform the Kândrâyana.
He who sells dyed cloth, tin, preciousstones, perfumes, sugar, honey, liquids or condiments (other than sugar, salt, and the like), or wool, must fast for three days.
He who sells meat, salt, lac, or milk, must perform the Kândrâyana.
And all those persons  must be initiated a second time.

column1: uṣṭreṇa khareṇa vā gatvā nagnaḥ snātvā suptvā bhuktvā prāṇāyāmatrayam kuryāt //
column2: He who has been riding (voluntarily) upon a camel, or upon an ass, and he who has (purposely) bathed, or slept, or eaten, quite naked, must stop his breath three times.

column1: japitvā trīṇi sāvitryāḥ sahasrāṇi samāhitaḥ / māsaṃ goṣṭhe payaḥ pītvā mucyate 'satpratigrahāt //
column2: By muttering attentively the Gâyatrî three thousand times, (by dwelling) upon the pasture of cows, (and) by subsisting on milk for a month, he becomes free from the sin of accepting unlawful presents.

column1: ayājyayājanaṃ kṛtvā pareṣām antyakarma ca / abhicāram ahīnaṃ ca tribhiḥ kṛcchrair vyapohati //
column2: He who has (knowingly) offered a sacrifice for an unworthy person (such as a low-caste person, or an outcast), he who has performed the funeral rites for a stranger, he who has practised magic rites (in order to destroy an enemy), and he who has performed a sacrifice of the kind called Ahîna, (all those persons) may rid themselves of theirsins by performing three Krikkhra (Prâgâpatya) penances.

column1: yeṣāṃ dvijānāṃ sāvitrī nānūcyeta yathāvidhi / tāṃś cārayitvā trīn kṛcchrān yathāvidhy upanāyayet //
column2: Those twice-born men, by whom the Gâyatrî has not been repeated (and the other initiatory ceremonies performed), as the law directs, must be made to perform three (Prâgâpatya) penances and must be initiated according to custom.

column1: prāyaścittaṃ cikīrṣanti vikarmasthās tu ye dvijāḥ / brāhmaṇyāc ca parityaktās teṣām apy etad ādiśet //
column2: Those twice-born men who are anxious to make an atonement for having committed an illegal act, or for having neglected the study of the Veda, must be made to perform the same penance.

column1: yad garhitenārjayanti karmaṇā brāhmaṇā dhanam / tasyotsargeṇa śudhyanti japyena tapasā tathā //
column2: Those Brâhmanas who have acquired property by base acts (such as living by the occupations of a lower caste, or accepting unlawful presents) become free from sin by relinquishing it, and by muttering (Veda texts) and practising austerities.

column1: vedoditānāṃ nityānāṃ karmaṇāṃ samatikrame / snātakavratalope ca prāyaścittam abhojanam //
column2: For omitting one of the regular acts enjoined in the revealed (and traditional) law, and for a breach of the rules laid down for a Snâtaka, a fast is ordained as atonement.
For attacking a Brâhmana (by raising a stick or a weapon against him), the Krikkhra (Prâgâpatya) penance must be performed;
and for fetching blood from him, the Krikkhrâtikrikkhra.

column1: enasvibhir nirṇiktair nārthaṃ kiṃcit samācaret / kṛtanirṇejanāṃś caitān na jugupseta dharmavit //
column2: With sinners, who have not expiated their crime, let a man not transact business of any kind. But a man who knows the law must not blame (or shun) those who have expiated it.

column1: bālaghnāṃś ca kṛtaghnāṃś ca viśuddhān api dharmataḥ / śaraṇāgatahantṝṃś ca strīhantṝṃś ca na saṃvaset //
column2: Let him not, however, live (or have any intercourse) with those who have killed children, or with ungrateful persons, or with those who have slain one come for protection, or a woman, even though such sinners may have obtained their absolution, as directed by the law.

column1: aśītir yasya varṣāṇi bālo vāpy ūnaṣoḍaśaḥ / prāyaścittārdham arhanti striyo rogiṇa eva ca //
column2: (An old man) who has passed his eightieth year, a youth under the age of sixteen, women, and sick persons have only to perform half of every penance.

In order to remove those sins for which no particular mode of expiation has been mentioned, penances must be prescribed, which shall be in accordance with the ability of the offender, and with the heaviness of his offence.
Now follow the penances for secret sins.

column1: sravantīm āsādya snātaḥ pratyahaṃ ṣoḍaśa prāṇāyāmān salakṣaṇān kṛtvaikakālaṃ haviṣyāśī māsena brahmahā pūto bhavati //
column2: The killer of a Brâhmana is purified, if, having approached a river (and bathed in it), he restrains his breath sixteen times, and takes only one meal, consisting of food fit for offerings, each day, for a month.
At the end of this rite he must give a milch cow.
By performing the same rite and by muttering (while standing in the water) the Aghamarshana (instead of stopping his breath), a drinker of spirituous liquor becomes free from sin.
(By performing the same rite and) muttering the Gâyatrî one thousand and ten times (each day), a stealer of gold becomes free from guilt.
One who has connection with a Guru's wife (becomes free from sin) by fasting for three days and muttering the Purushasûkta and (at the same time) offering a burnt-oblation.

column1: yathāśvamedhaḥ kraturāṭ sarvapāpāpanodakaḥ / tathāghamarṣaṇaṃ sūktaṃ sarvapāpāpanodakam //
column2: Even as the horse-sacrifice, the king of sacrifices, removes all sin, the hymn of Aghamarshana likewise removes all sin.
Let a twice-born man stop his breath, in order to rid himself of all sin;
all sins committed by atwice-born man may be removed by repeated Prânâyâmas.

column1: savyāhṛtiṃ sapraṇavāṃ gāyatrīṃ śirasā saha / triḥ paṭhed āyataprāṇaḥ prāṇāyāmaḥ sa ucyate //
column2: It is called a Prânâyâma, if a man, stopping the breath (which comes from the mouth and from the nostrils), recites the Gâyatrî three times, together with the Vyâhritis ('words'), with the sacred syllable Om, and with the (text called) Siras.

column1: akāraṃ cāpy ukāraṃ ca makāraṃ ca prajāpatiḥ / vedatrayān niraduhad bhūr bhuvaḥ svar itīti ca //
column2: The lord of creatures (Brahman) has milked out from the three Vedas the letter A, the letter U, and the letter M (of which the sacred syllable Om is composed), and (the three sacred words) Bhûh, Bhuvah, Svah (earth, the atmosphere, and heaven).

column1: tribhya eva tu vedebhyaḥ pādaṃ pādam adūduhat / tad ity ṛco 'syāḥ sāvitryāḥ parameṣṭhī prajāpatiḥ //
column2: The lord of creatures, the supreme deity, has also milked out from the three Vedas successively the three verses of the sacred stanza which begins with the word 'tad,' and is called Sâvitrî (or Gâyatrî).

column1: etad akṣaram etāṃ ca japan vyāhṛtipūrvikām / saṃdhyayor vedavid vipro vedapuṇyena yujyate //
column2: By muttering, every morning and evening, that syllable and that stanza, preceded by the three 'words,' a Brâhmana will obtain that religious merit which the (study of the) Veda confers, just as if he had actually studied the Veda.

column1: sahasrakṛtvas tv abhyasya bahir etat trikaṃ dvijaḥ / mahato 'py enaso māsāt tvacevāhir vimucyate //
column2: By repeating those three (Om, the 'words,' and the Gâyatrî every day) for a month out of the village, a thousand times, a twice-born man is purified even from a mortal sin, as a snake (is freed) from its withered skin.
Any member of the Brâhmana, Kshatriya, or Vaisya castes, who does not know those three texts,or fails to recite them in the proper season, meets with reproach among the virtuous.

column1: oṃkārapūrvikās tisro mahāvyāhṛtayo 'vyayāḥ / tripadā caiva gāyatrī vijñeyā brāhmaṇo mukham //
column2: The three imperishable 'great words,' preceded by the syllable Om, and the Gâyatrî consisting of three divisions, have to be recognised as the mouth (or beginning) of the Veda.

column1: yo 'dhīte 'hany ahany etāṃ trīṇi varṣāṇy atandritaḥ / sa brahma param abhyeti vāyubhūtaḥ khamūrtimān //
column2: He who repeats that stanza (preceded by the syllable Om and the three 'words') carefully every day for three years, will be absorbed in the highest Brahman after death, move as freely as air, and become as pure as air.

column1: ekākṣaraṃ paraṃ brahma prāṇāyāmāḥ paraṃ tapaḥ /
column2: The monosyllable (Om) is the highest Brahman, the stoppings of the breath are the best of austerities, but nothing is more exalted than the Gâyatrî;

column1: sāvitryās tu paraṃ nānyan maunāt satyaṃ viśiṣyate //
column2: (declaring the) truth is better than silence.

All religious acts ordained in the Veda, (whether) consisting in burnt-oblations or sacrifices (or alms-giving or other pious observances), perish (after the merit obtained by them has been exhausted);

column1: akṣaraṃ tv akṣaraṃ jñeyaṃ brahmā caiva prajāpatiḥ //
column2: but the syllable Om (akshara) must be known to be imperishable (akshara), as it is identical with Brahman, the lord of creatures.
The act of reciting (the syllable Om, the 'words,' and the Gâyatrî) is ten times better than the (Gyotishtoma or other) sacrifices prescribed (by the Veda);

column1: upāṃśuḥ syāc chataguṇaḥ sahasro mānasaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: it is a thousand times better when repeated mentally only.

column1: ye pākayajñāś catvāro vidhiyajñasamanvitāḥ / te sarve japayajñasya kalāṃ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīm //
column2: The four Pâkayagñas (small or domesticofferings), together with the sacrifices prescribed (in the Veda), though all united, are not equal to a sixteenth part of the sacrifice performed by reciting (those sacred prayers).

column1: japyenaiva tu saṃsidhyed brāhmaṇo nātra saṃśayaḥ /
column2: A Brâhmana may beyond doubt obtain final emancipation by solely repeating (those prayers), whether he perform any other religious observance or no;

column1: kuryād anyan na vā kuryān maitro brāhmaṇa ucyate //
column2: one who is benevolent towards all creatures (and does not slay them for sacrifices) is justly, called a Brâhmana (or one united to Brahman).
Now then follow the purifying Mantras from all the Vedas.

column1: yeṣāṃ japyaiś ca homaiś ca dvijātayaḥ pāpebhyaḥ pūyante //
column2: By muttering them, or reciting them at a burnt-oblation, the twice-born are purified from their sins. (They are as follows:)
The Aghamarshana;
The Devakrita;
The Suddhavatîs;
The Taratsamandîya;
The Kûshmândîs;
The Pâvamânîs;
The Durgâsâvitrî;
The Atishangas;
The Padastobhas;
The Vyâhriti Sâmans.;
The Bhârundas;
The Kandrasâman;
Thetwo Sâmans called Purushavrata;
The Ablinga;
The Bârhaspatya;
The Gosûkta;
The Âsvasûkta;
The two Sâmans called Kandrasûkta;
The Satarudriya;
The Atharvasiras;
The Trisuparna;
The Mahâvrata;
The Nârâyanîya;
And the Purushasûkta;;

column1: trīṇy ājyadohāni rathantaraṃ ca agnivrataṃ vāmadevyaṃ bṛhac ca / etāni gītāni punāti jantūn jātismaratvaṃ labhate yadīcchet //
column2: The three Âgyadohas, the Rathantara, the Agnivrata, the Vâmadevya, and the Brihatsâman, properly chanted, purify man from sin;
Now (the following persons) must be avoided:
Vrâtyas (i. e. those for whom the ceremony of initiation has not been performed)
Outcasts;
Descendants within the third degree' of an outcast mother or father, if they (or their outcast ancestors) have not been purified (by a penance).
(As a rule) the food of all such persons must not be eaten, nor gifts be accepted from them,.
He must avoid accepting repeated gifts from those whose presents must not be accepted.
By accepting such gifts, Brâhmanas lose their divine lustre.

column1: dravyāṇāṃ vāvijñāya pratigrahavidhiṃ yaḥ pratigrahaṃ kuryāt sa dātrā saha nimajjati //
column2: And he who, not knowing the law regarding acceptance of gifts, accepts (illicit) gifts, sinks, to hell together with the giver.

column1: pratigrahasamarthaś ca yaḥ pratigrahaṃ varjayet sa dātṛlokam avāpnoti //
column2: He who, being worthy to receive gifts, does not accept them, obtains that world which is destined for the liberal-minded (after death).
Firewood, water, roots, fruits, protection, meat, honey, a bed, a seat, a house, flowers, sourmilk, and vegetables he must not disdain to accept when they are offered to him.

column1: āhūyābhyudyatāṃ bhikṣāṃ purastād anucoditām / grāhyāṃ prajāpatir mene api duṣkṛtakarmaṇaḥ //
column2: Even if an offender (but not a mortal sinner) has beckoned and offered alms to him, which had been brought previously for the purpose, the lord of creatures has declared that they may be accepted from him.

column1: nāśnanti pitaras tasya daśa varṣāṇi pañca ca / na ca havyaṃ vahaty agnir yas tām abhyavamanyate //
column2: Neither will the manes eat (his funeral oblations offered to them) for fifteen years, nor will the fire convey his burnt-offerings (to the gods) if he rejects such alms.

If he wishes to provide for his (parents or other) Gurus or for (his wife or other) such persons as he is bound to maintain, or if he wants to worship the manes or the gods, he may accept gifts from any one;

column1: sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyān na tu tṛpyet svayaṃ tataḥ //
column2: but he must not satisfy himself with them.

column1: eteṣv api ca kāryeṣu samarthas tatpratigrahe / nādadyāt kulaṭāṣaṇḍha- patitebhyas tathā dviṣaḥ // guruṣu tv abhyatīteṣu vinā vā tair gṛhe vasan /
column2: But even in those cases, and though he be worthy to receive presents, let him not accept them from a dissolute woman, from a eunuch, from an outcast, or from an enemy.

column1: ardhikaḥ kulamitraṃ ca dāsagopālanāpitāḥ / ete śūdreṣu bhojyānnā yaś cātmānaṃ nivedayet //
column2: One who ploughs the ground for half the crop (and gives the other half to the king or a private person, who is the owner), a friend of the family, a (house-)slave, a herdsman, a barber, andone who announces himself (with the words 'I am your slave'): the food of all such may be eaten, although they are Sûdras.
The property of householders is of three kinds:
White, mottled, and black.

column1: śuklenārthena yad+aurdhvadehikaṃ karoti tenāsya devatvam āsādayati //
column2: By those obsequies which a man performs with white property, he causes (his departed ancestor) to be born again as a god.
By performing them with mottled property, he causes him to be born as a man.
By performing them with black property, he causes him to be born as an animal.
What has been acquired by the mode of livelihood of their own caste, by members of any caste, is called 'white.'
What has been acquired by the mode of livelihood of a caste by two or more degrees lower than their own, is called 'black.'

column1: kramāgataṃ prītidāyaṃ prāptaṃ ca saha bhāryayā / aviśeṣeṇa sarveṣāṃ dhanaṃ śuklam udāhṛtam //
column2: What has been inherited, friendly gifts, andthe dowry of a wife, that is called white property, for members of any caste indiscriminately.

column1: kṛtopakārād āptaṃ ca śabalaṃ samudāhṛtam // pārśvikadyūtacauryāpta pratirūpakasāhasaiḥ / vyājenopārjitaṃ yac ca tat kṛṣṇaṃ samudāhṛtam //
column2: What has been acquired by servile attendance, by gambling, by thieving, by begging, by deceit (as if a man says that he wants a present for another and takes it himself, or by forging gold or other metals), by robbery, or by fraud (as if a man shows one thing to a purchaser and delivers another to him instead), is called 'black property.'

column1: yathāvidhena dravyeṇa yat kiṃcit kurute naraḥ / tathāvidham avāpnoti sa phalaṃ pretya ceha ca //
column2: Whatever a man may do (in this world) with anything (he has, whether white, mottled, or black property) he will get his reward accordingly;
A householder must perform the Pâkayagñas(small or domestic offerings) in the fire kindled at the time of marriage.
He must offer the Agnihotra (or daily oblations of clarified butter) every morning and evening (in the Tretâ fires).
He must offer burnt-oblations to the gods (in case the Agnihotra cannot be performed).
Let him offer the two Darsapurnamâsas on the days of conjunction and opposition of the sunand moon.
In autumn and summer let him offer the Âgrayana (oblation of first-fruits);
Or when rice and barley are ripening (in winter and spring).
He who has a sufficient supply of food for more than three years (shall perform the Soma-sacrifice).
(He shall perform) the Soma-sacrifice once a year (in spring).
If he has not wealth (sufficient to defray the expenses of the Pasubandha, Soma, Kâturmâsya, and other Srauta sacrifices), he shall perform the Ishti Vaisvânarî.

column1: yajñārthaṃ bhikṣitam avāptam arthaṃ sakalam eva vitaret //
column2: If he has begged articles for a sacrifice (and obtained them), let him employ them all for that purpose (and never for himself).
Every evening and morning let him offer up the Vaisvadeva;
And let him give alms to an Ascetic (afterwards).
For giving alms and showing due honour to the recipient (by pouring water on his hands both before and afterwards) he obtains the same reward as for giving a cow.
If there is no ascetic (or other person worthy to receive alms), he must give a mouthful to cows;
Or he must cast it into fire.

column1: bhukte 'py anne vidyamāne na bhikṣukaṃ pratyācakṣīta //
column2: If there is food in the house, he must not reject a mendicant, (who arrives) after he has taken his meal himself.

column1: kaṇḍanī peṣaṇī cullī udakumbha upaskara iti pañca sūnā gṛhasthasya //
column2: A householder has five places where animals are liable to be destroyed: his wooden mortar, his slab to grind wheat or condiments upon, his fireplace, his water-pot, and his broom.

For the sake of expiating offences committed (by ignorantly destroying life) in those places, he must perform the (five) sacrifices addressed to the Veda, to the gods, to all created beings (or 'to the goblins'), to the manes, and to men.
Privately reciting (and teaching) the Veda is the sacrifice addressed to the Veda.
The regular burnt-oblation (Vaisvadeva) is the sacrifice addressed to the gods.
The Pitritarpana (refreshing the manes with food and water) is the sacrifice addressed to the manes.
The Bali-offering is the sacrifice addressed to all creatures (or 'to the goblins').
The sacrifice addressed to men consists in honouring a guest.

column1: devatātithibhṛtyānāṃ pitṝṇām ātmanaś ca yaḥ / na nirvapati pañcānām ucchvasan na sa jīvati //
column2: He who does not give their share to these five, the gods, his guests, (his wife and children and others,) whom he is bound to maintain, his manes, and himself, is not alive, though he breathes.

column1: brahmacārī yatir bhikṣur jīvanty ete gṛhāśramāt /
column2: These (three), the student, the hermit, and the ascetic, derive their existence from the order of householders;
therefore must a householder not treat them with disdain, when they have arrived (at his house at the proper time for begging alms).

column1: gṛhastha eva yajate gṛhasthas tapyate tapaḥ /
column2: The householder offers sacrifices, the householder practises austerities, the householder distributes gifts;

column1: pradadāti gṛhasthaś ca tasmāc chreṣṭho gṛhāśramī //
column2: therefore is the order of householders, the first of all.

column1: ṛṣayaḥ pitaro devā bhūtāny atithayas tathā /
column2: The Rishis, the manes, the gods, all creatures (dogs, &c.), and guests beg householders for support;
therefore is the order of householders the best of all.

column1: trivargasevāṃ satatānnadānaṃ surārcanaṃ brāhmaṇapūjanaṃ ca / svādhyāyasevāṃ pitṛtarpaṇaṃ ca kṛtvā gṛhī śakrapadaṃ prayāti //
column2: If a householder is intent upon pursuing the three objects of life (virtue, love, and wealth), upon constantly distributing presents of food, upon worshipping the gods, upon honouring the Brâhmanas, upon discharging his duty of privately reciting (and teaching) the Veda, and upon refreshing the manes (with oblations of balls of rice, water, and the like), he will attain the world of Indra.
In (the last watch of the night, which is called)the hour sacred to Brahman, let him rise and void his excrements.

column1: dakṣiṇābhimukho rātrau divā codaṅmukhaḥ saṃdhyayoś ca //
column2: By night (let him void them) facing the south, by day and during either twilight (let him void them) facing the north.
(He must) not (void them) on earth which has not been previously covered (with grass and the like);
Nor on a ploughed field;
Nor in the shade of a tree (fit to be used for sacrifices);
Nor on barren soil;
Nor on a spot abounding in fresh grass;
Nor where there are worms or insects;
Nor in a ditch (or hole, or upon the roots of a tree);
Nor on an ant-hill;
Nor on a path;
Nor on a public road;
Nor in a garden;
Nor on ashes;
Nor on coal;
Nor oncow-dung;
Nor in a fold for cattle;
Nor in the air;
Nor in water;
Nor facing the wind, or fire, or the moon, or the sun, or a woman, or a (father or other) Guru, or a Brâhmana;
Nor without having enveloped his head;

column1: loṣṭeṣṭakāparimṛṣṭagudo gṛhītaśiśnaś cotthāyādbhir mṛdbhiś coddhṛtābhir gandhalepakṣayakaraṃ śaucaṃ kuryāt //
column2: Having cleaned his hindparts with a clod of earth, or with a brick, (or with wood or grass,) and seizing his organ (with his left, after having removed his garment), he must rise and clean himself with water and earth (previously) fetched for the purpose, so as to remove the smell and the filth.

column1: ekā liṅge gude tisras tathaikatra kare daśa / ubhayoḥ sapta dātavyā mṛdas tisras tu pādayoḥ //
column2: The organ must once be cleaned with earth, the hindparts three times, the one hand (the left) ten times, both hands together seven times, and both feet together three times.
Such is the purification ordained for householders; it is double for students treble for hermits;

column1: triguṇaṃ tu vanasthānāṃ yatīnāṃ tu caturguṇam //
column2: and quadruple for ascetics.
A householder must not use Palâsa-wood for cleaning his teeth.
Nor (must he use the twigs of) the Sleshmântaka(or Selu) plant, nor of the soap plant, nor of the Vibhîtaka (or Kalidruma) tree, nor of the Dhava plant, nor of the Dhâmani tree (for that purpose).
Nor (the twigs of) the Bandhûka (or Bandhugîvaka) plant, nor of the Nirgundî shrub, nor of theS
Nor (the twigs of) the Kovidâra (Yugapattraka) Samî, Pîlu (Gudaphala), Pippala (holy fig-tree), Inguda, or Guggula trees;
Nor (the twigs of) the Pâribhâdraka (Sakrapâdapa), or tamarind, or Mokaka, or Semul trees, nor those of the hemp plant;
Nor sweet plants (such as liquorice sticks):
Nor sour plants (such as Âmlikâs);
Nor twigs that have withered on the stem;
Nor perforated (or otherwise faulty) wood;
Nor stinking wood;
Nor smooth wood;
He must not (use the sticks) facing the south or west.
He must use them facing the north or east;

He may use (the twigs of) the banyan or Asana trees, or of the Arka plant, or of the Khadira, or Karañga, or Badara (jujube), or Sal, or Nimb trees, or of the Arimeda, shrub, or of the Apâmârga or Malatî plants, or of the Kakubha or Bèl trees;
Or of the Kashâya tree, or of the Tikta or Katuka plants.

column1: kanīnyagrasamasthaulyaṃ sakūrcaṃ dvādaśāṅgulam / prātarbhūtvā ca yatavāg bhakṣayed dantadhāvanam //
column2: Before sunrise let him silently clean his teeth with a stick, which must be as thick as the top of the little finger, provided with one end that may be chewed (or 'with a brush'), and twelve Angulas long.

column1: prakṣālya bhaṅktvā taj jahyāc chucau deśe prayatnataḥ /
column2: Having washed and used the stick for cleaning the teeth, he must take care to leave it in a clean place;
he must never make use of it on the day of new moon (or on the day of full moon).

column1: atha dvijātīnāṃ kanīnikāmūle prājāpatyaṃ nāma tīrtham //
column2: The part at the root of the little finger of a twice-born man is called the Tîrtha sacred to Pragâpati.
The part at the root of the thumb is called the Tîrtha sacred to Brahman.
The part at the tops of the fingers is called the Tîrtha sacred to the gods.
The part at the root of the forefinger is called the Tîrtha sacred to the manes.

column1: anagnyuṣṇābhir aphenilābhiḥ aśūdraikakarāvarjitābhir akṣārābhir adbhiḥ śucau deśe svāsīno 'ntarjānu prāṅmukhaś codaṅmukho vā tanmanāḥ sumanāś  #
column2: and (let him sip it) in a clean place, duly seated, placing (his right hand) between his knees, facing the east or the north (or, the north-east), attentively regarding the water, and in a cheerful mood.
Let him sip water thrice with the Tîrtha sacredto Brahman (or with the Tîrthas sacred to the gods and to Pragipati respectively).
Let him wipe his lips twice (with the root of his thumb).
Let him touch the cavities (above his navel), his head, and his breast with water.
By water which reaches either their heart, or their throat, or their palate respectively, members of the three twice-born castes are purified each in his turn;

column1: śudhyeran strī ca śūdraś ca sakṛt spṛṣṭābhir antataḥ //
column2: a woman and a Sûdra are purified by water which has once touched their palate.
In order to obtain wealth and for the sake of security he shall apply to a lord.
He must not travel alone;
Nor with wicked companions;
Nor with Sûdras;
Nor with enemies;
Nor too early in the morning;
Nor too late in the evening;
Nor in the twilight;
Nor in too great a hurry;
Nor at night
Nor (let him travel) without cessation with (horses or other) beasts of draught that are quite young, diseased, or (otherwise) afflicted;
Nor with such as are deficient in limb;
Nor with weak ones;
Nor with young bulls;
Nor with untrained animals.

column1: yavasodake vāhanānām adattvā ātmanaḥ kṣuttṛṣṇāpanodanaṃ na kuryāt //
column2: He must not appease his hunger and allay his thirst without having first given grass and water to the animals.
He must not stop at a place where four ways meet;
Nor at night at the root of a tree:
Nor in an empty house;
Nor upon a meadow;
Nor in a stable;
Nor (must he stand) on hair, on the husks of grain, on potsherds, on bones, on ashes, or coal;
Nor on seeds of the cotton plant.
When he passes by a place where four ways meet, let him turn his right side towards it.
And let him do the same in passing by the image of a deity;
And in passing by well-known large trees.

After having seen a fire, or a Brâhmana (with his turban on), or a public prostitute, or a jar filled (with water), or a looking-glass, or an umbrella, or a flag, or a banner, or a Bèl tree, or a lid (or platter), or a palace built in the shape of a certain diagram (or in the form of a quadrangle without a western gate);
Or a fan, or a chowrie, or a horse, or an elephant, or a goat, or a cow (having a calf), or sour milk, or milk, or honey, or white mustard;
Or a lute, or sandal-wood, or a weapon, or fresh cow-dung, or fruit, or a flower, or a fresh pot-herb, or Gorokanâ, or blades of Dûrvâ grass;
Or a turban, or ornaments, or jewels, or gold, or silver, or clothes, or a seat, or a vehicle, or (raw) meat;
Having seen one intoxicated, or insane, deformed, he must or turn back;
(Also, if he has seen) one who has vomited, or one who has been purged, or one who has had his head shorn, or one who wears all his hair tied in one knot, or a dwarf;
Or (if he has seen) one wearing a dress (of a reddish-yellow colour) dyed with Kashâya, or an ascetic, or one smeared (with ashes);
Or (if he has seen) oil, or sugar, or dry cow-dung, or fire-wood, or grass (other than Kusa or Dûrvâ grass), or Palâsa (and other leaves, other than betel leaves), ashes, or coal;
Or (if he has seen) salt, or a eunuch, or (the spirituous liquor called) Âsava, or an impotent man, or cotton cloth, or a rope, or an iron chain for the feet, or a person with dishevelled hair.
(If he sees), while about to begin a journey, a lute, or sandal-wood, or fresh pot-herbs, or a turban, or an Ornament, or an unmarried damsel, he must praise them.

He must not (knowingly) step on (or step over, or stand on) the shade of the image of a deity, of a (learned) Brâhmana, of a spiritual teacher, of a brown (bull or other animal), or of one by whom the initiatory ceremony at a Soma-sacrifice has been performed.
Nor (must he step) on anything spat out or vomited, nor on blood, nor on fæces or urine, nor on water used for ablutions.
He must not step over a rope to which a calf (or a cow) is tied.

column1: pravarṣati na dhāvet // na vṛthā nadīṃ taret //
column2: He must not walk quickly in the rain. He must not cross a river without need;
Nor without having previously offered an oblation of water to the gods and to the manes;
Nor (swimming) with his arms;
Nor in a leaky vessel.
He must not stand on the bank (of a river).
He must not gaze into a pool.
He must not cross it (by swimming through it, or in any other way).

column1: vṛddhabhārinṛpasnāta strīrogivaracakriṇām / panthā deyā nṛpas tv eṣāṃ mānyaḥ snātaś ca bhūpateḥ //
column2: Way must be made for an aged man, for one carrying a burden, for a king, for a Snâtaka (of any of the three kinds), for a woman, for a sick person, for a bridegroom, and for one riding in a carriage. Among those, should they all meet, a king must behonoured by the rest (excepting the Snâtaka);
He must not bathe in another man's pool;

column1: ācaret pañca piṇḍān uddhṛtyāpas tad āpadi //
column2: In cases of distress (if there is no other water at hand) he may bathe (in another man's pool), after having offered up five (or seven, or four) lumps of clay and (three jars with) water.
Nor while he is afflicted (with a fever or other illness);
Nor without his clothes;
Nor at night; Unless it be during an eclipse;
Nor in the twilight.
, He must bathe early in the morning, when he beholds the east reddening with the rays of the (rising) sun.
After having bathed, he must not shake his head (in order to remove the water from his hair);
And he must not dry his limbs (with his hand or with a cloth);
Nor must he touch any oily substance.
He must not put on again the garment which he wore before, without its having been washed.

column1: snāta eva soṣṇīṣe dhaute vāsasī bibhṛyāt //
column2: After having bathed, he must cover with his head a turban and put on two garments washed (by himself).
He must not converse, (after having bathed,) with barbarians, low-caste persons, or outcasts.
He must bathe in cascades, ponds dug by the gods, and lakes. Stagnant water is more pure (and purifies more effectually) than water taken out (of a well or the like);
the water of a spring is more pure than that of a tank;
but the water of the Ganges is the purest of all.

column1: mṛttoyaiḥ kṛtamalāpakaṛṣo 'psu nimajjyopaviśyāpo hi ṣṭheti tisṛbhir hiraṇyavarṇeti catasṛbhir idam āpaḥ pravahateti ca tīrtham abhimantrayet
column2: After having removed the dirt by means of earth and water, and after having dived under water and returned (to the bank of the river), he must address the bathing-place with the three Mantras (beginning with the words), 'Ye waters are,'with the four Mantras (beginning with the words),'The golden-coloured (waters),' and with (the one Mantra beginning with the words), 'Carry away (all), that, O ye waters.'
Then he must dive underwater and mutter the Aghamarshana three times;
Or (he must mutter three times the Mantra which begins with the words), 'That most exalted step of Vishnu;'
Or the Drupadâ Sâvitrî (which begins with the words, 'Like one released from a post);
Or the Anuvâka (which begins with the words), 'They get their minds ready;'
Or the Purushasûkta.

column1: snātaś cārdravāsā devapitṛtarpaṇam ambhaḥstha eva kuryāt //
column2: After having bathed, he must feed the gods and the manes, while standing in the water with his wet clothes on.
If (being unable to remain in water after having bathed) he has changed his dress, (he must feed the gods and the manes,) after having crossed the bathing-place (and reached the bank).
(But) he must not wring his bathing-dress till he has satisfied the gods and the manes.;
After having bathed and sipped water, he must sip water (once more) according to the rule.
He must offer (sixteen) flowers to Purusha,while muttering the Purushasûkta, one with each verse.
Afterwards (he must offer) a libation of water.

column1: ādāv eva daivena tīrthena devānāṃ tarpaṇaṃ kuryāt //
column2: He must first offer one to the gods with the Tîrtha sacred to the gods.
Then he must offer an other to the manes with the Tîrtha sacred to the manes.
In offering the latter he must first of all feed (the manes of) his next of kin (such as his father, mother, maternal grandfather, uncles, brothers, &c.)
After that (he must feed) his relatives (such as a sister's son, a father-in-law, a brother-in-law, &c.) and distant kinsmen (such as the sons of his father's sisters and of his mother's sisters).
Then (he must feed) his (deceased) friends.
According, to the above rule he must bathe every day.
After having bathed, he must mutter as many purifying Mantras as possible.
