And he must mutter the Gâyatrî even more often (than other Mantras);
And the Purushasûkta.
There is nothing more sublime than those two (prayers).

column1: pavitrāṇāṃ tathā japye dāne ca vidhibodhite //
column2: One who has bathed is thereby entitled to perform the offerings to the Visvedevâs and to the manes, to mutter sacred texts, and to exercise the duty of hospitality, as prescribed by law.
Distress and misfortune, bad dreams and evil thoughts are taken from him even who only sprinkles himself with water (no matter from where it comes): that is the law.

column1: athātaḥ susnātaḥ suprakṣālitapāṇipādaḥ svācānto devatārcāyāṃ sthale vā bhagavantam anādinidhanaṃ vāsudevam abhyarcayet //
column2: Now then, after having duly bathed, and duly washed his hands and feet, and duly sipped water, he must worship Bhagavat Vâsudeva (Vishnu), who is without beginning and end, before an idol or on the sacrificial ground.

column1: aśvinoḥ prāṇas tau ta iti jīvādānaṃ dattvā yuñjate mana ity anuvākenāvāhanaṃ kṛtvā jānubhyāṃ pāṇibhyāṃ śirasā ca namaskāraṃ kuryāt //
column2: Having called up in his mind (Vishnu to life, with the Mantra), 'The two Asvins possess life, may they (give you life),'and having invited (Vishnu) with the Anuvâka (beginning with the words), 'They get their minds ready,' he must worship him with his knees, his hands, and his head.

column1: āpo hi ṣṭheti tisṛbhir arghyaṃ nivedayet //
column2: With the three Mantras (beginning with the words), 'Ye waters are,' he must (fetch and) announce the Arghya (or water for washing the hands).
With the four Mantras (beginning with the words), 'The golden-coloured,' (he must fetch and announce) the water for washing the feet;

column1: śaṃ na āpo dhanvanyā ity ācamanīyam //
column2: With (the one Mantra, beginning with the words), 'May the waters of the plain propitiate us,' the water which is to be sipped;
With (the one Mantra, beginning with the words), 'Carry away (all) that, O ye waters,' the water destined for the bath;

column1: rathe akṣeṣu vrṣabhasya vāje ity anulepanālaṃkārau //
column2: With (the four Mantras, beginning with the words, 'Proud) of the chariot, of the poles, the hero,' unguents and ornaments;
With (the one Mantra, beginning with the words), 'A youth, splendidly arrayed,' a garment;
With (the one Mantra, beginning with the word), 'Blooming,' a flower;
With (the one Mantra, beginning with thewords), 'Thou art murderous (dhûr), slay (dhûrva) (the slayer),' incense (dhûpa);
With (the one Mantra, beginning with the words), 'Thou art splendour and light,' a lamp;
With (the one Mantra, beginning with the words, 'I have praised) Dadhikrâvan,' a Madhuparka (honey-mixture);
With the eight Mantras (beginning with the word), 'Hiranyagarbha,' an offering of (other) eatables.

column1: cāmaraṃ vyajanaṃ mātrāṃ chatraṃ yānāsane tathā / sāvitreṇaiva tat sarvaṃ devāya vinivedayet //
column2: A chowrie, a fan, a looking-glass, an umbrella, a (palanquin or other) vehicle, and a (throne or other) seat, all these objects he must announce (and place before) the god (Vishnu), muttering the Gâyatrî (at the same time).

column1: evam abhyarcya tu japet sūktaṃ vai pauruṣaṃ tataḥ / tenaiva cājyaṃ juhuyād yadīcchec chāśvataṃ padam //
column2: After having thus worshipped him, he must mutter the Purushasûkta. After that, he who wishes to obtain eternal bliss must make oblations of clarified butter, while reciting the same hymn.
He must not make an oblation to the gods or to the manes with water collected at night.
He must not give any other fragrant substance than sandal, or musk, or (fragrant) wood (of the odoriferous Devadâru tree), or camphor, or saffron, or the wood of the Gâtîphala tree;
Nor a garment dyed with indigo;
Nor an ornament made of factitious jewels or gold;
Nor (a flower) having a nasty odour;
Nor one grown upon a thorny plant.

column1: kaṇṭakijam api śuklaṃ sugandhikaṃ tu dadyāt //
column2: But he may give even a flower grown upon a thorny plant, if it is white and sweet-smelling.

column1: raktam api kuṅkumaṃ jalajaṃ ca dadyāt //
column2: He may give even a red flower, if it is saffron, or a water-flower (such as the red lotus).
(He must) not (give) any animal substance (such as claws or horns) for the incense.
(He must) not (give) anything but clarified butter or oil for the lamp.
(He must) not (give) forbidden food at the offering of eatables;
Nor the milk of goats or female buffalos, though it is lawful food (otherwise);
Nor the flesh of five-toed animals, of fishes, and of boars.

column1: prayataś ca śucir bhūtvā sarvam eva nivedayet / tanmanāḥ sumanā bhūtvā tvarākrodhavivarjitaḥ //
column2: Fully prepared for the sacrifice and pure, he must announce (and offer up to Vishnu) all the oblations, with his mind fixed upon the deity, with a cheerful heart, and free from precipitation or anger.

column1: athāgniṃ parisamuhya paryukṣya paristīrya pariṣicya sarvataḥ pākād agram uddhṛtya juhuyāt //
column2: After having swept the place around the (kitchen) fire, sprinkled it with water all around,strewed (Kusa grass) all around, and sprinkled (the latter) with water all around, he must take out of all dishes the uppermost part and offer it:

column1: vāsudevāya saṃkarṣaṇāya pradyumnāyāniruddhāya puruṣāya satyāyācyutāya vāsudevāya //
column2: To Vâsudeva, to Sankarshana, to Pradyumna, to Aniruddha, to Purusha, to Satya, to Akyuta, to Vâsudeva.

Afterwards (he must offer twelve burnt-oblations) to Agni, to Soma, to Mitra, to Varuna, to Indra, to Indra and Agni united, to the Visvedevâs, to Pragâpati, to Anumati, to Dhanvantari, to Vâstoshpati, and to Agni Svishtakrit (the god of the fire who causes the proper performance of the sacrifice).
Then let him make a Bali-offering with that which has been left of the dishes.
(Strewing the two Balis) on both sides of the fire, to the east of it (on the north-eastern side first, and on the south-eastern side afterwards).
(Then let him offer other seven Balis) to all (the seven Ishtakâs or goddesses of the bricks of the altar, also to the east of the fire, while pronouncing the Mantras), 'Thy name is Ambâ;
thy name is Dulâ;
thy name is Nitatnî (Nitatnir);
thy name is Kupunîkâ (and so on).'

column1: nandini subhage sumaṅgali bhadraṃkarīti svaśriṣv abhipradakṣiṇam //
column2: (He must offer four Balis with the Mantras), 'O Nandinî; O Subhagâ; O Sumangalî;

column1: sthūṇāyāṃ dhruvāyāṃ śriyai hiraṇyakeśyai vanaspatibhyaś ca //
column2: (He must place two Balis), addressed to Sri Hiranyakesî and to the trees, near the firm pillar.
(He must place two Balis), addressed to Dharma and Adharma and to Mrityu, near the door.
(He must place one Bali), addressed to Varuna, in the water-jar.
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Vishnu,' (he must place one Bali) in the mortar.
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to the Maruts,' (he must place one Bali) on the mill-stone.

column1: upari śaraṇe vaiśravaṇāya rājñe bhūtebhyaś ca //
column2: (In the apartment) on the roof (let him place two Balis) addressed to Vaisrâvana (Kubera) the king, and to all created beings.
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Indra and to Indra's ministers,' (he must place two Balis). in the eastern part (of the house).
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Yama and to Yama's ministers,' (he must place two Balis) in the southern part..
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Varuna and to Varuna's ministers,' (he must place two Balis) in the western part.
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Soma and to Soma's ministers,' (let him place two Balis) in the northern part.
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Brahman and to Brahman's ministers,' (let him place two Balis) in the centre (of the house).
(Let him throw) in the air (a Bali) addressed to Âkâsa (the air).
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to the goblins roaming by day,' (let him place a Bali) on the sacrificial ground.
(With the words, 'Adoration be to the goblins) roaming by night,' (let him offer a Bali in the same place at the Vaisvadeva which takes place) at night.

column1: tato *dakṣiṇāgreṣu darbheṣu pitre pitāmahāya prapitāmahāya mātre pitāmahyai prapitāmahyai nāmagotrābhyāṃ ca piṇḍanirvāpaṇaṃ kuryāt [dakṣiṇagreṣu]
column2: Afterwards he must offer upon blades of Kusa grass, having the points turned towards the south, balls of rice to his father, to his grandfather, and to his great-grandfather, to his mother, to his grandmother, and to his great-grandmother, proclaiming at the same time their name and race (and adding the word Svadhâ, 'reverence').
Along with the balls of rice let him give ointments, flowers, incense, eatables, and the like.
After having fetched a jar with water, let himcause a Brâhmana to say the benediction (and give him the jar).
(The share) of dogs, crows, and Svapakas let him strew upon the earth.
And let him give (a mouthful of food as) alms.
By honouring guests he obtains the highest reward.
Let him assiduously honour a guest who arrives in the evening (after the Vaisvadeva is over).
Let him not suffer a guest to stay at his house unfed.

column1: yathā varṇānāṃ brāhmaṇaḥ prabhur yathā strīṇāṃ bhartā tathā gṛhasthasyātithiḥ //
column2: As the Brâhmanas are lords over all other castes, and as a husband is lord over his wives, a guest is the lord of a householder.
By honouring a guest he obtains heaven.

(One who has arrived as) a guest and is obliged to turn home disappointed in his expectations, takes away from the man, to whose house he has come, his religious merit, and throws his own guilt upon him.

column1: ekarātraṃ hi nivasann atithir brāhmaṇaḥ smṛtaḥ /
column2: A Brâhmana who stays for one night only as a guest, is called atithi (a guest);

column1: anityaṃ hi sthito yasmāt tasmād atithir ucyate //
column2: because he does not stay for a long time, therefore is he termed atithi.

column1: naikagrāmīṇam atithiṃ vipraṃ sāṃgatikaṃ tathā / upasthitaṃ gṛhe vindyād bhāryā yatrāgnayo 'pi vā //
column2: Let him not consider a Brâhmana fellow-villager or an acquaintance as his guest, though he has come to the house where his wife and his fires are.

column1: yadi tv atithidharmeṇa kṣatriyo gṛham āgataḥ / bhuktavatsu ca vipresu kāmaṃ tam api bhojayet //
column2: But if a Kshatriya has come to his house in the way of a guest, let him hospitably entertain him also, to his heart's desire, after the Brâhmana guests have eaten.

column1: vaiśyaśūdrāv api prāptau kuṭumbe 'tithidharmiṇau / bhojayet saha bhṛtyais tāv ānṛśaṃsyaṃ prayojayan //
column2: Should a Vaisya or a Sûdra come to his house as guests, he must even give food to them (at the same time and) with his servants, and treat them with kindness (but not like guests in the proper sense of the term).

column1: itarān api sakhyādīn saṃprītyā gṛham āgatān / prakṛtānnaṃ yathāśakti bhojayet saha bhāryayā //
column2: To (members of) other castes (such as Mûrdhâvasiktas) and to friends (or relatives or) other such persons, who have come to his house out of attachment, let him offer such food as happens to be there, to the best of his power, at the time when his wife takes her meal.

column1: svavāsinīṃ kumārīṃ ca rogiṇīṃ gurviṇīṃ tathā / atithibhyo 'gra evaitān bhojayed avicārayan //
column2: One recently married (but not yet delivered to her husband), an unmarried damsel, a sick woman, and a pregnant woman: to these let him give food unhesitatingly, even before his guests.

column1: adattvā yas tu etebhyaḥ pūrvaṃ bhuṅkte 'vicakṣaṇaḥ / bhuñjāno na sa jānāti śvagṛdhrair jagdhim ātmanaḥ //
column2: The foolish man who eats first himself, without having offered food to those (persons that have been mentioned), is not aware that he will himself be food (after death) for dogs and vultures.

column1: bhuktavatsu ca vipreṣu sveṣu bhṛtyeṣu caiva hi /
column2: After the Brâhmanas, (the Kshatriyas who have come as guests), the friends and relatives, (the parents and others) whom he is bound to maintain,(and the servants) have made their repast, let man and wife eat the leavings themselves.

column1: devān pitṝn manuṣyāṃś ca bhṛtyān gṛhyāś ca devatāḥ / pūjayitvā tataḥ paścād gṛhasthaḥ śeṣabhug bhavet //
column2: Having shown honour to the gods, to the manes, to men, to those whom he is bound to maintain, and to the household deities (as well as to dogs, crows, and the rest), let a householder enjoy that which has been left.

column1: aghaṃ sa kevalaṃ bhuṅkte yaḥ pacaty ātmakāraṇāt / yajñaśiṣṭāśanaṃ hy etat satām annaṃ vidhīyate //
column2: He who cooks food for himself only, cats nothing but sin: for that alone is considered as fit food for the virtuous, which is left, after the (customary) oblations have been offered.

column1: svādhyāyenāgnihotreṇa yajñena tapasā tathā / na cāpnoti gṛhī lokān yathā tv atithipūjanāt //
column2: By the daily recitation of the Veda, by the Agnihotra, by sacrificing, and by austerity, a householder does not obtain such excellent places of abode (after death) as by honouring a guest.

column1: sāyaṃ prātas tv atithaye pradadyād āsanodake / annaṃ caiva yathāśaktyā satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam //
column2: Whether he arrives in the evening or in the morning, he must offer a seat and water to his guest, and food, to the best of his ability, after having shown him marks of honour as the law directs.

column1: pratiśrayaṃ tathā śayyāṃ pādābhyaṅgaṃ sadīpakam / pratyekadānenāpnoti gopradānasamaṃ phalam //
column2: By giving (to a guest) shelter, a bed, ointments for his feet, and a lamp: for each of these gifts singly he reaps the same reward as for the gift of a cow.
He must not eat during an eclipse of the moon or of the sun.
He shall eat, after having previously bathed, when the eclipse is over.

column1: amuktayor astaṃ gatayoḥ snātvā dṛṣṭvā cāpare 'hni //
column2: If (the sun or moon) have set before the eclipse was over, he must bathe, and on the next day he may eat again, after having seen (the sun or moon rise),
A cow or a Brâhmana having met with a calamity, he must not eat on that day.
If the king has met with an accident, (he must not eat on that day).
An Agnihotrin, who is absent on a journey, must eat at that time of the day when the Agnihotra is supposed to be over.
He may also eat at that time of the day when the Vaisvadeva is supposed to be over.

column1: parvaṇi ca yadā kṛtaṃ manyeta parva //
column2: On the days of new and full moon (he may eat at that time) when he supposes the sacrifice customary on those days to have been performed.
He must not eat during an indigestion;
Nor at midnight;
Nor at noon;
Nor in the twilight;
Nor dressed in wet clothes;
Nor without his upper garment;
Nor naked;
Nor in water (nor in a boat)
Nor lying stretched out on the back;
Nor sitting on a broken stool;
Nor reclining on a couch;
Nor from a broken dish;
Nor (having placed the food) upon the ground;
Nor from the palm of his hand.

column1: lavaṇaṃ ca yatra dadyāt tan nāśnīyāt //
column2: That food which has been seasoned with salt (after having been cooked) he must not eat.
He must not abuse children (eating in the same row with him).
(He must) not (eat) dainties alone.
(He must) not (eat) substances from which the fat has been extracted.
, Nor (must he eat) roasted grain in the daytime.
At night (he must not eat) anything mixed with sesamum-seeds.
Nor (must he eat at night) sour milk or ground barley.
Nor (must he eat) the leaves of the mountain ebony, or of the banyan, or of the holy fig-tree, or of the hemp plant.
(He must) not (eat) without having first given to eat (to the gods and to the Brâhmanas); Nor without having made a burnt-offering first
Nor without having sprinkled his feet;
Nor without having sprinkled his hands and his face;
While having the remains of food en his mouth or hands, he must not take clarified butter.
Nor must he look at the moon, or at the sun, or at the stars (while unclean).
Nor must he touch his head (while unclean).
Nor must he recite the Veda (while unclean).
He must eat facing the east;
Or facing the south;
And after having honoured his food;
And cheerfully, adorned with a garland of flowers, and anointed with unguents.
He must not eat up his food completely;
Unless it consist of sour milk, or honey, or (clarified) butter, or milk, or ground barley, or meat, or sweetmeats.

column1: nāśnīyād bhāryayā sārdhaṃ nākāśe na tathotthitaḥ / bahūnāṃ prekṣamāṇānāṃ naikasmin bahavas tathā //
column2: He must not eat together with his wife, nor in the open air, nor standing, nor in the presence of many (hungry spectators), nor must many eat in the presence of one (hungry spectator).

column1: śūnyālaye vahnigṛhe devāgāre kathaṃcana / piben nāñjalinā toyaṃ nātisauhityam ācaret //
column2: Let him never eat in an empty house, in a house where the sacred fires are preserved, or in a temple dedicated to the gods. Neither must he drink water out of his joined hands, or satiate himself to repletion.

column1: na tṛtīyam athāśnīta na cāpathyaṃ kathaṃcana / nātiprage nātisāyaṃ na sāyaṃ prātar āśitaḥ //
column2: , Let him not take a third meal (over and above the two regular meals in the mornings and evenings), nor let him ever take unwholesome food. He must eat neither too early, nor too late, and he must take no food in the evening, after having fully satiated himself in the morning.

column1: na bhāvaduṣṭam aśnīyān na bhāṇḍe bhāvadūṣite / śayānaḥ prauḍhapādaś ca kṛtvā caivāvasakthikām //
column2: He must not eat bad food (whether injurious to health or otherwise reprehensible), nor from a bad dish (which is similar to the dishes used by barbarians, or which has been defiled by a wicked man eating from it), nor lying on the ground, nor with his feet raised upon a bench, nor sitting on his hams with a cloth tied round his legs and knees.
He must not have connection with his wife on the eighth, or fourteenth, or fifteenth day of the half-month.
And (he must avoid connubial intercourse) after having partaken of a Srâddha;
And after having given (a Srâddha);
And after having been invited to a Srâddha;
And in a temple, in a burial-ground, and in an empty house;
And at the root of a tree (or shrub);
And in the day-time;
And in the twilight;
And while he is unclean himself;
And with one sick;
And while he is sick himself,

column1: na hīnāṅgīṃ nādhikāṅgīṃ tathaiva ca vayo 'dhikām / nopeyād gurviṇīṃ nārīṃ dīrgham āyur jijīviṣuḥ //
column2: He must not have connection, if he wishes to enjoy a long life, with a woman who has a limb too little, nor with one who has a limb too much, nor with one older than himself, nor with a pregnant woman.
He must not sleep with his feet wet;
Nor facing the north or the west;
Nor naked;
Nor on wet (fresh) bamboo;
Nor in the open air;
Nor on a bedstead made of Palâsa-wood;
Nor on one made of the wood of five trees;
Nor on one made of the wood of a tree which has been split by an elephant;
Nor on a bedstead made of the wood of a tree that has been kindled by lightning;
Nor on a broken bedstead;
Nor on one made of scorched wood;
Nor on one made of the wood of a tree that used to be watered with a jar;
Nor in a burial-ground, nor in an empty house, nor in a temple;
Nor with people who are restless of limb;
Nor with women;
Nor on grain, nor (in a stable of) cows, nor (on the couch of any of his) Gurus, nor on the fireplace, nor (in a building dedicated to the) gods.

column1: nocchiṣṭo na divā supyāt saṃdhyayor na ca bhasmani / deśe na ca aśucau nārdre na ca parvatamastake //
column2: He must not sleep while the remnants offood are on his hands or face, nor in the day-time, nor in the twilight, nor upon ashes, nor in a place soiled (by excrements and the like), nor in a wet place, nor on the top of a mountain.
Now he must not contemn any one (whether of equal rank, or of higher or lower rank than himself).

column1: na ca hīnādhikāṅgān mūrkhān dhanahīnān avahaset //
column2: He must not mock those who have a limb too little or a limb too much, who are ignorant, or who are poor.
He must not serve low people.
Let him not engage in work that may keep him from repeating (or teaching) the Veda.
Let him wear such a dress as becomes his age,
And his sacred knowledge, his descent, his means, and his country.
He must not be overbearing.
He must constantly consult the holy laws and other (salutary, precepts relating to the acquisition of wealth, wisdom, and freedom from disease).

column1: na nāstīty abhibhāṣeta // na nirgandhogragandhi raktaṃ ca mālyaṃ bibhṛyāt //
column2: He must not wear a garland of flowers which has no smell at all, or an offensive smell, or which is red.
Let him wear a garland of water-flowers even though they be red.
And (he must wear) a staff made of bamboo;
And a jar with water;
And a sacrificial string made of cotton thread;
And two golden ear-rings.
, He must not look at the rising sun;
Nor at the setting (sun);
Nor (must he look at the sun) shining through an awning of cloth (under which he is lying).
Nor at the sun reflected in a looking-glass or in water;
Nor at the midday sun;
, Nor at the face of any of his Gurus while hie is angry;
Nor at his own image reflected in oil or in water;
Nor reflected in a dirty looking-glass;
Nor at his wife eating;

column1: na striyaṃ nagnām // na kaṃcana mehamānam //
column2: Nor at a naked woman;
Nor at an elephant (or other dangerous animal) broken loose from the rope that ties him;

Nor at a fight between bulls (or elephants or buffalos) or the like animals, while he is him self standing in a (crowd or any other) place, from which it would be difficult for him to effect his escape;
Nor at one insane;
Nor at one intoxicated;
He must not throw any impure substances into the fire;
Nor blood;
Nor poison;
Neither (must he throw any of those substances) into water.
He must not step over a fire.
He must not warm his feet (by the fire).
He must not wipe (the dirt from his feet) with blades of Kusa grass.
He must not wash (his feet) in a vessel of white copper.
He must not (wash) one foot with the other,
He must not scratch the ground (with a piece of wood or the like).
He must not crush clods of earth. He must not cut grass.
He must not tear his nails or the hairs (of his beard or others) with his teeth.
He must avoid gambling;
He must not wear a garment, or shoes, or a garland, or a sacrificial string which had before been worn by another.
He must not give advice to a Sûdra;
Nor (must he give him) the leavings of his food, nor the residue of an oblation (unless he is his own servant);
Nor (must he give him) sesamum;
Nor (must he point out) the sacred law to him;
Nor (must he prescribe) a penance (for him for atonement of a sin).

column1: na saṃhatābhyāṃ pāṇibhyāṃ śira udaraṃ ca kaṇḍūyet //
column2: He must not scratch his head or his belly, with both hands joined.
He must not reject sour milk or the Sumanas flower (when offered to him).
He must not take off his garland (from his head) himself (but he may cause another to do so).
Let him not rouse (a superior) from sleep.
He must not (by harsh speeches and the like) render disaffected one who is well affected towards him.
He must not speak to a woman in her courses;
Nor to barbarians or low-caste persons.
When a sacred fire, or an idol, or a Brâhmana is near, he must stretch forth his right hand (from his upper garment).
If he sees a cow trespassing upon another man's field, he must not announce it (to the owner of that field).
And if he sees a calf sucking (at the udder of a cow, he must not announce it to the owner of the latter).
He must not endeavour to please overbearing men (by flattering their pretensions).
He must not dwell in a kingdom governed by a Sûdra king;
Nor in one abounding with wicked people;
And he must not live (in a kingdom) in which there are no physicians;
Nor in one afflicted (with a disease or other calamity).
And (he must not stay) long on a mountain.
He must not (walk or otherwise) exert himself without a purpose.
He must not dance or sing.
He must not make a noise by slapping (his left arm, after having placed it upon his right shoulder, with his right hand).
He must not make vulgar speeches.
He must not tell an untruth.
He must not say disagreeable things.
He must not strike any one upon a vital part.
He must not despise himself if he wishes to enjoy long life.
He must often repeat his prayers at each twilight (if he wishes to live long).
He must not play with (venomous) serpents or with weapons.
He must not touch the cavities of his body without a cause.
He must not raise a stick against another man.
One who deserves punishment he must strike in order to punish him.
(He must strike) him upon his back with a shoot of bamboo or with a rope.
He must take care not to revile a god, a Brâhmana, the Sâstras, or the high-minded (Rishis).
And (he must avoid) gain and pleasure repugnant to duty.
(He must avoid) even lawful acts which may give offence to mankind.
On the days of new and full moon let him make a propitiatory offering.
He must not cut even grass (on those two days).
He must adorn himself (with garlands, sandal, and the like).
Thus he must observe established customs.
Those customs, which have been explicitly ordained in revealed and in traditional texts, and which are practised by the virtuous, must always be observed by a righteous man with subdued passions.

column1: ācārāl labhate cāyur ācārād īpsitāṃ gatim /
column2: By adhering to established usage he attains to old age;

column1: sarvalakṣanahīno 'pi yaḥ sadācāravān naraḥ / śraddhadhāno 'nasūyaś ca śataṃ varṣāṇi jīvati //
column2: He who observes the usages established among the virtuous, who is a believer in revelation, and free from ill-will, lives a hundred years, eventhough he does not possess any external marks of prosperity.
He must persist in keeping his mind and his organs of sense under restraint.
Restraint of the mind implies restraint of the senses.
One who has acquired complete command over himself, gains this world and the next.
One who has no command over himself, reaps no fruit from any of his acts (whether worldly or tending to the acquisition of spiritual merit).

column1: damaḥ pavitraṃ paramaṃ maṅgalyaṃ paramaṃ damaḥ /
column2: Self-restraint is the best instrument of purification; self-restraint is the best of auspicious objects;

column1: damena sarvam āpnoti yat kiṃcin manasecchati //
column2: by self-restraint he obtains anything he may desire in his heart.

column1: daśārdhayuktena rathena yāto manovaśenāryapathānuvartinā / taṃ ced rathaṃ nāpaharanti vājinas tathāgataṃ nāvajayanti śatravaḥ //
column2: The man who rides (as it were) in a chariot drawn by his five senses and directed by his mind (as the charioteer), who keeps it on the path of the virtuous, can never be overcome by his enemies (lust, wrath, and greed), unless the horses (unrestrained by the charioteer) run away with the chariot.

column1: āpūryamāṇam acalapratiṣṭhaṃ samudram āpaḥ praviśanti yadvat / tadvat kāmā yaṃ praviśanti sarve sa śāntim āpnoti na kāmakāmī //
column2: As the waters (of all streams) are stored up (and reabsorbed) in the ocean, which, though being filled with them, remains unmoved and tranquil, even so that man, in whose mind the passions are stored up (and dissolved), obtains perfect calmness but not he who strives after the gratification of his desires.
One desirous of celebrating a Srâddha must invite the Brâhmanas on the day before (it is to take place).

column1: dvitīye 'hni śuklapakṣasya pūrvāhṇe kṛṣṇapakṣasyāparāhṇe viprān susnātān svācāntān yathābhūyo vayaḥkrameṇa kuśottareṣv āsaneṣūpaveśayet //
column2: On the next day, in the forenoon, if it falls in the bright half of the month, and in the afternoon, if it falls in the dark half of the month, the Brâhmanas, who must have duly bathed and duly sipped water, must be placed by him, in the order of their seniority' (or) of their sacred knowledge, upon seats covered with Kusa grass.

column1: dvau daive prāṅmukhau trīṃś ca pitrye udaṅmukhān //
column2: (He must entertain) two (Brâhmanas) facing the east at the Srâddha of the gods (Visvedevâs), and three facing the north at the Srâddha of the manes;
Or one only at each Srâddha.

After having (worshipped the Visvedevâs and) offered a burnt-oblation: during the recitation of the first Pañkaka (pentad) at a Srâddha repast consistingof undressed grain or performed for the gratification of a special desire;
At a Srâddha repast consisting of meat, during the recitation of the second Pañkaka;
At a new moon (Srâddha), during the recitation of the last Pañkaka;

column1: āgrahāyaṇyā ūrdhvaṃ kṛṣṇāṣṭakāsu ca krameṇaiva prathamamadhyamottamapañcakaiḥ //
column2: On the Ashtakâs (or eighth days) of the (three) dark halves subsequent to the full moon day of the month Âgrahâyana (or Mârgasîrsha), during the recitation of the first, second, and last Pañkakas respectively;
Likewise on the Anvashtakâs (or ninth days of the dark halves of those months);
He must invite the manes, after having received permission to do so from the Brâhmanas.

column1: apayantv asurā iti dvābhyāṃ tilaiḥ yātudhānānāṃ visarjanaṃ kṛtvā //
column2: Having driven away the Yâtudhânas by strewing grains of sesamum and by reciting the twoMantras (the first of which begins with the words), 'May the Asuras go away;'

column1: eta pitaraḥ sarvāṃs tān agra ā me yantv etad vaḥ pitara ity āvāhanaṃ kṛtvā, kuśatilamiśreṇa gandhodakena yās tiṣṭhanty amṛtā vāg iti yan me māteti ca pādyaṃ nivedya,
column2: He must invite the manes (with the four Mantras), 'Come near, O ye manes,' '(Conduct) them all (here), O Agni,' 'May my (ancestors) come near,' 'This is your (share), O ye manes.' Then let him prepare the water for washing the feet with scented water, which has been mixed up with Kusa grass and sesamum, while reciting (the three Mantras), 'Those standing,' 'Speech is imperishable,' and 'What my mother (has sinned),' and offer it (to the Brâhmanas);

column1: arghyaṃ kṛtvā nivedya cānulepanaṃ kṛtvā kuśatilavastrapuṣpālaṃkāradhūpadīpair yathāśaktyā viprān samabhyarcya ghṛtaplutam annam ādāya ādityā  #
column2: let him prepare the Arghya (or water mixed with Dûrvâ grass, flowers, &c.) and offer it to them; let him offer to the Brâhmanas, to the best of his power, Kusa grass, sesamum, clothes, flowers, ornaments, incense, and lamps; let him take food sprinkled with clarified butter;

column1: rudrā vasava iti vīkṣya, agnau karavāṇīty uktvā tac ca vipraiḥ kurv ity ukte āhutitrayaṃ dadyāt //
column2: let him look them in the face with the Mantra, 'O ye Âdityas, Rudras, and Vasus;' let him say, 'I will offer an oblation in the fire,' and if the Brâhmanas say, 'Offer an oblation,' let him offer three burnt-oblations.'

column1: ye māmakāḥ pitara etad vaḥ pitaro 'yaṃ yajña iti ca havir anumantraṇaṃ kṛtvā yathopapanneṣu
column2: After having consecrated the offerings with the Mantras, 'They, who are my ancestors,' 'This is your (share), O ye manes,' and 'This offering,' he must pour (what is left of) the food into such vessels as happen to be there, or (into golden ones at the offering addressed to the Visvedevâs and) into silverones (at the offering addressed to the manes), and offer it first to the two Brâhmanas facing the east (who have been invited to the Srâddha of the gods).

column1: pitre pitāmahāya prapitāmahāya ca nāmagotrābhyām udaṅmukheṣu //
column2: Afterwards he must offer it to the (three) Brâhmanas facing north (who represent his three ancestors, addressing himself) to his father, grandfather and great-grandfather, (and calling out) their name and race.

column1: tad adatsu brāhmaṇeṣu yan me prakāmād ahorātrair yad vaḥ kravyād iti japet //
column2: While the Brâhmanas are eating the food, let him mutter (the three Mantras), 'Whatever (trickles down) through my fault,' 'With days and nights,' and 'Whatever (limb) of yours, Agni.'
And (let him mutter) the Itihâsa (Epics), Purâna (Legends), and the Dharmasâstra (Institutes of the Sacred Law).

column1: ucchiṣṭasaṃnidhau dakṣināgreṣu kuśeṣu pṛthivī darvir akṣitā ity ekaṃ piṇḍaṃ pitre nidadhyāt //
column2: Near the leavings let him deposit upon blades of Kusa grass with the ends turned towards the south one ball of rice for his father, while saying, 'Earth is (like) a spoon, imperishable (satisfaction).'

column1: antarikṣaṃ darvir akṣitā ity dvitīyaṃ piṇḍaṃ pitāmahāya //
column2: With the Mantra, 'Air is (like) a spoon, imperishable (satisfaction,' let him deposit) a second ball for his grandfather.

column1: dyaur darvir akṣitā iti tṛtīyaṃ prapitāmahāya //
column2: With the Mantra, 'Heaven is (like) a spoon, imperishable (satisfaction,' let him deposit) a third ball for his great-grandfather.

column1: ye atra pitaraḥ pretā iti vāso deyam //
column2: With the Mantra, 'Those ancestors whohave died,' let him place a garment (upon the balls).
With the Mantra, 'Give us sons, O ye manes,' (let him place) food upon them.

column1: atra pitaro mādayadhvaṃ yathābhāgam iti darbhamūle karāvagharṣaṇam // ūrjaṃ vahantīr ity anena sodakena pradakṣiṇaṃ piṇḍānāṃ vikiraṇaṃ kṛtvā arghapuṣpadhūpālepanānnādibhakṣyabhojyāni nivedayet //
column2: With the Mantra, 'Enjoy it, O ye manes, partake of it,  imparting vigour,' let him sprinkle the balls to the right with the wet (remainder of the food), and offer the Argha, flowers, incense, unguents, and rice, and other victuals and dainties to the Brâhmanas.
And (he must offer them, ) a jar with water, which has been mixed up with honey, clarified butter, sesamum, and (ointments, oil, and the like).

column1: bhuktavatsu brāhmaṇeṣu tṛptim āgateṣu, mā me kṣeṣthety annaṃ satṛṇam abhyukṣyānnavikiram ucchiṣṭāgrataḥ kṛtvā,
column2: The Brâhmanas having eaten and being satisfied, let him sprinkle the food (as much as has been left by them) and the grass with the Mantra, 'Mayest thou not fail me,' and strew the food near the leavings;
and having asked them, 'Are you satisfied? Is (the Srâddha) finished,' he must first give water for sipping to the Brâhmanas facing the north, and then to those facing the east;

column1: tataś ca suprokṣitam iti śrāddhadeśaṃ saṃprokṣya, darbhapāṇiḥ sarvaṃ kuryāt //
column2: and he must sprinkle the place where the Srâddha has been offered (with water, with the Mantra), 'Well sprinkled.' All these rites he must perform while holding blades of sacred grass in his hand.

column1: tataḥ prāṅmukhāgrato yan me rāma iti pradakṣiṇaṃ kṛtvā pratyetya ca,
column2: Afterwards he must, while turning his face towards the Brâhmanas facing the east, circumambulatethem from left to right, with the Mantra, 'What a crow (may have eaten of my offering),' and turn back again;

he must honour them with sacrificial fees, to the best of his power, saying, 'May you be satisfied,' and on their answering, 'We are satisfied,' he must address them with the Mantra, 'The gods and the manes.'

column1: akṣayyodakaṃ ca nāmagotrābhyāṃ dattvā viśve devāḥ prīyantām iti prāṅmukhebhyas tataḥ prāñjalir idaṃ tanmanāḥ sumanā yāceta //
column2: After having given (to all) water (with the Mantra, 'May the food and water and whatever else I gave you be) imperishable,' (and calling out their name and race, and having added the Mantra, 'May the Visvedevâs be satisfied,' he must ask, with folded hands, and with an attentive and cheerful mind, the following (benediction) from the Brâhmanas facing the east:

column1: dātāro no 'bhivardhantāṃ vedāḥ saṃtatir eva ca / śraddhā ca no mā vyagamad bahu deyaṃ ca no 'stv iti //
column2: 'May the liberal-minded in our race increase in number, and may the (study of the) Vedas and our progeny (also increase). May faith not depart from us, and may we have plenty to bestow on the poor.
They shall answer, 'Thus let it be.'

column1: annaṃ ca no bahu bhaved atithīṃś ca labhemahi / yācitāraś ca naḥ santu mā ca yāciṣma kaṃcana // ity etābhyām āśiṣaḥ pratigṛhya //
column2: (The second half of the benediction shall be, as follows), "May we have plenty of food, and may we receive guests. May others come to beg of us, and may not we be obliged to beg of any one.'

column1: vāje vāja ity ca tato brāhmaṇāṃś ca visarjayet /
column2: He must dismiss the Brâhmanas, with the Mantra, 'With all food,' after having honoured them according to custom, accompanied them (as far as the limits of his estate), and taken his leave of them.

column1: pūjayitvā yathānyāyam anuvrajyābhivādya ca // aṣṭakāsu daivapūrvaṃ śākamāṃsāpūpaiḥ śrāddhaṃ kṛtvānvaṣṭakāsv aṣṭakāvad vahnau hutvā daivapūrvam eva mātre pitāmahyai prapitāmahyai ca pūrvavad brāhmaṇān bhojayitvā dakṣiṇābhiś
column2: After having worshipped, on each Ashtakâ, the gods and performed, with vegetables, meat, and cakes respectively, a Srâddha (according to the rules given in the last chapter), he must, on each Anvashtakâ, worship the gods and offer a burnt-oblation in the same way as on the Ashtakâ (i.e. reciting the same three Pañkakas successively), and entertain Brâhmanas in the same way as (directed) before (in the preceding chapter), in honour of his mother, his paternal grandmother, and his paternal great-grandmother, honour them with presents, accompany them (as far as the limits of his estate), and dismiss them
Then he must dig (six) trenches.
On the border of these trenches, to the northeast of them, he must light fires and place balls of rice.
On the border of three of the trenches (he must place balls) for the men, and on the border of the other three (he must place balls) for the women.
He must fill the three trenches for the men with water mixed with food.
(He must fill) the three trenches for the women with milk mixed with food.
(And he must fill up) each triad of trenches singly with sour milk, meat, and milk.

column1: pūrayitvā japed etad bhavadbhyo bhavatībyo 'stu cākṣayam //
column2: After having filled (the trenches), he must mutter the Mantra, 'May this (food) be imperishable for ye men and for ye women.'

column1: pitari jīvati yaḥ śrāddhaṃ kuryāt, sa yeṣāṃ pitā kuryāt teṣāṃ kuryāt //
column2: He who makes a Srâddha-offering while his father is alive, must offer it to those persons to whom his father offers (his Srâddhas).

column1: pitari pitāmahe ca jīvati yeṣāṃ pitāmahaḥ //
column2: (If he offers a Srâddha) while both his father and grandfather are alive, (he must offer it to those persons) to whom his grandfather (offers his Srâddhas).

column1: pitari pitāmahe prapitāmahe ca jīvati naiva kuryāt //
column2: While his father, grandfather, and great-grandfather are alive, he must offer no Srâddha at all.

column1: yasya pitā pretaḥ syāt sa pitre piṇḍaṃ nidhāya pitāmahāt paraṃ dvābhyāṃ dadyāt //
column2: He whose father is dead (but whose grandfather is alive), must first of all offer a ball of rice to his father, after that, two balls to the two ancestors coming before his grandfather (or to his great-grandfather and to his fourth ascendant).

column1: yasya pitā pitāmahaś ca pretau syātāṃ sa tābhyāṃ piṇḍau dattvā pitāmahapitāmahāya dadyāt //
column2: He whose father and grandfather are dead (but whose great-grandfather is alive), must first offer two balls to those two, and then offer one ball to the grandfather of his grandfather.

column1: yasya pitāmahaḥ pretaḥ syāt sa tasmai piṇḍaṃ nidhāya prapitāmahāt paraṃ dvābhyāṃ dadyāt //
column2: He whose grandfather is dead (but whose father and great-grandfather are alive), must give one ball to his grandfather and two balls to the father and grandfather of his great-grandfather.

column1: mātāmahānām apy evaṃ śrāddhaṃ kuryād vicakṣaṇaḥ / mantroheṇa yathānyāyaṃ śeṣāṇāṃ mantravarjitam //
column2: An intelligent man must offer Srâddhas to his maternal grandfather, and to the father and grandfather of him, in the same way (as to his paternal ancestors), duly modifying the Mantras. But the Srâddhas addressed to other relatives, (uncles, brothers, and the like, must be performed) without Mantras.

column1: amāvāsyās tisro 'ṣṭakās tisro 'nvaṣṭakā māghī prauṣṭhapady ūrdhvaṃ kṛṣṇatrayodaśī vrīhiyavapākau ceti //
column2: The (twelve) days of new moon, the three Ashtakâs, the three Anvashtakâs, a Mâgha day (i.e. 'day on which the moon enters the lunar asterism Maghâ'), which falls on the thirteenth of the dark half of the month Praushthapada, and the two seasons when rice and barley grow ripe (or autumn and spring):
Thus have the regular times for a Srâddha been declared by the lord of creatures. He who fails to perform a Srâddha on those days, goes to hell.
The sun's passage from one sign of the zodiac, to another;
The two equinoctial points;
The two solstitial points particularly;
The (Yoga) Vyatîpâta;
A time of rejoicing (as, when a son has been born, or another happy event happened):

column1: etāṃs tu śrāddhakālān vai kāmyān āha prajāpatiḥ /
column2: These occasions for a Srâddha the lord of creatures has pronounced optional;

column1: śrāddham eteṣu yad dattaṃ tad ānantyāya kalpate //
column2: a Srâddha which is performed on these occasions gives infinite satisfaction (to the manes).

column1: saṃdhyārātryor na kartavyaṃ śrāddhaṃ khalu vicakṣaṇaiḥ /
column2: No Srâddha must be performed in the twilight or at night by an intelligent man. A Srâddha may be performed at those times also when an eclipse (of the sun or of the moon) takes place.

For a Srâddha which is offered them at the time of an eclipse satisfies the manes, as long as the moon and the stars exist, and procures immense advantages and the satisfaction of all his desires to the sacrificer.

column1: satatam āditye 'hni śrāddhaṃ kurvann ārogyam āpnoti //
column2: By performing a Srâddha on Sunday he procures everlasting freedom from disease.
(By performing a Srâddha) on Monday he becomes beloved.
(By performing it) on Tuesday (he procures) success in battle.
(By performing it) on Wednesday (he enjoys) all his desires.
(By performing it) on Thursday (he acquires) such religious knowledge as he desires.
(By performing it) on Friday (he acquires) wealth.
(By performing it) on Saturday (he procures) longevity.
(By performing it under the Nakshatra or constellation) Krittikâs (he gains) heaven.
(By performing it under the constellation) Rohinî (he obtains) progeny.
(By performing it under the constellation) Saumya (or Mrigasiras he procures) the superhuman power of a pious Brâhmana.
(By performing it under the constellation) Raudra (or Ârdrâ he reaps) the fruit of his labours.
(By performing it under the constellation) Punarvasu (he procures) land.
(By performing it under the constellation) Pushya (or Tishya he procures) prosperity.
(By performing it under the constellation) Sârpa (or Âsleshâs he obtains) beauty.
(By performing it under the constellation) Paitrya (or Maghâ he enjoys) all his desires.
(By performing it under the constellation) Bhâgya (or Pûrvaphâlgunî) he becomes beloved.
(By performing it under the constellation) Âryamana (or Uttaraphâlgunî he procures) wealth.
(By performing it under the constellation) Hasta (he acquires) superiority among his kindred.
(By performing it under the constellation) Tvâshtra (or Kitrâ he procures) handsome sons.
(By performing it under the constellation) Svâti (he procures) success in trade.
(By performing it under the constellation) Visâkhâs (he acquires) gold.
(By performing it under the constellation) Maitra (or Anurâdhâ he procures) friends.
(By performing it under the constellation) Sâkra (or Gyeshthâ he procures) royalty.
(By performing it' under the constellation) Mûla (he procures good results in) agriculture.
(By performing it under the constellation) Âpya (or Pûrvâshâdhâs he procures) success in sea-voyages.
(By performing it under the constellation) Vaisvadeva (or Uttarâshâdhâs he enjoys) all his desires.
(By performing it under the constellation) Abhigit (he procures) superiority.
(By performing it under the constellation) Sravana (he enjoys) all his desires.
(By performing it under the constellation) Vâsava (or Dhanishthâs he procures success in preparing) salt.
(By performing it under the constellation) Vâruna (or Satabhishâ he obtains) freedom from disease.
(By performing it under the constellation) Âhirbudhnya (or Uttarabhâdrapadâ he obtains) a house.
(By performing it under the constellation) Paushna (or Revatî he acquires) cows.
(By performing it under the constellation) Âsvina (or Asvinî he obtains) a horse.
(By performing it under the constellation) Yâmya (or Bharanî he procures) longevity,
(By offering it) on the first day of a lunar fortnight (he procures) a house and handsome wives.
(By offering it) on the second day (he procures) a beautiful daughter (and sons-in-law).
(By offering it) on the third day (he enjoys) all his desires.
(By offering it) on the fourth day (he procures) cattle.
(By offering it) on the fifth day (he procures) handsome sons.
(By offering it) on the sixth day (he obtains) success in gaming.
(By offering it) on the seventh day (he procures good results in) agriculture.
(By offering it) on. the eighth day (he procures success in) trade.
(By offering it) on the ninth day (he procures) cattle.
(By offering it) on the tenth day (he procures) horses.
(By offering it) on the eleventh day (he procures) sons endowed with the superhuman power of a pious Brâhmana.
(By offering it) on the twelfth day (he procures) gold and silver.
(By offering it) on the thirteenth day he becomes beloved.
(By offering it) on the fifteenth day (he enjoys) all his desires.
For Srâddhas for those who have been killed in battle the fourteenth day is ordained.
There are two stanzas on this subject recited by the manes.

column1: api jāyeta so 'smākaṃ kule kaścin narottamaḥ / prāvṛṭkāle 'site pakṣe trayodaśyāṃ samāhitaḥ //
column2: 'May that excellent man be born to our race, whosoever he may be, who attentively offers a Srâddha in the rainy season on the thirteenth of the dark half,
'With milk profusely mixed with honey;

column1: kārttikaṃ sakalaṃ māsaṃ prākchāye kuñjarasya ca //
column2: and (he who offers such Srâddhas) during the whole month Kârttika and (in the afternoon) when the shadow of an elephant falls towards the east.'

column1: atha na naktaṃ gṛhītenodakena śrāddhaṃ kuryāt //
column2: He must not perform a Srâddha with water collected at night.

column1: kuśābhāve kuśasthāne kāśān dūrvāṃ vā dadyāt //
column2: On failure of Kusa grass he must employ Kâsa or Dûrvâ grass instead.
Instead of a garment (he may give) cotton thread.

column1: daśāṃ visarjayet yady apy ahatavastrajā syāt //
column2: He must avoid (giving) the fringe of cloth, though it be of cloth not yet used.
And (he must not give) flowers having a nasty odour, or no odour at all, the blossoms of thorny plants, and red flowers.

column1: śuklāni sugandhīni kaṇṭakijāny api jalajāni raktāny api dadyāt //
column2: He may give white and sweet-smelling flowers, even though grown on thorny plants, and aquatic flowers, even though they be red.

column1: vasāṃ medaṃ ca dīpārthe na dadyāt // ghṛtaṃ tailaṃ vā dadyāt //
column2: He must not give marrow or fat instead of a lamp.S. He may give clarified butter or sesamum-oil.
He must not give (the nails or horns) of animals instead of the incense of all kinds (prescribed for a Srâddha).
He may give bdellium mixed up with honey and clarified butter.
He may give sandal, saffron, camphor, aloe wood, or Padmaka wood instead of an ointment.
He must not salt (the dishes) publicly (after they have been cooked).
He must not give clarified butter, condiments, or the like (i. e. sour milk, milk, &c.) with his hands.
He must use metallic vessels;
Especially vessels made of silver.

He must place (on the sacrificial ground) vessels made of the horn of the rhinoceros, blankets made of the hair of the mountain-goat, the skin of a black antelope, sesamum, white mustard, unbroken grains, (silver and copper vessels and other) purificatory objects, and (a goat and other animals or objects), by which the demons are kept aloof.
And (he must not use the bean called) Râgamâsha, (the lentil called) Masûra, stale food, and factitious salt.
Let him avoid wrath.
He must not shed a tear. He must not be in a hurry.

column1: ghṛtādidāne taijasāni pātrāṇi khaḍgapātrāṇi phalgupātrāṇi ca praśastāni //
column2: In offering the clarified butter and other (liquids, such as condiments, sour milk, milk, and the like) he must use metallic vessels, vessels made of the horn of the rhinoceros, and vessels made of the wood of the Phalgu tree.
There is a Sloka on this subject:

column1: sauvarṇarājatābhyāṃ ca khaḍgenaudumbareṇa vā / dattam akṣayyatāṃ yāti phalgupātreṇa cāpy atha //
column2: 'That which has been offered in vessels made of gold, or of silver, or of the horn of the rhinoceros, or of copper, or of Phalgu wood, becomes imperishable (and brings infinite reward to the sacrificer).'

column1: tilair vrīhiyavair māṣair adbhir mūlaphalaiḥ śākaiḥ śyāmākaiḥ priyaṅgubhir nīvārair mudgair godhūmaiś ca māsaṃ prīyante //
column2: Sesamum, rice, barley, beans, water, roots, fruits, vegetables, Syâmâka grain, millet, wild rice, kidney-beans, and wheat satisfy (the manes) for a month;
The flesh of fishes (excepting those species that are forbidden), for two months;
The flesh of the common deer, for three months;
The flesh of sheep, for four months;
The flesh of birds (of those kinds that may be eaten), for five months;
The flesh of goats, for six months;
The flesh of the spotted deer, for seven months;
The flesh of the spotted antelope, for eight months;
Beef, for nine months;
Buffalo's meat, for ten months;
The meat of a hornless goat, for eleven months;
The milk of a cow, or preparations from it, for a year.
On this subject there exists a stanza, which the manes utter:

column1: kālaśākaṃ mahāśalkaṃ māṃsaṃ vārdhrīṇasasya ca / viṣāṇavarjyā ye khaḍgā āsūryaṃ tāṃs tu bhuṅkṣmahe //
column2: '(The pot-herb) Kâlasâka (sacred basil), (the prawn) Mahâsalka, and the flesh of the (crane called) Vârdhrînasa, (and of) a rhinoceros having no horn, is food which we always accept.'
He must not place the food upon a chair.
He must not touch it with his foot.
He must not sneeze upon it.
He must drive the Yâtudhânas away by means of sesamum or mustard-seeds.
Let him perform the Srâddha in an enclosed place.
He must not look at a woman in her courses;
Nor at a dog;
Nor at a tame pig;
Nor at a tame cock.
Let him strive to perform the Srâddha in sight of a goat.
The Brâhmanas must eat in silence.
They must not eat with their heads covered
Nor with shoes on their feet;
Nor with their feet placed upon a stool.
Let not men with a limb too little, or with a limb too much, look at a Srâddha;
Nor Sûdras;
Nor outcasts.

column1: tatkālaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ brāhmaṇānumatena bhikṣukaṃ vā pūjayet //
column2: If at the time of a Srâddha a Brâhmana or an ascetic (has come to his house), he must feed him, if (the invited) Brâhmanas permit it.

column1: havir guṇān na brāhmaṇā brūyur dātrā pṛṣṭāḥ //
column2: The Brâhmanas must not declare the qualities of the sacrificial dishes, even though asked to do so by their host.

column1: yāvad ūṣmā bhavaty anne yāvad aśnanti vāgyatāḥ / tāvad aśnanti pitaro yāvan noktā havir guṇāḥ //
column2: As long as the dishes remain warm, as long as (the Brâhmanas) eat in silence, as long as the qualities of the sacrificial food are not declared by them, so long the manes enjoy it.

column1: sārvavarṇikam annādyaṃ saṃnīyāplāvya vāriṇā / samutsṛjed bhuktavatām agrato vikiran bhuvi //
column2: Having brought together (the remainder of) all the sorts of substantial food and (of the vegetables and) the like, he must sprinkle it with water, and place it before the Brâhmanas, who have taken their meal, strewing it on the ground.

column1: uccheṣaṇaṃ bhūmigatam ajihmasyāśaṭhasya ca / dāsavargasya tat pitrye bhāgadheyaṃ pracakṣate //
column2: What has dropped on the ground from the dishes, at a sacrifice addressed to the manes, they declare to be the share of servants, provided they be not dishonest or depraved.
At a (Srâddha) offering to the Visvedevâs let him not enquire (into the qualities or descent of) a Brâhmana (whom he means to invite).
But at a (Srâddha offering) to the manes he must enquire as closely as possible (into the qualities and descent of a Brâhmana, whom he means to invite).
He must not invite (to a Srâddha) such as have a limb too little, or a limb too much;
Nor those who act (deceitfully) like cats;
Nor Brâhmanas who subsist upon the offerings made to an idol which they attend;
Nor physicians;
Nor sons of an unmarried woman;
Nor sons of the son of an unmarried woman;
Nor those who sacrifice for a multitude of persons;
Nor those who offer sacrifices for a whole village;
Nor those who offer sacrifices for Sûdras;
Nor those who offer sacrifices for those for whom it is forbidden to sacrifice (such as outcasts and others);
Nor those who sacrifice for such;
Nor those who do work on holidays;
Nor those who teach (the Veda) for a fee;
Nor those who have been taught (the Veda) for a fee;
Nor those who subsist on food given to them by a Sûdra;
Nor those who have intercourse with an outcast;
Nor those who neglect their daily study of the Veda;
Nor those who neglect their morning and evening prayers;
Nor those who are in the king's service;
Nor 'naked' persons;
Nor those who quarrel with their father;
Nor those who have forsaken their father, mother, Guru, holy fire, or sacred study.
All those persons are said to defile a company, because they have been expelled from the community of Brâhmanas. Let a wise man avoid carefully, therefore, to entertain them at a Srâddha.
The following persons sanctify a company:
A Trinâkiketa;
One who keeps five fires;
One who can sing the Sâmans called Gyeshtha;
One who has studied the whole Veda;
One who has studied one Vedânga;
One who has studied either the Purânas (Legends), or the Itihâsas (Epics), or grammar;
One who has studied one of the Dharmasâstras (Institutes of the Sacred Law);
One purified by visiting sacred places of pilgrimage;
One purified by offering sacrifices;
One purified by austere devotion;
One purified by veracity;
One purified by (constantly muttering) Mantras;
One intent upon muttering the Gâyatrî;
One in whose family the study and teaching of the Veda are hereditary.
One who knows the Trisuparna (the text which thrice contains the word Suparna).
A son-in-law;
And, particularly, devotees.
, There is a stanza recited by the manes, which refers to this subject:

column1: api sa syāt kule 'smākaṃ bhojayed yas tu yoginam / vipraṃ śrāddhe prayatnena yena tṛpyāmahe vayam //
column2: 'May that man be born to our race, who feeds a Brâhmana devotee assiduously at a Srâddha, by which repast we are satisfied ourselves.'
He must not offer a Srâddha in a country inhabited by barbarians.
He must not visit a country, inhabited by barbarians (excepting on a pilgrimage).
By (constantly) drinking water from (or bathing in) a pool situated in a foreign (barbarous) country, he becomes equal to its inhabitants.
Those countries are called barbarous (mlekkha) where the system of the four castes does not exist;

column1: sa mlecchadeśo jijñeya āryāvartas tataḥ paraḥ //
column2: the others are denoted Âryâvarta, (the abode of the Âryans).
A Srâddha offered at the (Tîrtha or place of pilgrimage called) Pushkaras confers eternal bliss upon the giver;
And so does the muttering of prayers, the offering of burnt-oblations, and the practice of austerities in that place.
Even by merely bathing at Pushkara he is purified from all his sins.
The same effect may be produced at Gayâsîrsha;
And near Vata (Akshayavata);
And on the Amarakantaka mountain;
And on the Varâha mountain;
And anywhere on the bank of the Narmadâ (Nerbudda) river;
And on the bank of the Yamunâ (Jumna);
And, particularly, on the Gangâ;
And at Kusâvarta;
And at Binduka;
And upon the Nîlgiri hills;
And at Kanakhala;
And at Kubgâmra;
And on the Bhrigutunga (mountain);
And at Kedâra;
And on the Mahâlaya (mountain);
And on the Nadantikâ (river);
And on the Sugandhâ (river);
And at Sâkambharî;
And at Phalgutîrtha;
And on theMahâgangâ;
And at Trihalikâgrâma;
And at Kumâradhârâ;
And at Prabhâsa;
; And particularly anywhere on (the bank of) the Sarasvatî;
At Gangâdvâra (Haridvâr), at Prayâga (Allahabad), where the Gangâ falls into the ocean, constantly in the Naimisha forest, and especially at Benares;
And at Agastyâsrama;
And at Kanvâsrama (on the Mâlinî river);
And on the Kausikî (Kosi river);
And on the bank of the Sarayû (Surju river in Oudh);
And on the confluence of the Sona (Sone) and Gyotisha rivers;
And on the Srîparvata (mountain);
And at (the Tîrtha situated on the Yamunâ, which is called) Kâlodaka.
And at Uttaramânasa (in the Kedâr mountains, in the Himâlayas).
And at Vadavâ (in the Dekhan).
And at Matangavâpî (in the southern part of Gayâ);
And at Saptârsha;
And at Vishnupada;
And at Svargamârgapada (or Rathamârga);
And on the Godâvarî river (in the Dekhan);
And on the Gomatî (river);
And on the Vetravatî (river);
And on the Vipâsâ (river);
And on the Vitastâ (river);
And on the banks of the Satadru (river);
And on the Kandrabhâgâ (river);
And on the Îrâvati (river);
And on the banks of the Indus;
And on the southern Pañkanada;
And at Ausaga (?);
And at other such Tîrthas;
And on the banks of (other) holy rivers;
And anywhere at the birth-place of a deity, (such as Râma, Krishna, and others);
And on sand-banks;
And near waterfalls;
And on mountains;
And in arbours (the sporting-places of Krishna);
And in woods;
And in groves;
And in houses smeared with cow-dung,
And in 'pleasant spots.'
There are some stanzas recited by the manes, which refer to this subject:

column1: kule 'smākaṃ sa jantuḥ syād yo no dadyāj jalāñjalīn / nadīṣu bahutoyāsu śītalāsu viśeṣataḥ //
column2: 'May that person be born to our race, who will give us libations of water, taken from streams abounding with water, especially if their floods (coming from the Himâlayas) are cool.

column1: api jāyeta so 'smākaṃ kule kaścin narottamaḥ / gayāśīrṣe vaṭe śrāddhaṃ yo naḥ kuryāt samāhitaḥ //
column2: 'May that excellent man be born to our race, who offers us a Srâddha attentively at Gayâsîrsha or at Vata.'

column1: eṣṭavyā bahavaḥ putrā yady eko 'pi gayāṃ vrajet / yajeta vāśvamedhena nīlaṃ vā vṛṣam utsṛjet // atha vṛṣotsargaḥ //
column2: A man must wish to have many sons, because if only one of them goes to Gayâ (and offers a Srâddha to him after his death), or if he performs a horse-sacrifice, or if he sets a dark-coloured bull at liberty, (he will acquire final emancipation through him.)
Now follows the ceremony of setting a bull at liberty, (which should take place)
(The bull must be) the offspring of a milch cow having young ones living.
He must have all marks.
He must be dark-coloured;
Or red, but having a white mouth, a white tail.. and white feet and horns.

column1: yūthasyācchādakam // tato gavāṃ madhye susamiddham agniṃ paristīrya pauṣṇaṃ caruṃ payasā śrapayitvā pūṣā gā anvetu na iha ratir iti ca hutvā vṛṣam ayaskāras tv
column2: Then, after having (kindled) a blazing fire among the cows (in the cow-pen) and strewed Kusa grass around it, let him boil with milk a dish sacred to Pûshan, and offer (two oblations) in the fire with the Mantras, 'May Pûshan follow our cows,' and 'Here is pleasure.' And let a blacksmith mark the bull.
On the one flank (the right), with a discus; on the other flank (the left), with a trident.

column1: aṅkitaṃ ca hiraṇyavarṇeti catasṛbhiḥ śaṃ no devīr iti ca snāpayet //
column2: After he has been marked, let him wash the bull with the four Mantras, (beginning with the words), 'The golden-coloured,' and with (the five Mantras, beginning with the words), 'May the divine (waters help and propitiate us').

column1: snātam alaṃkṛtaṃ snātālaṃkṛtābhiś catasṛbhir vatsatarībhiḥ sārdham ānīya rudrān puruṣasūktaṃ kūśmāṇḍīś ca japet //
column2: Having washed and adorned the bull, he must bring him near, together with four young cows,which must also have been washed and decorated, and he must mutter the Rudras, the Purushasûkta, and the Kûshmândîs.

column1: pitā vatsānām iti vṛṣabhasya dakṣiṇe karṇe paṭhet //
column2: Then let him pronounce in the bull's right ear the Mantra, 'The father of calves;'
And the following (Mantras):

column1: vṛṣo hi bhagavān dharmaś catuṣpādaḥ prakīrtitaḥ /
column2: 'Holy law is a bull and is declared to have four feet: him I choose for the object of my worship;

column1: vṛṇomi tam ahaṃ bhaktyā sa me rakṣatu sarvataḥ //
column2: may he protect me wholly.

column1: etaṃ yuvānaṃ patiṃ vo dadāmy anena krīḍantīś carata priyeṇa / mā hāsmahi prajayā mā tanūbhir mā radhāma dviṣate soma rājan //
column2: 'This young (bull) I give you as husband (O ye calves), roam about sportingly with him for your lover. May we not be deficient in progeny, O king Soma, and may we live long, and may we not be oppressed by our enemies.'

column1: vṛṣaṃ vatsatarīyuktam aiśānyāṃ kārayed diśi / hotur vastrayugaṃ dadyāt suvarṇaṃ kāṃsyam eva ca //
column2: He must drive away the bull together with the calves in a north-eastern direction and give a pair of garments, gold, and a vessel made of white copper to the officiating priest.
The blacksmith shall receive as wages as much as he claims, and food prepared with a great deal of butter, and (three) Brâhmanas shall be fed.

column1: utsṛṣṭo vṛṣabho yasmin pibaty atha jalāśaye / jalāśayaṃ tat sakalaṃ pitṝṃs tasyopatisṭhati //
column2: Any pool from which the bull drinks afterhaving been set at liberty) that entire pool will refresh the manes of him who has set the bull at liberty.

column1: śṛṅgeṇollikhate bhūmiṃ yatra kvacana darpitaḥ / pitṝṇām annapānaṃ tat prabhūtam upatiṣṭhati //
column2: The earth which is anywhere dug up by the bull exulting in his strength, is converted into delicious food and drink to satisfy the manes.

column1: atha vaiśākhyāṃ paurṇamāsyāṃ kṛṣṇājinaṃ sakhuraṃ saśṛṅgaṃ suvarṇaśṛṅgaṃ raupyakhuraṃ mauktikalāṅgūlabhūṣitaṃ kṛtvāvike ca vastre prasārayet
column2: Now on the day of full moon in the month Vaisâkha he must spread out upon a woollen blanket the skin of a black antelope (together with the horns and hoofs), after having adorned the former with gold and the latter with silver, and after having ornamented the tail with a string of pearls.
After that, he must cover (that part of the blanket which is not covered by the skin) with sesamum.
And he must adorn the navel with gold.
He must cover (the skin) with a couple of new garments.
He must place all sorts of perfumes and jewels upon it.

column1: catasṛṣu dikṣu catvāri taijasāni pātrāṇi kṣīradadhimadhughṛtapūrṇāni nidhyāyāhitāgnaye brāhmaṇāyālaṃkṛtāya vāsoyugena pracchāditāya dadyāt
column2: After having placed on its four sides (beginning with the eastern side) four metallic dishes (of copper, silver, white copper, and gold respectively) filled with milk, sour milk, honey, and clarified butter respectively, (and having poured out water) he must give (the skin, seizing it by the tail), to a Brâhmana, who is an Agnihotrin, decked with ornaments, and clad in two garments.
There are (the following) stanzas in regard to this subject:

column1: yas tu kṛṣṇājinaṃ dadyāt sakhuraṃ śṛṅgasaṃyutam / tilaiḥ pracchādya vāsobhiḥ sarvaratnair alaṃkṛtam //
column2: 'He who bestows (upon a pious Brâhmana) the skin of a black antelope, together with the hoofs and horns, after having covered it with seeds of sesamum and garments, and adorned it with all sorts of jewels:

column1: sasamudraguhā tena saśailavanakānanā / caturantā bhaved dattā pṛthivī nātra saṃśayaḥ //
column2: 'That man doubtless obtains the same reward as if he were to bestow the whole earth on him, bordered as it is on every side (by the oceans), together with the oceans and caverns, and with rocks, groves, and forests.

column1: kṛṣṇājine tilān kṛtvā hiraṇyaṃ madhusarpiṣī / dadāti yas tu viprāya sarvaṃ tarati duṣkṛtam //
column2: 'He who places sesamum, gold, honey, and butter on the skin of a black antelope and gives the whole to a Brâhmana, annihilates the consequences of all his own evil actions.'
A cow in the act of bringing forth a young one is (comparable to) the earth.

column1: tām alaṃkṛtāṃ brāhmaṇāya dattvā pṛthivīdānaphalam āpnoti //
column2: By bestowing such a cow upon a Brâhmana, after having decked her with ornaments, he obtains the same reward as if he were to bestow the earth (upon him),
There is a stanza in regard to this subject:

column1: savatsāromatulyāni yugāny ubhayatomukhīm / dattvā svargam avāpnoti śraddadhānaḥ samāhitaḥ //
column2: 'One who full of faith and with intense application of mind gives away a pregnant cow, enters heaven for as many Yugas (or ages of the world) as that cow and her calf together have hairs on their bodies.'
The month Kârttika is sacred to the god Agni.
Agni is the first of all gods.

column1: tasmāt tu kārttikaṃ māsaṃ bahiḥsnāyī gāyatrījapanirataḥ sakṛd eva haviṣyāśī saṃvatsarakṛtāt pāpāt pūto bhavati //
column2: Therefore is that man purified from every sin committed during the past year, who persists during the month Kârttika in bathing (daily) out of the village, in muttering the Gâyatrî, and in taking a single meal each day, consisting of food fit for oblations.

column1: kārttikaṃ sakalaṃ māsaṃ nityasnāyī jitendriyaḥ / japan haviṣyabhugdāntaḥ sarvapāpaiḥ pramucyate //
column2: He who bathes (at the prescribed time, early in the morning) constantly, during the whole month Kârttika, who keeps his organs of sense under control, who mutters (the Gâyatrî), who eats food fit for oblations only, and who governs his passions, is purified from every sin.

column1: mārgaśīrṣaśuklapañcadaśyāṃ mṛgaśirasā yuktāyāṃ cūrṇitalavaṇasya suvarṇanābhaṃ prastham ekaṃ candrodaye brāhmaṇāya pradāpayet //
column2: If on the fifteenth of the bright half of the month Mârgasîrsha the moon enters the lunar asterism. Mrigasiras, he must give at the time when the moon rises (a vessel with) a golden centre, containing a Prastha of ground salt, to a Brâhmana.
By (performing) this rite he obtains beauty and good fortune in a future birth.

column1: tasyāṃ gaurasarṣapakalkodvartitaśarīro gavyaghṛtapūrṇakumbhenābhiṣiktaḥ sarvauṣadhibhiḥ sarvagandhaiḥ sarvabījaiś ca snāto ghṛtena bhagavantaṃ vāsudevaṃ snāpayitvā gandhapuṣpadhūpadīpanaivedyādibhir abhyarcya vaiṣṇavaiḥ śākrair bārhaspatyaiś ca mantraiḥ pāvake hutvā sasuvarṇena ghṛtena
column2: If on the full moon day of the month Pausha the moon enters the lunar asterism Pushya, he must rub over his body with a dough prepared with white mustard-seeds, anoint himself with a kumbha of clarified butter made of cow-milk, wash himself with (water and with) all sorts of medicinal herbs, all sorts of perfumes, and all sorts of seeds, wash (an image of) Bhagavat Vâsudeva (Vishnu) with clarified butter, and worship him with perfumes, flowers, incense, with a lamp, with eatables, and the like, offer an oblation in the fire with Mantras tending to the praise of Vishnu , Mantras tending to the praise of Indra , Mantras tending to the praise of Brihaspati , and cause three Brâhmanas to pronounce the benediction, after having bestowed clarified butter and gold upon them.

column1: brāhmaṇān svasti vācayet // vāsoyugaṃ kartre dadyāt //
column2: To the priest (who has performed the burnt-oblation for him) he must give a pair of garments.
By (performing) this rite he obtains prosperity (pushyate).

column1: māghī maghāyutā cet, tasyāṃ tilaiḥ śrāddhaṃ kṛtvā pūto bhavati //
column2: If on the full moon day in the month Mâgha the moon enters the lunar asterism Maghâ and he performs a Srâddha with sesamum on that day, he is purified.

column1: phālgunī phalgunīyutā cet, tasyāṃ brāhmaṇāya susaṃskṛtaṃ svāstīrṇaṃ śayanaṃ nivedya bhāryāṃ manojñāṃ rūpavatīṃ draviṇavatīṃ cāpnoti //
column2: If on the full moon day in the month Phâlguna the moon enters the lunar asterism Uttaraphâlgunî, and he gives on that day a bedstead, quite complete and covered with good rugs, to a Brâhmana, he obtains an amiable, handsome, and wealthy wife.
A woman who does the same, (obtains) a husband (possessing those qualities).
If on the full moon day of the month Kaitra the moon enters the lunar asterism Kitrâ, and he gives a variegated (kitra) garment (to a Brâhmana) on that day, he obtains good fortune.

column1: vaiśākhī viśākhāyutā cet, tasyāṃ brāhmaṇasaptakaṃ kṣaudrayuktais tilaiḥ saṃtarpya dharmarājānaṃ prīṇayitvā pāpebhyaḥ pūto bhavati //
column2: If on the full moon day of the month Vaisâkha the moon enters the lunar asterism Visâkhâ, and he feeds on that day seven Brâhmanas with sesamum. mixed with honey, in order to please king Dharma, he is purified from his sins.

column1: jyaiṣṭhī jyeṣṭhāyutā cet syāt, tasyāṃ chatropānahapradānena gavādhipatyaṃ prāpnoti // āṣāḍhyām āṣāḍhāyuktāyām annapānadānena tad evākṣayyam āpnoti //
column2: If on the full moon day of the month Gyaishtha the moon enters the lunar asterism Gyeshtha and he gives on that day an umbrella and a pair of shoes (to a Brâhmana), he becomes possessed of many cows.

column1: śrāvaṇyāṃ śravaṇayuktāyāṃ jaladhenuṃ sānnāṃ vāsoyugāc chāditāṃ dattvā svargam āpnoti //
column2: If on the full moon day of the month Srâvana the moon is seen in conjunction with the lunar asterism Sravana and he gives a milch cow covered with two garments, together with food (to a Brâhmana), he attains heaven.

If on the full moon day of the month Praushthapada(or Bhâdrapada) the moon is seen in conjunction with the lunar asterism Uttaraproshthapadâ (or Uttarabhâdrapadâ), and he gives a cow (to a Brâhmana) on that day, he is cleansed from every sin.

column1: āśvayujyām aśvinīgate candramasi ghṛtapūrṇaṃ bhājanaṃ suvarṇayutaṃ viprāya dattvā dīptāgnir bhavati //
column2: If on the full moon day of the month Âsvayuga (or Âsvina) the moon is seen in conjunction with the lunar asterism Asvinî, and he gives a vessel filled with clarified butter, and gold (to a Brâhmana) on that day, he obtains an excellent digestive faculty.

column1: tasyāṃ sitam ukṣāṇam anyavarṇaṃ vā śaśāṅkodye sarvasasyaratnagandhopetaṃ dīpamadhye brāhmaṇāya dattvā kāntārabhayaṃ na paśyati //
column2: If on the full moon day of the month Kârttika the moon enters the lunar asterism. Krittikâ, and he bestows on that day, at the time of moonrise, upon a Brâhmana, a white bull, or one of a different colour, together with all sorts of grains, all sorts of jewels, and all sorts of perfumes, after having lighted lamps on both sides (of the bull), he will meet with no danger on perilous roads.

column1: vaiśākhaśuklatṛtīyāyām upoṣito 'kṣataiḥ śrīvāsudevam abhyarcya tān eva hutvā dattvā ca sarvapāpebhyaḥ pūto bhavati //
column2: - If on the third day of the bright half of the month Vaisâkha he worships, after having fasted, Vâsudeva (Vishnu) with (one thousand and eight, or one hundred) unbroken grains (of barley, while muttering the Mantra, Om namo bhagavate, vâsudevâya), and offers up the same in fire, and gives them (to a Brâhmana), he is purified from every sin.

column1: yac ca tasminn ahani prayacchati tad akṣayyatām āpnoti //
column2: And whatever he gives on that day becomes imperishable.

column1: pauṣyāṃ samatītāyāṃ kṛṣṇapakṣadvādaśyāṃ sopavāsas tilaiḥ snātas tilokakaṃ dattvā tilair vāsudevam abhyarcya tān eva hutvā dattvā bhuktvā ca  # pāpebhyaḥ pūto bhavati //
column2: If on the twelfth day of the dark half following on the full moon day of the month Pausha, he washes himself, after having kept a fast, with sesamum-seeds, gives water mixed with sesamum(to the manes), worships Vâsudeva with sesamum, offers up (part of) the same in fire, gives to Brâhmanas of it, and eats (the remainder himself) he is purified from his sins.

column1: māghyāṃ samatītāyāṃ kṛṣṇadvādaśyāṃ sopavāsaḥ śravaṇaṃ prāpya śrīvāsudevāgrato mahāvartidvayena dīpadvayaṃ dadyāt //
column2: (If) on the twelfth day of the (the dark half following on the full moon day of the month Mâgha, moon enters Sravana), he must keep a fast till the moon has entered that asterism, and place two lamps with two large wicks near (an image of) Vâsudeva;

column1: dakṣiṇapārśve mahārajanaraktena samagreṇa vāsasā ghṛtatulām aṣṭādhikāṃ dattvā //
column2: Placing on the right hand (of the. image of Vâsudeva, and kindling, a lamp) containing one hundred and eight Palas of clarified butter, with an entire piece of cloth (together with the fringes) dyed with saffron (as wick) in it;

column1: vāmapārśve tilatailayutāṃ sāṣṭāṃ dattvā śvetena samagreṇa vāsasā //
column2: (And placing) on its left, (and kindling, a lamp) containing one hundred and eight Palas of sesamum oil, with an entire piece of white cloth (as wick) in it.

column1: etat kṛtvā yasmin rāṣṭre 'bhijāyate yasmin deśe yasmin kule tatrojjvalo bhavati //
column2: He who has performed this rite obtains exquisite happiness, in whatever kingdom, in whatever province, and in whatever race he may be born again.

column1: āśvinaṃ sakalaṃ māsaṃ brāhmaṇebhyaḥ pratyahaṃ ghṛtaṃ pradāyāśvinau prīṇayitvā rūpabhāg bhavati //
column2: He who gives daily during the whole month Âsvina clarified butter to Brâhmanas, in order to please the two Asvins, obtains beauty. He who feeds daily during;

column1: tasminn eva māsi pratyahaṃ gorasair brāhmaṇān bhojayitvā rājyabhāg bhavati //
column2: that mouth (three) Brâhmanas with (milk and other) bovine productions, obtains a kingdom.

column1: pratimāsaṃ revatīyute candramasi madhughṛtayutaṃ pāyasaṃ revatīprītyai paramānnaṃ brāhmaṇān bhojayitvā revatīṃ prīṇayitvā rūpasya bhāgī bhavati
column2: He who feeds on the Revatâ day of every month (three) Brâhmanas with rice boiled in milkwith sugar and mixed with honey and clarified butter, in order to please .(the goddess) Revatî, obtains beauty.

column1: māghe māsy agniṃ pratyahaṃ tilair hutvā saghṛtaṃ kulmāṣaṃ brāhmaṇān bhojayitvā dīptāgnir bhavati //
column2: He who daily throughout the month Mâgha offers sesamum-seeds in fire and feeds (three) Brâhmanas with sour rice-gruel mixed with clarified butter, obtains an excellent digestive power.

column1: sarvāṃ caturdaśīṃ nadījale snātvā dharmarājānaṃ pūjayitvā sarvapāpebhyaḥ pūto bhavati //
column2: He who bathes in a river and worships king Dharma on the fourteenth of both halves of every month, is purified from every sin.

column1: yadīcched vipulān bhogāṃś candrasūryagrahopagān / prātaḥsnāyī bhaven nityaṃ dvau māsau māghaphālgunau //
column2: One desirous of obtaining the manifold advantages attending an eclipse of the sun or moon must constantly bathe in the mornings during the two months Mâgha and Phâlguna.

column1: atha kūpakartus tatpravṛtte pānīye duṣkṛtasyārdhaṃ vinaśyati //
column2: The digger of a well has (the consequences of) the half of his evil acts taken from him as soon as the water comes forth from it.
A digger of pools is for ever freed from thirst, and attains the world of Varuna.
A giver of water shall never stiffer from thirst (in heaven, for a hundred Yugas or ages of the world).
He who plants trees will have those trees for his sons in a future existence.
A giver of trees gladdens the gods by (offering up) their blossoms to them.
(He gladdens) his guests by (giving) their fruits to them;
(He gladdens) travellers with their shade;
(He gladdens) the manes with the water (trickling down from their leaves) when it rains.
A maker of dikes attains heaven.

column1: devāyatanakārī yasya devasyāyatanaṃ karoti tasyaiva lokam āpnoti //
column2: A builder of temples enters the dwelling-place of that deity to whom he has erected a temple.
He who causes (a temple erected by another) to be whitewashed acquires brilliant fame.
He who causes (such a temple) to be painted with (a different) colour (such as blue, yellow, and others) attains the world of the Gandharvas.
By giving flowers he becomes fortunate.
By giving ointments he acquires renown.
By giving a lamp he obtains an excellent eyesight and exquisite happiness.
By giving food he obtains strength.
By removing the remains of an offering to a deity he obtains the same reward as for giving a cow.

column1: devagṛhamārjanāt tadupalepanāt brāhmaṇocchiṣṭamārjanāt pādaśaucād akalyaparicaraṇāc ca //
column2: The same reward is also obtained by scouring a temple, by smearing it (with cow-dung and the like), by removing the leavings of the food of a Brâhmana, by washing his feet, and by nursing him when sick.

column1: kūpārāmataḍāgeṣu devatāyataneṣu ca / punaḥ saṃskārakartā ca labhate maulikaṃ phalam //
column2: He who consecrates anew a well, or a park, or a pool, or a temple (when they have been soiled) obtains the same reward as he who first made them.
Protecting (one attacked by robbers, or by tigers, or otherwise in danger) is more meritorious than any (other) gift.
By doing so he obtains that place of abode (after death) which he desires himself.
By giving land he obtains the same (heavenly reward).

column1: gocarmamātrām api bhuvaṃ pradāya sarvapāpebhyaḥ pūto bhavati //
column2: By giving land to the extent of a bull's hide only he is purified from every sin.
By giving a cow he attains heaven.
A giver of ten milch cows (obtains) the mansion of cows (after death).
A giver of a hundred milch cows enters the mansions of Brahman (after death).

column1: suvarṇaśṛṅgīṃ raupyakhurāṃ muktālāṅgūlāṃ kāṃsyopadohāṃ vastrottarīyāṃ dattvā dhenuromasaṃkhyāni varṣāṇi svargalokam āpnoti //
column2: He who gives (a milch cow) with gilt horns, with hoofs covered with silver, with a tail wound with a string of pearls, with a milk-pail of white copper, and with a cover of cloth, shall reside in heaven for as many years as the cow has hairs on her body;
Particularly, if it is a brown cow.
He who has given a tamed bull is (equal in virtue to) a giver of ten milch cows.
The giver of a horse attains the mansion of Sûrya (the sun-god).
The giver of a garment (attains) the mansion of Kandra (the god of the moon).
By giving gold (he attains) the mansion of Agni (the god of fire).
By giving silver (rûpya, he obtains) beauty (rûpa).
By giving dishes (pâtra) made of (gold or silver or other) metal he renders himself worthy (pâtra) to obtain everything he may desire.
By giving clarified butter, honey, or oil (he acquires) freedom from disease;
The same by giving (boiled or otherwise dressed) drugs.
By giving salt (lavana, he obtains) personal charms (lâvanya).
By giving grain (produced in the rainy season, such as Syâmâka grain, he acquires) satiation;
The same (effect is obtained) by giving grain (produced in winter or spring, such as wild turmeric or wheat).
A giver of food (obtains) all the rewards (enumerated above).
By giving grain (of any of the kinds not mentioned before, such as Kulattha or Kodrava grain, he obtains) good fortune.
A giver of sesamum (obtains) such offspring as he desires. A giver of fuel (obtains) an excellent digestive power;
And he obtains victory in every fight.
By giving a seat (he obtains) high rank.
By giving a bed. a wife (possessed of the qualities mentioned above).
By giving a pair of shoes (he obtains) a carriage yoked with mules.
By giving an umbrella (he attains) heaven.
By giving a fan or a chowrie (he obtains) prosperity in travelling.
By giving a house (he receives) the post of governor of a town.

column1: yad yad iṣṭatamaṃ loke yac cāsti dayitaṃ gṛhe / tat tad guṇavate deyaṃ tad evākṣayam icchatā //
column2: Whatever a man is most fond of in this world (himself) and what his family like best, all that he must bestow upon a virtuous (Brâhmana), if he wishes it to become imperishable.
What is given to another than a Brâhmana produces the same fruit in the world to come.
(What is given) to one who calls himself a Brâhmana (because he was born and initiated as such, but who does not perform his daily duties) produces twice the same fruit.
(What is given) to one who has studied the main portions of the Veda produces a thousand times the same fruit.
(What is given) to one who has mastered the whole Veda, produces infinite fruit.
A domestic priest may claim gifts from his own employer (but from no one else).
And so may a sister, a daughter and sons-in-law (or other connections claim gifts from their. brother, father, &c., but not from a stranger).

column1: na vāry api prayaccheta baiḍālavratike dvije / na bakavratike pāpe nāvedavidi dharmavit //
