column2: One who knows his duty must not give even water to a twice-born man who acts like a cat, or to a Brâhmana who acts like a crane, or to one who has not studied the Veda.

column1: dharmadhvajī sadā lubdhaś chādmiko lokadāmbhikaḥ / baiḍālavratiko jñeyo hiṃsraḥ sarvābhisaṃdhakaḥ //
column2: One who constantly hoists the flag of religion, and who is avaricious, crafty, deceitful, pitiless, and a calumniator of everybody, such a man is said to act like a cat.

column1: adhodṛṣṭir naikṛtikaḥ svārthasādhanatatparaḥ / śaṭho mithyāvinītaś ca bakavrataparo dvijaḥ //
column2: One who hangs his head, who is bent upon, injuring others and upon his own gain, artful, and falsely demure, such a man is said to act like, a crane.

column1: ye bakavratino loke ye ca mārjāraliṅginaḥ / te patanty andhatāmisre tena pāpena karmaṇā //
column2: Those who act like cranes in this world, and those who act like cats, fall into (the hell called) Andhatâmisra on account . of their wickedness.

column1: na dharmasyāpadeśena pāpaṃ kṛtvā vrataṃ caret / vratena pāpaṃ pracchādya kurvan strīśūdradambhanam //
column2: If a man has committed an offence and does penance for it, he must not do so under pretext of performing an act of piety, covering his crime under a (fictitious) vow, and imposing on women and Sûdras.

column1: pretyeha cedṛśo vipro garhyate brahmavādibhiḥ / chadmanācaritaṃ yac ca vrataṃ rakṣāṃsi gacchati //
column2: A Brâhmana who acts thus, is despised in the next life and in this by those who know the Veda, and the penance performed by him under such false pretence goes to the (demons called) Râkshasas.

column1: na dānaṃ yaśase dadyān na bhayān nopakāriṇe / na nṛtyagītaśīlebhyo dharmārtham iti niścitam //
column2: He must not give (to a panegyrist) from vain-glory, or from fear, or to a friend (from whom he hopes to obtain benefit), nor (must he bestow gifts), with a view to acquire religious merit, upon dancers or singers:, that is a fixed rule.
A householder, when he sees his skin has become wrinkled and his hair turned grey, must go to live in a forest.
Or (he must do so) when he sees the son of his son.
Let him (before going into the forest) entrust the care of his wife to his sons, or let her accompany him.
Let him keep the sacred fires in his new abode as before.
He must not omit to perform the five sacrifices,but (he must perform them) with (fruits, herbs, or roots) growing wild.
He must not relinquish the private recitation of the Veda.
He must preserve his chastity.
He must wear a dress made of skins or bark.
He must suffer the hairs of his head, of his beard, and of his body, and his nails to grow.
He must either collect provisions, after the manner of the pigeon, for a month, or he must collect them for a year.
He who has collected provisions for a year, must throw away what he has collected on the day of full moon in the month Âsvina.

column1: grāmād āhṛtya vāśnīyād aṣṭau grāsān vane vasan / puṭenaiva palāśena pāṇinā śakalena vā //
column2: Or an hermit may bring food from a village, placing it in a dish made of leaves, or in a single leaf, or in his hand, or in a potsherd, and eat eight mouthfuls of it.
An hermit must dry up his frame by the practice of austerities.
In summer he must expose himself to five fires.
During the season of the rains he must sleep in the open air.
In winter he must wear wet clothes.
He must eat at night.
He may eat flowers.
He may eat fruits.
He may eat vegetables.
He may eat roots.
Or he may eat boiled barley once at the close of a half-month.
Or he may eat according to the rules of the Kândrâyana.
He shall break his food with stones.
Or he shall use his teeth as a pestle.
This whole world of deities and of men has devotion for its root, devotion for its middle, devotion for its end, and is supported by devotion.

column1: tapomadhyaṃ tapo 'ntaṃ ca tapasā ca tathā dhṛtam // yad duṣcaraṃ yad durāpaṃ yad dūraṃ yac ca duṣkaram /
column2: , What is hard to follow, hard to reach, remote, or hard to do, all that may be accomplished by devotion;

column1: sarvaṃ tat tapasā sādhyaṃ tapo hi duratikramam //
column2: since there is nothing that may not be effected by devotion.

column1: atha triṣv āśrameṣu pakvakaṣāyaḥ prājāpatyām iṣṭiṃ kṛtvā sarvavedasaṃ dakṣiṇāṃ dattvā pravrajyāśramī syāt //
column2: After having passed through the first three orders and annihilated passion, he must offer an oblation to Pragâpati, in which he bestows all his wealth (upon priests) as fee for the performance of the sacrifice, and enter the order of ascetics.

column1: ātmany agnīn āropya bhikṣārthaṃ grāmam iyāt //
column2: Having reposited the fires in his own mind, he must enter the village, in order to collect alms, (but never for any other purpose).
He must beg food at seven houses.
If he does not get food (at one house), he must not grieve.
, He must not beg of another ascetic.

column1: bhuktavati jane atīte pātrasaṃpāte bhaikṣam ādadyāt //
column2: When the servants have had their meal, when the dishes have been removed, let him beg food (consisting of the leavings).
(He must receive the food) in an earthen vessel, or in a wooden bowl, or in a vessel made of the bottle-gourd.
He must cleanse those vessels with water.
He must shun food obtained by humble salutation.
He must live in an empty house.
Or (he must) live at the root of a tree.
He must not stay for more than one night in one village (except during the rainy season).

column1: kaupīnācchādanamātram eva vasanam ādadyāt // dṛṣṭipūtaṃ nyaset pādam //
column2: He must set down his feet purified by looking down.
He must drink water purified (by straining it) with a cloth.
He must utter speeches purified by truth.
He must perform acts purified by his mind.
He must neither wish for death nor for (a long) life.
He must bear abuse patiently.
He must treat no one with contempt.
He must not pronounce a benediction.

column1: vāsyaikaṃ takṣato bāhuṃ candanenaikam ukṣataḥ / nākalyāṇaṃ na kalyāṇaṃ tayor api ca cintayet //
column2: Should one man chop his one arm with an axe, and another sprinkle his other arm with sandal, he must neither curse the one in his mind, nor bless the other.
He must constantly be intent upon stopping his breath, upon retention of the image formed in his mind, and upon meditation.
He must reflect upon the transitoriness of the passage through mundane existence;
And upon the impure nature of the body;
And upon the destruction of beauty by old age;
And upon the pain arising from diseases bodily, mental, or due to an excess (of the bile, &c.)
And upon (the pain arising from) the (five) naturally inherent (affections).
On his having to dwell in an embryo, covered with everlasting darkness;
And on (his having to dwell) between urine and fæces;
On his having to suffer, (as an embryo,) pain from the cold and hot. (food and drink, which his mother happens to have taken);
, On the dreadful pain which he has to suffer, at the time of his birth, while the embryo is coming forth from the narrowness of the womb;
On his ignorance and his dependency upon his (parents and other) Gurus in childhood;
On the manifold anxieties arising from the study of the Veda (and from the other obligations of a student);

column1: yauvane ca viṣayāprāptāv amārgeṇa tadavāptau viṣayasevanān narake patanam //
column2: And (on the anxieties arising) in youth from not obtaining the objects of pleasure, and upon the abode in bell (ordained as punishment) for enjoying them, after they have been obtained unlawfully;
On the union with those whom we hate, and the separation from those whom we love;

column1: narake ca sumahadduḥkham // saṃsārasaṃsṛtau tiryagyoniṣu ca //
column2: On the fearful agonies of hell;

column1: evam asmin satatayāyini saṃsāre na kiṃcit sukham //
column2: (And let him reflect thus that) there is no pleasure to be met with in this never-ceasing passage of the soul through mundane existence;

column1: yad api kiṃcit duḥkhābhāvāpekṣayā sukhasaṃjñaṃ tad apy anityam //
column2: '(And that) even what is called pleasure, on account of the absence of pain, is of a transient nature;
(And that) he who is unable to enjoy such pleasures (from sickness or some such cause), or who is unable to procure them (from poverty), suffers severe pangs.
He must recognise this human frame to consist of seven elements. blood, flesh,
Those elements are, adeps, scrum of flesh, bone, marrow, and semen.
It is covered with skin.
And it has a nasty smell.
It is the receptacle of (the above-named) impure substances (adeps and the rest).
Though surrounded by a hundred pleasures, it is subject to change.
Though carefully supported (by elixirs and the like), it is subject to destruction.
It is the stay of carnal desire, wrath, greed, folly, pride, and selfishness.
It consists of earth, water, fire, air, and ether.
it is provided with bone, tubular vessels (carrying bile and phlegm through the body), tubes (conducting the vital airs), and sinews.
It is endowed with the quality of ragas (passion).
It is covered with six skins.
It is kept together by three hundred and sixty bones.
They are distributed (as follows):
The teeth together with their receptacles are sixty-four in number.
There are twenty nails.
There are as many bones to the hands and feet (one at the root of each finger and toe).
There are sixty joints to the fingers and toes.
There are two (bones) to the two heels.
There are four to the ancles. {sic}
There are four to the elbows.
There are two to the knees and two to the cheeks.
(There are two) to the thighs and (two) to the shoulders.
(There are two) to the lower part of the temples, (two) to the palate, and (two) to the hips.
The backbone consists of forty-five (bones).
The neck consists of fifteen (bones).
The collar-bone consists of one (bone on each side).
The jaw likewise.
There are two (bones) at its root.
There are two (bones) to the forehead, (two) to the eyes, and (two) to the cheeks.,
The nose has one bone, the nose-bone.

column1: arbudaiḥ sthālakaiś ca sārdhaṃ dvāsaptatiḥ pārśvakāḥ //
column2: The ribs together with the joints called 'arbuda,' and with the joints called 'sthânaka,' consist of seventy-two (bones).
The breast contains seventeen bones.
There are two temporal bones.
The head has four skull-bones. Thus (the bones have been enumerated).
There are in this human frame seven hundred tubular vessels (carrying bile and phlegm through the body, or arteries).
Of sinews, there are nine hundred.
Of tubes (conducting the vital airs, or nerves), there are two hundred.
Of muscles, there are five hundred.
Of tubular vessels (or arteries), the branches of the smaller tubular vessels, there are twenty-nine Lakshas (two millions nine hundred thousand) and nine hundred and fifty-six.
Of hair-holes, of the hair of the beard and of the head, there are three hundred thousand.
Of sensitive parts of the body, there are one hundred and seven.
Of joints, there are two hundred.

Of (atoms of) hairs (of the body), there are fifty-four Kotis (or five hundred and forty millions) and sixty-seven Lakshas (making in all five hundred and forty-six millions and seven hundred thousand).

column1: nābhirājo gudaṃ śukraṃ śoṇitaṃ śaṅkhakau mūrdhā kaṇṭho hṛdayaṃ ceti prāṇāyatanāṇi //
column2: The navel, the principle of vital action (which dwells in the heart), the anus, semen, blood, the temples, the head, the throat, and the heart are the seats of the vital airs.

column1: bāhudvayaṃ jaṅghādvayaṃ madhyaṃ śīrṣam iti ṣaḍaṅgāni //
column2: The two arms, the two legs, the belly, and the bead are the six limbs.

column1: vasā vapā avahananaṃ nābhiḥ klomā yakṛt plīhā kṣudrāntraṃ vṛkkakau bastiḥ purīṣādhānaṃ āmāśayaḥ hṛdayaṃ sthūlāntraṃ gudam udaraṃ gudakoṣṭham
column2: Adeps, marrow, the left lung, the navel, the right lung, the liver, the spleen, the small cavity of the heart, the kidneys, the bladder, the rectum, the stomach, the heart, the large cavity (intestine), theanus, the belly, and the two bowels in it (are the inner parts of the body).

column1: kanīnike akṣikūṭe śaṣkulī karṇau karṇapatrakau gaṇḍau bhruvau śaṅkhau dantaveṣṭau oṣṭhau kakundare vaṅkṣaṇau vṛṣaṇau vṛkkau śleṣmasaṃghātikau stanau upajihvā sphicau bāhū jaṅghe ūrū piṇḍike tālūdaraṃ bastiśīrṣau cibukaṃ galaśuṇḍike avaṭuś cety asmin
column2: The pupils of the eye, the eyelashes, the outer parts of the cars, the ears themselves, the tragus of each ear, the cheeks, the eyebrows, the temples, the gums, the lips, the cavities of the loins, the two groins, the scrotum, the two kidneys and breasts of females, which are composed of phlegm, the uvula, the hindparts, the arms, the shanks, the thighs, the fleshy parts of the shanks and thighs, the palate, the two bones (or muscles) at the upper end of the bladder, the chin, the soft palate, and the nape of the neck: these are the 'places' (of vital energy) in the body.
Sound, tangibility, form or colour, savour, and odour are the (five) objects of sense.
Nose, eye, skin, tongue, and ear are the (five) organs of perception.
Hands, feet, anus, parts of generation, and tongue are the (five) organs of action.
Mind, intellect, the individual Self, and the indiscrete' are 'that which exceeds the senses.'

column1: idaṃ śarīraṃ vasudhe kṣetram ity abhidhīyate / etad yo vetti taṃ prāhuḥ kṣetrajñam iti tadvidaḥ //
column2: This human frame, O Earth, is called 'field.' He who knows (how to enter and how to leave) it is denominated, by those conversant with thesubject, 'the knower of the field' (i.e. Self or Soul).

column1: kṣetrajñam api māṃ viddhi sarvakṣetreṣu bhāvini / kṣetrakṣetrajñavijñānaṃ jñeyaṃ nityaṃ mumukṣuṇā //
column2: Know me, O illustrious one, to be the Self of all fields (whether born from the womb, or arisen from an egg, or from sweat, or from a germ or shoot). Those striving after final emancipation must constantly seek to understand the 'field' and to obtain a knowledge of the knower of the field.

column1: ūrusthottānacaraṇaḥ savye kare karam itaraṃ nyasya tālusthācalajihvo dantair dantān asaṃspṛśan svaṃ nāsikāgraṃ paśyan diśaś cānavalokayan vibhīḥ praśāntātmā caturviṃśatyā tattvair vyatītaṃ cintayet //
column2: Sitting with the feet stretched out and crossed so as to touch the thighs, with the right hand (stretched out and) resting upon the left, with the tongue fixed in the palate, and without bringing the one row of teeth in contact with the other, with the eyes directed to the tip of the nose, and without glancing at any of the (four) quarters of the sky, free from fear, and with composure, let him meditate upon (Purusha), who is separate from the twenty-four entities,

column1: nityam atīndriyam aguṇaṃ śabdasparśarūparasagandhātītaṃ sarvajñam atisthūlam //
column2: He who is eternal, beyond the cognisance of the senses, destitute of qualities, not concerned with sound, tangibility, form, savour, or odour, knowing everything, of immense size,
He who pervades everything, and who is devoid of form,
Whose hands and feet are everywhere, whose eyes, head, and face are everywhere, and who is able to apprehend everything with all the senses.
Thus let him meditate.
If he remains absorbed in such meditation for a year, he obtains the accomplishment of Yoga (concentration of the thought and union with the Supreme).

column1: tadā pṛthivyaptejovāyvākāśamanobuddhyātmāvyaktapuruṣāṇāṃ pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ dhyātvā tatra labdhalakṣaḥ tatparityajyāparam aparaṃ dhyāyet //
column2: If he is unable to fix his mind upon the beingdestitute of form, he must meditate successively on earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect, self, the indiscrete, and Purusha: having fully apprehended one, he must dismiss it from his thoughts and fix his mind upon the next one in order.
In this way let him arrive at meditation upon Purusha.

column1: tatrāpy asamarthaḥ svahṛdayapadmasya avāṅmukhasya madhye dīpavat puruṣaṃ dhyāyet //
column2: If unable to follow this method also, he must meditate on Purusha shining like a lamp in his heart, as in a lotus turned upside down.

column1: tatrāpy asamartho bhagavantaṃ vāsudevaṃ kirīṭinaṃ kuṇḍalinam aṅgadinaṃ śrīvatsāṅkaṃ vanamālāvibhūṣitoraskaṃ saumyarūpaṃ caturbhujaṃ śaṅkhacakragadāpadmadharaṃ caraṇamadhyagatabhuvaṃ dhyāyet //
column2: If he cannot do that either, he must meditate upon Bhagavat Vâsudeva (Vishnu), who is adorned with a diadem, with ear-rings, and with bracelets, who has the (mystic mark) Srîvatsa and a garland of wood-flowers on his breast, whose aspect is pleasing, who has four arms, who holds the shell, the discus, the mace, and the lotus-flower, and whose feet are supported (and worshipped) by the earth.
Whatever he meditates upon, that is obtained by a man (in a future existence): such is the mysterious power of meditation.

column1: tasmāt sarvam eva kṣaraṃ tyaktvā akṣaram eva dhyāyet //
column2: Therefore must he dismiss everything perishablefrom his thoughts and meditate upon what is imperishable only.

column1: na ca puruṣaṃ vinā kiṃcid apy akṣaram asti //
column2: There is nothing imperishable except Purusha.
Having become united with him (through constant meditation), he obtains final liberation.

column1: puram ākramya sakalaṃ śete yasmān mahāprabhuḥ / tasmāt puruṣa ity evaṃ procyate tattvacintakaiḥ //
column2: Because the great lord pervades the whole universe (pura), as he is lying there (sete), therefore is he denominated Puru-sha by those who reflect upon the real nature (of the Supreme Spirit).

In the first part and the latter part of the night must a man bent on contemplation constantly and with fixed attention meditate upon Purusha Vishnu, who is destitute of (the three) qualities (sattva, ragas, and tamas) and the twenty-fifth entity.

column1: tattvātmānam agamyaṃ ca sarvatattvavivarjitam / aśaktaṃ sarvabhṛc caiva nirguṇaṃ guṇabhoktṛ ca //
column2: He (or it) is composed of the entities, beyond the cognisance of the senses, distinct from all the (other) entities, free from attachment (to the producer, &c.), supporting everything, devoid of qualities and yet enjoying (or witnessing the effect of) qualities.

column1: bahir antaś ca bhūtānām acaraṃ caram eva ca /
column2: It exists without and within created beings (as being enjoyed and as enjoyer), and in the shape both of immovable things (such as trees or stones) and of movable things (such as water or fire);

column1: sūkṣmatvāt tadavijñeyaṃ dūrasthaṃ cāntike ca tat //
column2: it is undistinguishable on account of its subtlety;

column1: avibhaktaṃ ca bhūtena vibhaktam iva ca sthitam /
column2: It is not distinct from creation, and yet distinct from it in outward appearance;

column1: bhūtabhavyabhavadrūpaṃ grasiṣṇu prabhaviṣṇu ca // jyotiṣām api tajjyotis tamasaḥ param ucyate / jñānaṃ jñeyaṃ jñānagamyaṃ hṛdi sarvasya dhiṣṭhitam //
column2: It is termed the light of the sidereal bodies and the enemy of darkness (ignorance), it is knowledge, it should be known, it may be understood (by meditation), it dwells in every man's heart.

column1: iti kṣetraṃ tathā jñānaṃ jñeyaṃ coktaṃ samāsataḥ /
column2: Thus the 'field,' knowledge (or meditation), and what should be known have been concisely declared;
that faithful adherent of mine who makes himself acquainted therewith, becomes united to me in spirit.

column1: ity evam uktā vasumatī jānubhyāṃ śirasā ca namaskāraṃ kṛtvovāca //
column2: When Vishnu had finished his speech, the goddess of the earth inclined her knees and her head before him and said:

column1: bhagavan, tvatsamīpe satatam evaṃ catvāri bhūtāni kṛtālayāni ākāśaḥ śaṅkharūpī,
column2: 'O Bhagavat! Four (out of the five) grosser elements are receiving their support from thee, and are constantly about thee: the ether, in the form of the shell;
the air, in the form of the discus;
the fire, in the form of the mace;

column2: and the water, in the form of the lotus. Now I also desire to attend upon thee, in my own shape, as the ground which Bhagavat's feet tread upon.'

column1: ity evam ukto bhagavāṃs tathety uvāca //
column2: Having been addressed thus by the goddess of the earth, Bhagavat answered, 'So be it.'
And the goddess of the earth, her desire having been gratified, did as she had said.
And she praised the god of the gods (as follows):
'Om. Adoration be to thee.
'Thou art the god of the gods.
'Thou art Vâsudeva.
'Thou art the creator.
'Thou art the god (who, creates, preserves, and destroys) at will.
'Thou art the gratifier of human desires.
'Thou art the guardian of the earth.
'Thou art the lord (protector) of creatures.
'Thou art the exalted lord of creatures.
'Thou art the lord of strength.
'Thou art the lord of holy speech.
'Thou art the lord (creator and preserver) of the world.
'Thou art the lord of heaven.
'Thou art the lord of woods (who makes the trees grow).
'Thou art the lord (producer) of (mother's) milk.
'Thou art the lord of the earth (and causest it to yield its produce)
'Thou art the lord of the waters.
'Thou art the lord of the (eight) quarters of the sky.
'Thou art the lord of (the principle) Mahat.
'Thou art the lord of the wind.
'Thou art the lord of happiness.
'Thou art Brahman personified.
'Thou art dear to Brâhmanas.
'Thou pervadest everything.
'Thou surpassest all conception.
'Thou art attainable by knowledge (meditation).
'Thou art invoked at many (offerings).
'Thou art praised with many (hymns of the Veda).
'Thou likest everything sacred.
'Thou art fond of Brahman (the Veda).
'Thou belongest to the (gods called) Brahmakâyas.
'Thy size is immense.
'Thou belongest to the Mahârâgas.
'Thou belongest to the four Mahârâgas.
'Thou art brilliant.
'Thou art most brilliant.
'Thou art the seven (parts of a Sâman, or the seven divisions of the universe).
'Thou art most blessed.
'Thou art tone.
'Thou art Tushita (or "satisfied with the honours shown to thee by faithful attendants").
'Thou art Mahâtushita (or "highly satisfied even without being worshipped").
'Thou art the tormentor (destroyer of the world).
'Thou art wholly created.
'Thou art uncreated.
'Thou art obsequious (to thy followers).
'Thou art sacrifice.
, 'Thou art the (recipient of the) great sacrifice.
'Thou art connected with sacrifices.
'Thou art the fit recipient of offerings.
Thou art the consummation of offerings.
Thou art invincible.
'Thou art Vaikuntha.
'Thou surpassest (the organs of sense, mind, and intelligence).
'Thou art of old.
'Thou art the protector of living beings.
'Thou wearest radiant locks of hair.
'Thou takest thy sacrificial cake.
'Thou art lord over everything.
'Thou art the support of all.
'Thy ears are pure.
'Never ceasing homage is paid to thee.
'Thou art blazing fire (or "Thou art shining with clarified butter offered up to thee").
'Thou hast a lotus springing from thy navel.
'Thou holdest a lotus (in thy hand).
'Thou wearest a garland of lotus-flowers.
'Thou hast one horn.
'Thou art the great boar.
'Thou art eternal.
'Thou art infinite.
Thou art Purusha.
Thou art the great (unbounded) Purusha.
Thou art (the sage) Kapila.
Thou art the teacher of the Sânkhya.
Thy powers are everywhere.
Thou art virtue.
Thou art the giver of both virtue and wealth.
Desires are gratified by thee.
Thou art Vishnu.
Thou art triumphant everywhere.
Thou art capable of bearing (the extremities of heat and cold and any others).
Thou art Krishna.
Thou art the lotus-eyed god.
Thou art Nârâyana (the son of Nara).
Thou art the final aim.
Thou art the resort of all beings.
Adoration, adoration (be to thee)!'

column1: stutvā tv evaṃ prasannena manasā pṛthivī tadā / uvāca saṃmukhaṃ devīṃ labdhakāmā vasuṃdharā //
column2: The goddess of the earth, after her desire had been gratified, and after she had thus praised(Vishnu) with a cheerful mind I addressed herself to the goddess (Lakshmî).

column1: dṛṣṭvā śriyaṃ devadevasya viṣṇor gṛhītapādāṃ tapasā jvalantīm / sutaptajāmbūnadacāruvarṇāṃ papraccha devīṃ vasudhā prahṛṣṭā //
column2: After having seen Sri (Lakshmî), the goddess of the earth, highly pleased, questioned (in the following manner) that goddess, who was stroking the feet of Vishnu, the god of the gods, who was shining with the splendour of her austerities, and whose face was radiant like melted gold.

'O charming lady! Thy hands are as beautiful as the expanded red lotus. Thou art holding the feet of him whose navel resembles the expanded red lotus. Thou art constantly residing in an abode resembling the expanded red lotus. Thy waist has the colour of the expanded red lotus.
thy hue is radiant like gold; thy robe is white; thy body is adorned with gems;
thou art resplendent like the sun;

column1: tvam eva nidrā jagataḥ pradhānā lakṣmīr dhṛtiḥ śrīr viratir jayā ca /
column2: thou art Srî; thou art indifference (the freedom from all worldly pursuits and appetites, which is the consequence of final emancipation); thou art victory;thou art beauty;

column1: kāntiḥ prabhā kīrtir atho vibhūtiḥ sarasvatī vāg atha pāvanī ca //
column2: thou art the power of expression;

column1: svadhā titikṣā vasudhā pratiṣṭhā sthitiḥ sudīkṣā ca tathā sunītiḥ /

column1: khyātir viśālā ca tathānasūyā svāhā ca medhā ca tathaiva buddhiḥ //

column1: ākramya sarvaṃ tu yathā trilokīṃ tiṣṭhaty ayaṃ devavaro 'sitākṣi / tathā sthitā tvaṃ varade tathāpi pṛcchāmy ahaṃ te vasatiṃ vibhūteḥ //
column2: 'As the first of the gods (Vishnu) pervades the whole aggregate of the three worlds (sky, atmosphere, and earth), even so doest thou, O black-eyed bestower of gifts. Yet I inquire for the dwelling, in which thy superhuman power is residing.'

column1: ity evam uktā vasudhāṃ babhāṣe lakṣmīs tadā devavarāgrataḥsthā / sadā sthitāhaṃ madhusūdanasya devasya pārśve tapanīyavarṇe //
column2: The goddess of the earth having thus spoken to her, Lakshmî, standing by the side of the chief of the gods, enunciated the following answer: 'I am constantly at the side of the brilliant destroyer of Madhu, O goddess, who shinest like gold.

column1: asyājñayā yaṃ manasā smarāmi śriyā yutaṃ taṃ pravadanti santaḥ / saṃsmāraṇe cāpy atha yatra cāhaṃ sthitā sadā tac chṛṇu lokadhātri //
column2: 'But learn from me, where I reside (besides), O support of the world, from the instruction of him, whom I am constantly reflecting upon in my mind, and whom the virtuous call the husband of Srî, and from my own recollection.

column2: 'I reside in the sun, in the moon, and in the cloudless atmosphere in which the flock of the stars is spread out. (I reside) in that cloud, from which the waters of the rain pour down, in that cloudwhich is adorned with Indra's bow and in that cloud from which the rays of lightning flash forth.

column1: tathā suvarṇe vimale ca rūpye ratneṣu vastreṣv amaleṣu bhūme / prāsādamālāsu ca pāṇḍurāsu devālayeṣu dhvajabhūṣiteṣu //
column2: '(I reside) in bright gold and silver, and in spotless gems and clothes, O goddess of the earth. (I reside) in rows of whitewashed palaces and in temples decorated with the attributes of deities.

column1: sadyaḥ kṛte cāpy atha gomaye ca matte gajendre turage prahṛṣṭe / vṛṣe tathā darpasamanvite ca vipre tathaivādhyayanaprapanne //
column2: '(I reside) in fresh cow-dung, in a noble elephant in rut, in a horse exulting in his vigour, in a proud bull, and in a Brâhmana who studies the Veda.

column1: siṃhāsane cāmalake ca bilve chatre ca śaṅkhe ca tathaiva padme /
column2: 'I reside in a throne, in an Âmalaka (Dhâtrî) shrub, in a Bel tree, in an umbrella, in a shell (trumpet), in a lotus-flower;

column1: dīpte hutāśe vimale ca khḍga ādarśabimbe ca tathā sthitāham //
column2: in blazing fire, and in a polished sword or mirror. 'I reside in jars filled with water and in painted (halls), in which there are chowries and fans;
in splendid golden vessels, and in earth recently thrown up.

column1: kṣīre tathā sarpiṣi śādbale ca kṣaudre tathā dadhni puraṃdhrigātre /
column2: '(I reside) in milk, butter, fresh grass, honey, and sour milk;

column1: dehe kumāryāś ca tathā surāṇāṃ tapasvināṃ yajñahutāṃ ca dehe //
column2: in the body of a married woman, in the frame of an unmarried damsel, and in the frame of (images of) gods, of ascetics, and of officiating priests.

column1: śare ca saṃgrāmavinirgate ca sthitā mṛte svargasadaḥprayāte /
column2: '(I reside) in an arrow, in one who, has returned (victorious) from battle, and in one who has fallen on the field of honour and proceeded to a scat in heaven;

column1: vedadhvanau cāpy atha śaṅkhaśabde svāhāsvadhāyām atha vādyaśabde //
column2: in the sound of (repeating) the Veda, in the flourish of the shell (trumpet), in the sacrificial exclamations addressed to the gods and to the manes, and in the sound of musical instruments.

column1: rājyābhiṣeke ca tathā vivāhe yajñe vare snātaśirasy athāpi / puṣpeṣu śukleṣu ca parvateṣu phaleṣu ramyeṣu saridvarāsu //
column2: '(I reside) in the consecration of a king, in the marriage ceremony, in a sacrifice, in a bridegroom, in one who has washed his head, in white flowers, in mountains, in fruits, in (islets in themiddle of a river and other) pleasant spots, and in large streams.

column1: saraḥsu pūrṇeṣu tathā jaleṣu saśādvalāyāṃ bhuvi padmakhaṇḍe / vane ca vatse ca śiśau prahṛṣṭe sādhau nare dharmaparāyaṇe ca // ācāraseviny atha śāstranitye vinītaveṣe ca tathā suveṣe /
column2: '(I reside) in lakes filled with water, in (pure) waters, and in ground covered with fresh grass, in a wood abounding in lotuses (and fruits), in a newborn infant, in a suckling, in one exulting in joy, in a virtuous man, and in one wholly bent upon practising the law.

column1: suśuddhadānte malavarjite ca mṛṣṭāśane cātithipūjake ca //
column2: '(I reside) in a man who observes approved usages, in one who constantly acts up to the sacred law, in one modestly, and in one splendidly attired, in one who keeps his organs of sense and his mind under control, in one free from sin, in one whose food is pure, and in one who honours his guests.

column1: svadāratuṣṭe nirate ca dharme dharmotkaṭe cātyaśanād vimukte / sadā sapuṣpe sasugandhigātre sugandhalipte ca vibhūṣite ca //
column2: '(I reside) in one who is satisfied with his own wife (and does not covet other men's wives), in one bent upon doing his duty, in one eminently virtuous, in one who refrains from eating too often (i. e. three or four times a day), in one constantly adorned with flowers, in one who associates with such as anoint their limbs with fragrant unguents, in one who is scented with perfumes (himself), and in one adorned (with bracelets and ear-rings).

column1: satye sthite bhūtahite niviṣṭe kṣamānvite krodhavivarjite ca /
column2: '(I reside) in one habitually veracious, in one friendly towards all creatures, in a married householder, in one forbearing, in one free from wrath, in one skilled in his own business, and in one skilled in other men's business, in one who never thinks of any but propitious things, and in one constantly humble..

column1: nārīṣu nityaṃ suvibhūṣitāsu pativratāsu priyavādinīṣu / amuktahastāsu sutānvitāsu suguptabhāṇḍāsu balipriyāsu //
column2: '(I reside) in women who wear proper ornaments always, who are devoted to their husbands, whose speeches are kind, who keep up saving habits, who have sons, who keep their household utensils ingood order, and who are fond of offering domestic oblations.

'(I reside) in women who keep the house clean (by scouring it, plastering it with cow-dung, and the like), who keep their organs, of sense under control, who are not quarrelsome, contented, strictly, observing the law, and charitable;

column1: dharmavyapekṣāsu dayānvitāsu sthitā sadāhaṃ madhusūdane ca //
column2: and I always reside in the destroyer of Madhu.

column1: nimeṣamātraṃ ca vinā kṛtāhaṃ na jātu tiṣṭhe puruṣottamena //
column2: 'I do not remain separated from Purushottama for a single moment.'

column1: dharmaśāstram idaṃ śreṣṭhaṃ svayaṃ devena bhāṣitam / ye dvijā dhārayiṣyanti teṣāṃ svarge gatiḥ parā //
column2: Those among the twice-born who will act according to (the precepts promulgated in) this excellent law-code, which has been proclaimed by the god himself, shall obtain a most excellent abode in heaven.

column1: idaṃ pavitraṃ maṅgalyaṃ svargyam āyuṣyam eva ca / jñānaṃ caiva yaśasyaṃ ca dhanasaubhāgyavardhanam //
column2: It purifies from sin, it is auspicious, it leads to heaven, procures long life, knowledge (of the four objects of human pursuit) and renown, and increases wealth and prosperity.

column1: adhyetavyaṃ dhāraṇīyaṃ śrāvyaṃ śrotavyam eva ca / śrāddheṣu śrāvaṇīyaṃ ca bhūtikāmair naraiḥ sadā // ya idaṃ paṭhate nityaṃ bhūtikāmo naraḥ sadā /
column2: . It must be studied, it must be borne in mind, it must be recited, it must be listened too, and it must be constantly repeated at Srâddhas by persons desirous of prosperity.laws, which is conducive to happiness, the best means of purification, destructive of bad dreams, productive of a great deal of religious merit, and the source of prosperity.]
